_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of âbele 'apple tree.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Obelis (LPDB) HG Apfelbaum (DFD). | Inherited in EB as an l-stem but transferred to the i- and ē-stems, cf. Lt. dial. C-st. gen.sg. obelès~obel̃s a.o., Lv. dial. i-f âbels, Lt. i-f obelìs. Outside EB we only find forms extended with n-suffix, cf. OPr. wobalne, OCS ablanь, OIr. aball, Lat. top. Abella. If 'apple tree' was lexicalized on the basis of oblique forms of *ábōl (vel sim.) 'apple' then EB forms seem archaic. | ALEW s.v. obelìs; Derksen 2015, 339; LEW 515; Mažiulis 4, 259; ME 1, 234; SEJL 831 s.v. obelìs and obuolỹs.
nom.pl. of ābelis, Motionsmasculinum to âbele 'apple tree.' Only exists as a personal name and a surname, cf. Lt Obelis (LPDB) HG Apfelbaum (DFD). LPV 39; LVV 1, 61 s.v. âbele.
_alternative etymology: variant of ābels ← He. habel 'breath; vapour; vanity' via HG Abel (LPV 39).

_etymology: nom.pl. of ābelietis 'apple grower.' ietis-derivation to âbele 'apple tree.' Possibly a surname, cf. Lt Obeliẽnis (LPDB) HG Appelman (DFD). AK.

nom.pl. of ābeļkalns 'apple tree hill.' Also a surname (LUV), probably referring to someone living on or near an apple tree hill. | Compound of âbele 'apple tree' and kal̂ns 'hill, mountain.' | AK.

pl.tant. 'Ābeļi cemetery' | Syntagm of gen. of pl.tant. top. Ābeļi and nom.pl. of kaps 'grave; (pl.) cemetery.' Ābeļi is the nom.pl. of surname Ābelis (LUV), a Motionsmaskulinum to âbele 'apple tree,' cf. also Lt. Obelis (LPDB) HG Apfelbaum (DFD). Exists only as surname and toponym. | LPV 39; LVV 1, 61 s.v. âbele.

dial. for pl.tant. ābeļu kapi 'Ābeļi cemetery' | Syntagm of gen. of pl.tant. top. Ābeļi and nom.pl. of kaps 'grave; (pl.) cemetery.' Ābeļi is the nom.pl. of surname Ābelis (LUV), a Motionsmaskulinum to âbele 'apple tree,' cf. also Lt. Obelis (LPDB) HG Apfelbaum (DFD). Dial. variant probably a surname, too. | LPV 39; LVV 1, 61 s.v. âbele.

syntagm of gen. of pl.tant. top. Ābeļi and muĩža 'estate,' i.e., 'Ābeļi estate.' Top. Ābeļi is the nom.pl. of Ābelis, Motionsmasculinum to âbele 'apple tree.' Only exists as a personal or surname, cf. Lt. Obelis (LPDB) HG Apfelbaum (DFD). LPV 39; LVV 1, 61 s.v. âbele.

dial. for ābeļu muiža, syntagm of gen. of pl.tant. top. Ābeļi and muĩža 'estate,' i.e., 'Ābeļi estate.' Top. Ābeļi is the nom.pl. of Ābelis, Motionsmasculinum to âbele 'apple tree.' Probably a personal or surname, cf. Lt. Obelis (LPDB) HG Apfelbaum (DFD). LPV 39; LVV 1, 61 s.v. âbele.

syntagm of gen. of pl.tant. top. Ābeļi and nom.-acc.pl. of sala 'island; hillock in marsh,' i.e., 'Ābeļi islands.' Top. Ābeļi is the nom.pl. of Ābelis, Motionsmasculinum to âbele 'apple tree.' Only exists as a personal or surname, cf. Lt. Obelis (LPDB) HG Apfelbaum (DFD). LPV 39; LVV 1, 61 s.v. âbele.
nom.pl. of ābeļzieds, compound of âbele 'apple tree' and ziêds 'blossom.' AK.
syntagm of gen.pl. of âbeļziêds 'apple blossom' (a compound of âbele 'apple tree' and ziêds 'blossom') and nom.-acc.pl. of mãja 'house.' AK.
nom.pl. of âbuõldā̀rzs, compound of âbuõls 'apple' and dā̀rzs 'garden.' AK.

nom.pl. of ābuoliņš 'clover.' Inherited as iņš-derivation to âbuõls 'apple' but contaminated with *dāˀbilas vel sim., cf. Lt dóbilas 'clover.' Similarly OPr wobilis 'clover' with w- from woble 'apple.' Also a surname, probably referring to someone living on or near a clover field, cf. Lt. Dóbilas (LPDB) HG Klee (DFD). ALEW s.v. dóbilas; Derksen 2015, 339; LEW 99 s.v. dóbilas; ME 1, 234; 1, 446 s.v. dâbuols; SEJL 223 s.v. dobilaĩ.
_alternative etymology: might be a surname in the sense 'apple grower.'

_etymology: nom.pl. of ābuoliņš 'clover.' Inherited as iņš-derivation to âbuõls 'apple' but contaminated with *dāˀbilas vel sim., cf. Lt dóbilas 'clover.' Similarly OPr wobilis 'clover' with w- from woble 'apple.' Also a surname, probably referring to someone living on or near a clover field, cf. Lt. Dóbilas (LPDB) HG Klee (DFD). ALEW s.v. dóbilas; Derksen 2015, 339; LEW 99 s.v. dóbilas; ME 1, 234; 1, 446 s.v. dâbuols; SEJL 223 s.v. dobilaĩ.
_alternative etymology: might be a surname in the sense 'apple grower.'

_etymology: syntagm of gen. of top. pl.tant. Sausēji and nom. of top. pl.tant.  ābuoliņš 'clover,' i.e., 'Ābuoliņi-by-Sausēji.' The first element is nom.pl. of sausējs 'fly honeysuckle (lonicera xylosteum); skinny person,' ējs-derivation to sàuss 'dry' (LVV2 S1 248; ME 3, 775). The second element is nom.pl. of ābuoliņš 'clover' which is inherited as a dim. to âbuõls 'apple' but contaminated with *dāˀbilas 'clover,' cf. Lt. dóbilas 'clover.' Similarly OPr. wobilis 'clover' with w- from woble 'apple.' Also a surname, probably referring to someone living on or near a clover field, cf. Lt. Dóbilas (LPDB) HG Klee (DFD) (ALEW s.v. dóbilas; Derksen 2015, 339; LEW 99 s.v. dóbilas; ME 1, 234; 1, 446 s.v. dâbuols; SEJL 223 s.v. dobilaĩ).

nom.-acc.pl. of âbuõlīte, īte-derivation to âbuõls 'apple.' Hardly dim. due to the gender shift. Rather Motionsfemininum to surname Âbuõlītis in the sense 'apple grower' or (perhaps more likely) adjective with the feminine plural substantivized as a noun of place, i.e., 'apple garden.' Âbuõls is inherited as an l-stem but transferred to o- or ii̯o-stem class in both Lv. and Lt., cf. Lv. dial. âbuolis, Lt. óbuolas obuolỹs a.o. Elsewhere in BS a k-suffix is present, cf. OPr. wobelke OCS ablъko etc. In order to account for the variety of attested suffixal ablaut grades in the cognates to both âbuõls 'apple' and âbele 'apple tree' which are considered to have arisen from one lexeme, a holokinetic paradigm is usually reconstructed, i.e., PIE nom.sg. *ábōl gen.sg. *abéls inst.sg. *ablóh1 or nom.sg. *h2ébōl acc.sg. *h2bélm gen.sg. *h2blós vel sim. ALEW s.v. obelìs; Derksen 2015, 339 s.v. obuolys; LEW 515 s.v. obelìs; ME 1, 235; SEJL 831.
_alternative etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of âbuõlīte, dim. to ābuole, dial. for âbele 'apple tree;' an otherwise unattested ē-stem variant of dial. âbuõlĩtis 'clover' (ME 1, 234 s.v. âbuõliņš).

_etymology: nom.pl. of âbuõltiņš, synchronically D to âbuõls 'apple.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Obeliẽnis (LPDB) HG Appelman (DFD). | Inherited as an l-stem but transferred to o- or ii̯o-class in East Baltic, cf. Lv. dial. âbuolis, Lt. óbuolas obuolỹs a.o. Elsewhere in BS a k-suffix is present, cf. OPr. wobelke OCS ablъko etc. In order to account for the variety of attested suffixal ablaut grades in the cognates to both âbuõls 'apple' and âbele 'apple tree' which are considered to have arisen from one lexeme, a holokinetic paradigm is usually reconstructed, i.e., PIE nom.sg. *ábōl gen.sg. *abéls inst.sg. *ablóh1 or nom.sg. *h2ébōl acc.sg. *h2bélm gen.sg. *h2blós vel sim. | ALEW s.v. obelìs; Derksen 2015, 339 s.v. obuolys; LEW 515 s.v. obelìs; ME 1, 235; SEJL 831.
nom.-acc.pl. of acālija 'azalea.' Ultimately from Gr. ἀζαλέᾱ 'dry, parched' via Lat. azalea 'azalea' and probably also HG Azalea 'id.' AK.

partly standardized var. of *acišķas (should be -ys or -is), nom.-acc.pl. of *acišķa, Motionsfemininum to *acišķis 'well builder; well dweller.' Probably an old surname, cf. HG Brunnbauer Brunnengräber a.o. (DFD). Might also be a pl.tant. in the sense 'well digger's house; well place.' | išķa-derivation to aka 'water well,' cf. Lt. ãkas~akà 'hole in the ice' OCS oko 'eye' Gr. ὀπή 'opening, hole.' | ALEW sub akìs; Derksen 2015, 46; LEW 5 sub akìs; ME 1, 62.

dial. or latg. for *acišķi, nom.pl. of *acišķis 'well builder; well dweller.' Probably an old surname, cf. HG Brunnbauer Brunnengräber a.o. (DFD). | išķis-derivation to aka 'water well,' cf. Lt. ãkas~akà 'hole in the ice' OCS oko 'eye' Gr. ὀπή 'opening, hole.' | ALEW sub akìs; Derksen 2015, 46; LEW 5 sub akìs; ME 1, 62.
nom.pl. of PN Ãdams 'Adam.' Ultimately from BHe ādām 'man, earthling' via Gr. Ἀδάμ, Lat Ādām and probably also MLG, cf. also Lt Adamas Adomas. LVV 1, 63; LPV 40.
nom.pl. of pers. name Ãdams 'Adam.' Ultimately from BHe ādām 'man, earthling' via Gr. Ἀδάμ, Lat Ādām and probably also MLG, cf. also Lt Adamas Adomas. LVV 1, 63; LPV 40.

adamova 'Adam's (place).' Also a FN (LUV). | borrowed from Ru. TN adámovo, nom.-acc.sg.neut. to adámov 'Adam's,' itself an ov-derivation to PN Adám 'Adam.' Ultimately from BHe ādām 'man, earthling' probably via Gr. Ἀδάμ. | LVV 1, 4 s.v. adama-muiža; LPV 40 s.v. Ādams.

nom.-acc.sg.neut. of adámov 'Adam's,' ov-derivation to Adám 'Adam' in the sense 'Adam's place.' Ultimately from BHe ādām 'man, earthling' probably via Gr. Ἀδάμ. LVV 1, 4 s.v. adama-muiža; LPV 40 s.v. Ādams.
_alternative etymology: a transliteration of Po adamowo; borrowed from Po adamowo.

_etymology: borrowed from Ru adámovo (top.) with transfer to ā-stems. Ru adámovo is the nom.-acc.sg.neut. to adámov 'Adam's,' an ov-derivation to Adám 'Adam' in the sense 'Adam's place.' Ultimately from BHe ādām 'man, earthling' probably via Gr. Ἀδάμ. LVV 1, 4 s.v. adama-muiža; LPV 40 s.v. Ādams.
_alternative etymology: borrowing of the corresponding nom.sg.fem.; borrowed from Po adamowo or BRu adámava (nom.-acc.sg.neut.); transliteration of BRu nom.-acc.sg.neut. adámava.

_etymology: adamova 'Adam's (place).' Also a FN (LUV). | borrowed from Ru. TN adámovo, nom.-acc.sg.neut. to adámov 'Adam's,' itself an ov-derivation to PN Adám 'Adam.' Ultimately from BHe ādām 'man, earthling' probably via Gr. Ἀδάμ. | LVV 1, 4 s.v. adama-muiža; LPV 40 s.v. Ādams.

Adamova cliff.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of top. Adamova and kràuja 'cliff.' Adamova is borrowed from Ru. top. Adámovo and transferred to the ā-stems. Ru. Adámovo is the nom.-acc.sg.neut. to Adámov 'Adam's,' ov-derivation to Adám 'Adam' in the sense 'Adam's place.' Ultimately borrowed from BHe. ādām 'man, earthling' probably via Gr. Ἀδάμ. | LVV 1, 4 s.v. adama-muiža; LPV 40 s.v. Ādams.

Adámovo is the nom.-acc.sg.neut. to Adámov 'Adam's,' ov-derivation to Adám 'Adam' in the sense 'Adam's place.' Ultimately borrowed from BHe. ādām 'man, earthling' probably via Gr. Ἀδάμ. | LVV 1, 4 s.v. adama-muiža; LPV 40 s.v. Ādams.

nom.-acc.sg.neut. of adámov 'Adam's,' ov-derivation to Adám 'Adam' in the sense 'Adam's place.' Ultimately borrowed from BHe. ādām 'man, earthling' probably via Gr. Ἀδάμ. | LVV 1, 4 s.v. adama-muiža; LPV 40 s.v. Ādams.
_alternative etymology: transliteration of Po adamowo; borrowed from Po adamowo.

_etymology: nom.-acc.sg.neut. of adámov 'Adam's,' ov-derivation to Adám 'Adam' in the sense 'Adam's place.' Ultimately borrowed from BHe. ādām 'man, earthling' probably via Gr. Ἀδάμ. | LVV 1, 4 s.v. adama-muiža; LPV 40 s.v. Ādams.
nom.-acc.pl. of mežruõze 'dog rose (rosa canina)' | Compound of mežs 'forest' and ruõze 'rose.' | AK.
nom.-acc.pl. of ãdere 'blood vessel, artery, vein; sinew; earth-radition (geopathology),' borrowed from MLG āder(e) 'blood vessel, artery, vein; sinew,' cf. also Est āder 'id.' ME 1, 236.

allegro shortening of âdmināni, dial. or partly standardized var. of âdminȩ̃ni, nom.pl. of *âdminȩ̃ns 'member of the tanner's household, tanner's.' Probably a patronymic surname, cf. Po Garbarek (ISNP) HG Gerbers (DFD). | ȩ̃ns-derivation to âdminis 'tanner.' | LVV 1, 64.

dial. or partly standardized var. of âdminȩ̃ni, nom.pl. of *âdminȩ̃ns 'member of the tanner's household, tanner's.' Probably a patronymic surname, cf. Po Garbarek (ISNP) HG Gerbers (DFD). | ȩ̃ns-derivation to âdminis 'tanner.' | LVV 1, 64.

dial. or partly standardized var. of âdminȩ̃ni (lack of vowel length is quite common in AŠĢTD but ņ is unclear—could be contamination with âdmiņi as if derived from plural stem, or pure error), nom.pl. of *âdminȩ̃ns 'member of the tanner's household, tanner's.' Probably a patronymic surname, cf. Po Garbarek (ISNP) HG Gerbers (DFD). | ȩ̃ns-derivation to âdminis 'tanner.' | LVV 1, 64.

dialectal or partly standardized variant of âdminȩ̃ni (less likely of âdmināni), nom.pl. of âdminȩ̃ns, ȩ̃ns-derivation to âdminis 'tanner.' Possibly a patronymic surname in the sense 'member of the tanner's household, tanner's,' cf. HG Gerbers (DFD) Po Garbarek (ISNP). LVV 1, 64.

nom.pl. of âdminis 'tanner,' compound of âda 'skin' and mĩt 'step, tread,' cf. Lt. odaminỹs~odminỹs 'id.' Also a surname, cf. Lt. Ódminis (LPDB) Po. Garbarz (ISNP) HG Gerber (DFD). LEW 454 s.v. mìnti; 515 s.v. óda; ME 1, 236; SEJL 832 s.v. óda.
nom.-acc.pl. of aĩda 'garden, fence.' Borrowed from Est aed 'garden, fence.' LVV 1, 6.
_alternative etymology: less likely to Lt áidas 'echo, noise.'

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of aĩda 'garden, fence.' Borrowed from Est aed 'garden, fence.' LVV 1, 6.
_alternative etymology: less likely to Lt áidas 'echo, noise.'

_etymology: pl.tant. aĩjas 'cradle,' reinterpretation as an ā-stem of aĩjã, interjection used to lull children. ME 1, 12.
_alternative etymology: nom.pl. of *aĩja (could be pl.tant.) 'garden, fence,' borrowed from Est aed 'id.' but based on the nom.pl. aia-d, cf. LVV 1, 6 s.v. aĩdas and aĩjaži.

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of ainava 'landscape, scenery,' ava-derivation to aina 'image.' Both neologisms, first attested in the 19th century. Otherwise etymology unclear. ME 1, 13 sub aina, ainava.
nom.-acc.pl. of ainava 'landscape, scenery,' ava-derivation to aina 'image.' Both neologisms, first attested in the 19th century. Otherwise etymology unclear. ME 1, 13 sub aina, ainava.

nom.-acc.pl. of aĩrĩte, ĩte-derivation to aĩre 'rudder, oar,' borrowed from Liv. air~airas or Est. aer (cf. also Fi. airo) which in turn hail from Gmc. *airō 'id.' Lt. aĩrė 'rudder, oar; sail' might be borrowed from Lv. (LKŽ). Probably rather associative than diminutive in meaning, i.e., a pl.tant. in the sense 'boatsman's house,' cf. also the surname Aĩrĩtis which must mean 'boatsman' like HG Rudel (DFD). LKŽ s.v. aĩrė; ME 1, 13.
nom.pl. of PN Aivars 'Ivor.' Also a FN (LUV). | Borrowed from Eng. Ivor, itself from ON Ívarr 'yew-warrior' which is a compound of *iwa 'yew' and *harjar 'warrior.' | de Vries 1977, 288; LPV 46.

nom.pl. of D to PN Aivars 'Ivor.' Also a FN, cf. LUV s.v. Aivars. | Borrowed from Eng. Ivor, itself from ON Ívarr 'yew-warrior' which is a compound of *iwa 'yew' and *harjar 'warrior.' | de Vries 1977, 288; LPV 46.

nom.pl. of àizkal̂ns 'hill-beyond,' compound of àiz 'behind' and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill,' cf. also variants àizkal̂ne~-is and Lt. ažùkalnė~-is ùžkalnė~-is 'id.' Also a surname, cf. Lt. Ùžkalnis (LPDB) Po. Zabrzeski Zagóra (ISNP). ME 1, 30 s.v. àizkal̂ne.

nom.pl. of àizkal̂nis 'hill-beyond,' compound of àiz 'behind' and -kal̂nis, compositional variant of kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' Variant of àizkal̂ne~-s and cognate with Lt. ažùkalnis~-ė is ùžkalnis~-ė 'id.' Probably a surname, cf. Àizkal̂ns Lt. Ùžkalnis (LPDB) Po. Zabrzeski Zagóra (ISNP). ME 1, 30 s.v. àizkal̂ne.

àizkraũkle 'Kraukle-beyond.' Also a FN (LUV). | Compound of àiz 'behind' and HN Kraukle (nearby stream). Probably a folk etymology of àizkraukne 'barrier, barricade, dam.' | LVV 1, 9; ME 2, 263 s.v. kraûklis; 2, 295 s.v. kŗaukt.

Schloss Ascheraden 'Ascheraden castle.' Also a FN, cf. Ašeradens (LUV). | Borrowed from MLG Ascrath with anaptyctic e and d for t due to secondary association with LG toponyms in -rad(e). Ultimately from an otherwise unattested Lv. *azkrāte~azkrāts 'barrier' which is derived from àizkrât 'pile up; save up.' | Blese 1938, 132–134; LEW 291 s.v. kráuti; LVV 1, 9; ME 1, 33 s.v. àizkrât.
_alternative etymology: MLG Ascrath ← Lv. *azkràce~azkŗãce 'rapids-beyond; beyond the jut' (Blese 1938, 132–134); named after nearby stream Āzķere which is of unclear origin (Biel Gr 44).

_etymology: àizkraukne 'barrier, barricade, dam.' | From older *àizkrautne, compound of àiz 'behind' and *krautne '(stone) heap,' i.e., tnē-derivation to kŗaũt~kraũt 'gather, hoard; load.' | Blese 1938, 132–134; LVV 1, 9; ME 2, 296 s.v. kŗaũt.

aiskarod. | Borrowed from MLG Ascrath, itself from an otherwise unattested Lv. *azkrāte~azkrāts 'barrier' which is derived from àizkrât 'pile up; save up.' Initial ais- influenced by Lv. | Blese 1938, 132–134; LEW 291 s.v. kráuti; LVV 1, 9; ME 1, 33 s.v. àizkrât.
_alternative etymology: MLG Ascrath ← Lv. *azkràce~azkŗãce 'rapids-beyond; beyond the jut' (Blese 1938, 132–134); named after nearby stream Āzķere which is of unclear origin (Biel Gr 44).

_alternative etymology: -n of German extraction; folk etymology change of the Latvian name; scribal errors

_etymology: aschrâte. | Borrowed from MLG Ascrath, itself from an otherwise unattested Lv. *azkrāte~azkrāts 'barrier' which is derived from àizkrât 'pile up; save up.' | Blese 1938, 132–134; LEW 291 s.v. kráuti; LVV 1, 9; ME 1, 33 s.v. àizkrât.
_alternative etymology: MLG Ascrath ← Lv. *azkràce~azkŗãce 'rapids-beyond; beyond the jut' (Blese 1938, 132–134); named after nearby stream Āzķere which is of unclear origin (Biel Gr 44).

_etymology: àizkraũkles pilsdrupas 'Aizkraukle castle ruins.' Gen.sg. of àizkraũkle 'Kraukle-beyond.' Also a FN (LUV). | Compound of àiz 'behind' and HN Kraukle (nearby stream). Probably a folk etymology of àizkraukne 'barrier, barricade, dam.' | LVV 1, 9; ME 2, 263 s.v. kraûklis; 2, 295 s.v. kŗaukt.

àizkraũkles mâcîtãja muĩža 'Aizkraukle clergy house.' Gen.sg. of àizkraũkle 'Kraukle-beyond.' Also a FN (LUV). | Compound of àiz 'behind' and HN Kraukle (nearby stream). Probably a folk etymology of àizkraukne 'barrier, barricade, dam.' | LVV 1, 9; ME 2, 263 s.v. kraûklis; 2, 295 s.v. kŗaukt.

ascheraden. Also a FN, cf. Ašeradens (LUV). | Borrowed from MLG Ascrath with anaptyctic e and d for t due to secondary association with LG toponyms in -rad(e). Ultimately from an otherwise unattested Lv. *azkrāte~azkrāts 'barrier' which is derived from àizkrât 'pile up; save up.' | Blese 1938, 132–134; LEW 291 s.v. kráuti; LVV 1, 9; ME 1, 33 s.v. àizkrât.
_alternative etymology: MLG Ascrath ← Lv. *azkràce~azkŗãce 'rapids-beyond; beyond the jut' (Blese 1938, 132–134); named after nearby stream Āzķere which is of unclear origin (Biel Gr 44).

_etymology: àizkraũkles muĩža 'Aizkraukle estate.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of àizkraũkle 'Kraukle-beyond' and muĩža 'estate.' | AK.

àizkraũkles pilskal̂ns 'Aizkraukle hillfort.' Gen.sg. of àizkraũkle 'Kraukle-beyond.' Also a FN (LUV). | Compound of àiz 'behind' and HN Kraukle (nearby stream). Probably a folk etymology of àizkraukne 'barrier, barricade, dam.' | LVV 1, 9; ME 2, 263 s.v. kraûklis; 2, 295 s.v. kŗaukt.

aschrath. | Borrowed from MLG Ascrath, itself from an otherwise unattested Lv. *azkrāte~azkrāts 'barrier' which is derived from àizkrât 'pile up; save up.' | Blese 1938, 132–134; LEW 291 s.v. kráuti; LVV 1, 9; ME 1, 33 s.v. àizkrât.
_alternative etymology: MLG Ascrath ← Lv. *azkràce~azkŗãce 'rapids-beyond; beyond the jut' (Blese 1938, 132–134); named after nearby stream Āzķere which is of unclear origin (Biel Gr 44).

_etymology: nom.pl. of àizkrauklis 'inhabitant of Aizkraukle' vel sim. | ii̯o-derivation to àizkraũkle, itself a compound of àiz 'behind' and HN Kraukle (nearby stream). Probably a folk etymology of àizkraukne 'barrier, barricade, dam.' | LVV 1, 9; ME 2, 263 s.v. kraûklis; 2, 295 s.v. kŗaukt.

partly standardized var. of àizpùrviẽši (should be -īši), nom.pl. of àizpùrviẽtis 'marsh-beyond dweller.' Also a surname (LUV), cf. Lt. Užpelkaitis (LPDB) Po. Zabłotny (ISNP) HG Moorkamp (DFD). | ietis-derivation to àizpùrvs 'marsh-beyond,' itself a compound of àiz 'behind' and pùrvs 'swamp.' | ME 1, 45.

nom.pl. of gasparts. Probably a pers. or surname, cf. Lv. Gaspars (LUV) Gaspards (PDB) Lt. Gasparas (LPDB) HG Gaspar(d) (DFD). Stem-final t for d might be generalized from nom.sg. | Borrowed from OPers. *ganzabarah 'treasurer' (itself a Medism) via BHe. gizbar and, judging by the final -t, Fr. Gaspard. | LPV 192 s.v. Kaspars.

nom.pl. of aizpurs or aizpuris 'marsh-beyond,' compound of àiz 'behind' and purs, dialectal variant of pùrvs 'swamp,' or -puris, compositional variant of pùrvs. Both Aizpurs and Aizpuris are also surnames, cf. Lt. Užpelkaitis (LPDB) Po. Zabłotny (ISNP) HG Moorkamp (DFD). LVV 1, 11; ME 1, 45.

nom.pl. of aizpurs or aizpuris 'marsh-beyond,' compound of àiz 'behind' and purs, dialectal variant of pùrvs 'swamp,' or -puris, compositional variant of pùrvs. Both Aizpurs and Aizpuris are also surnames, cf. Lt. Užpelkaitis (LPDB) Po. Zabłotny (ISNP) HG Moorkamp (DFD). LVV 1, 11; ME 1, 45.

nom.-acc.pl. of àizpure 'marsh-beyond,' compound of àiz 'behind' and -pure, dialectal variant of -pùrve, itself a compositional variant of pùrvs 'swamp.' Aizpuris also exists as a surname, cf. Lt. Užpelkaitis (LPDB) Po. Zabłotny (ISNP) HG Moorkamp (DFD). LVV 1, 11; ME 1, 45.

nom.pl. of dialectal variant of àizpùrviẽtis 'marsh-beyond dweller,' ietis-derivation to àizpùrvs 'marsh-beyond.' Àizpùrvs is a compound of àiz 'behind' and pùrvs 'swamp.' Probably a surname, cf. Lt. Užpelkaitis (LPDB) Po. Zabłotny (ISNP) HG Moorkamp (DFD). ME 1, 45.

nom.pl. of partly standardized variant of àizpùrviẽtis 'inhabitant of place beyond the marsh.' ietis-derivation to àizpùrvs 'place beyond the marsh.' Àizpùrvs is a compound of àiz 'behind' and pùrvs 'swamp.' Also a surname, cf. Lt. Užpelkaitis (LPDB) Po. Zabłotny (ISNP) HG Moorkamp (DFD). ME 1, 45.
nom.pl. of àizpùrvs 'marsh-beyond,' compound of àiz 'behind' and pùrvs 'swamp.' Also a surname, cf. Lt. Užpelkaitis (LPDB) Po. Zabłotny (ISNP) HG Moorkamp (DFD). LVV 1, 11; ME 1, 45.

nom.pl. of àizpùrviẽtis 'marsh-beyond dweller.' Also a surname (LUV), cf. Lt. Užpelkaitis (LPDB) Po. Zabłotny (ISNP) HG Moorkamp (DFD). | ietis-derivation to àizpùrvs 'marsh-beyond,' itself a compound of àiz 'behind' and pùrvs 'swamp.' | ME 1, 45.

dial. for àizpùrvišķi, nom.pl. of àizpùrvišķis 'marsh-beyond dweller.' Probably a surname, cf. Lt. Užpelkaitis (LPDB) Po. Zabłotny (ISNP) HG Moorkamp (DFD). | išķis-derivation to àizpùrvs 'marsh-beyond,' itself a compound of àiz 'behind' and pùrvs 'swamp.' | ME 1, 45.
dial. or latg. for nīcgalis 'floodplain.' | Compound of nīca 'place downriver' and -galis, compositional variant of gals 'end.' | ME 2, 746 s.v. nīcgals.
floodplain' | Compound of nīca 'place downriver' and -gale, compositional variant of gals 'end.' | ME 2, 746 s.v. nīcgals.
compound of àiz 'behind' and upe 'river, stream,' cf. Lt ùžupis ažùpis a.o. 'river-beyond.' ME 1, 58.

nom.-acc.pl. of àizupĩte, diminutive to àizupe 'river-beyond,' compound of àiz 'behind' and upe 'river, stream,' cf. Lt. ùžupis ažùpis a.o. Also a surname in which case rather 'river-beyond dweller,' cf. Lt. Ùžupis (LPDB) Po. Zarzecki Zarzeczny (ISNP). ME 1, 58.
nom.pl. of àizvẽjš 'lee.' | Compound of àiz 'behind' and vẽjš 'wind,' cf. Lt. ažùvėjis a.o. | ME 1, 59 s.v. àizvẽja.
nom.pl. of àizvẽjš 'lee.' | Compound of àiz 'behind' and vẽjš 'wind,' cf. Lt. ažùvėjis a.o. | ME 1, 59 s.v. àizvẽja.
nom.-acc.pl. of àizvẽja 'lee.' | Compound of àiz 'behind' and -vẽja, compositional variant of vẽjš 'wind,' cf. Lt. ažùvėja a.o. | ME 1, 59.
nom.pl. of àizvẽjš 'lee.' | Compound of àiz 'behind' and vẽjš 'wind,' cf. Lt. ažùvėjis a.o. | ME 1, 59 s.v. àizvẽja.
nom.-acc.pl. of akācija 'acacia.' Ultimately borrowed from Gr. ἀκακίᾱ (itself possibly a substrate word) via Lat. acacia and perhaps HG Akazie, cf. also Lt. akãcija. AK.
nom.-acc.pl. of aka 'water well.' Inherited from PIE, cf. Lt ãkas~akà 'hole in the ice' OCS oko 'eye' Gr ὀπή 'opening, hole.' ALEW s.v. akìs; Derksen 2015, 46; LEW 5 sub akìs; ME 1, 62.
_alternative etymology: borrowed from Liv akk Est hakk 'western jackdaw (coloeus monedula)' or Est akku 'wolf.' LVV 1, 13

_etymology: nom.pl. of partly standardized variant of ãķis 'hook,' borrowed from MLG hake 'hook; huckster, retailer,' cf. also Est hāk. Also a surname in which case meaning might be either 'hook' (referring to a body part, e.g., the nose, or to a blacksmith's or a fisher's tool or to a river bend) or 'huckster, retailer,' cf. Lt. Kablỹs (LPDB), Po. Hak (ISNP), HG Haak (DFD). ME 1, 237.
nom.pl. of akmȩnãjs 'stony; stony area,' ājs-derivation to akmens 'stone, rock,' cf. Lt. akmenójus 'stony area' (and neol. akmenójis 'mineral'). ME 1, 63.

nom.pl. of akmens 'stone, rock.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Ãkmenas (LPDB) Po. Kamień (ISNP) HG Stein (DFD). | Cognate with Lt. akmuõ Gr. ἄκμων 'anvil' Ved áśman- 'whetting stone; sky' Av asman- 'stone; sky' a.o. The Baltic reflexes show centum reflex of the palatal *ḱ though satǝm reflexes occur in Lv. asmens and Lt. ašmuõ 'blade' which are considered cognates. | ALEW s.v. akmuõ; Derksen 2015, 47; LEW 5; ME 1, 64; SEJL 12.

nom.pl. of akmeņkalns 'stone hill,' compound of akmens 'stone, rock' and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' Also a surname, probably referring to someone who lives in a rocky and hilly area, cf. HG Steinberg (DFD). AK.
compound of akmens 'stone, rock' and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' Also a surname, probably referring to someone who lives in a rocky and hilly area, cf. HG Steinberg (DFD). AK.
nom.pl. of akmeņkrasts 'stone shore,' compound of akmens 'stone, rock' and krasts 'shore, bank.' AK.
compound of akmens 'stone, rock' and muĩža 'estate.' Might be a jocular expression for 'prison.' AK.
dialectal for akmeņmuiža 'stone estate,' compound of akmens 'stone, rock' and muĩža 'estate.' Might be a jocular expression for 'prison.' AK.
compound of mũris 'wall' and muĩža 'estate.' Jocular expression for 'prison.' ME 2, 679 s.v. mũrmuiža.
nom.-acc.pl. of akmensdruva 'stone field,' compound of akmens 'stone, rock' and druva 'grainfield.' Possibly a surname, cf. HG Steenhorst Steinfeld (DFD). AK.

nom.pl. of akmentiņš, dim. to akmens 'stone, rock.' Inherited from PIE, cf. Lt akmuõ Gr ἄκμων ‘anvil’ Ved áśman- ‘whetting stone; sky’ Av asman- ‘stone; sky’ a.o. Baltic shows centum reflex of the palatal *ḱ but satǝm reflexes occur in Lv asmens and Lt ašmuõ ‘blade’ which are considered cognates. Also a surname, probably refers to someone who lives in a rocky place, cf. Lt. Akmenė̃lis (LPDB) Po. Kamieniak (ISNP) HG Steinel (DFD). ALEW s.v. akmuõ; Derksen 2015, 47; LEW 5; ME 1, 64; SEJL 12

nom.pl. of akmentiņš, dim. to akmens 'stone, rock.' Inherited from PIE, cf. Lt akmuõ Gr ἄκμων ‘anvil’ Ved áśman- ‘whetting stone; sky’ Av asman- ‘stone; sky’ a.o. Baltic shows centum reflex of the palatal *ḱ but satǝm reflexes occur in Lv asmens and Lt ašmuõ ‘blade’ which are considered cognates. Also a surname, probably refers to someone who lives in a rocky place, cf. Lt. Akmenė̃lis (LPDB) Po. Kamieniak (ISNP) HG Steinel (DFD). ALEW s.v. akmuõ; Derksen 2015, 47; LEW 5; ME 1, 64; SEJL 12
dialectal or partly standardized variant of akmȩnãjs 'stony; stony area,' ājs-derivation to akmens 'stone, rock,' cf. Lt. akmenójus 'stony area' (and neol. akmenójis 'mineral'). ME 1, 63.
dialectal, semi-standardized or latgalian variant of akmȩnãjs 'stony; stony area,' ājs-derivation to akmens 'stone, rock,' cf. Lt. akmenójus 'stony area' (and neol. akmenójis 'mineral'). ME 1, 63.
nom.pl. of pers. name Alberts 'Albert.' Borrowed from HG Albert < Adalbert 'noble-illustrious,' compound of OHG adal 'noble' and beraht 'bright, illustrious.' LPV 47.

nom.pl. of àldiņš, dim. to alds 'windbag,' cf. also Lt. aldas~aldà 'noise, shriek.' Borrowed from Ru. dial. holda 'shout, cry.' Also a surname, cf. Lt. Čiáuška (LPDB) Po. Gadula (ISNP). LEW 6 sub áldra; LLV 1, 19; ME 1, 66; SEJL 16 sub al̃doti.
_alternative etymology: nom.pl. of aldinis (personal name) which might nonetheless belong to the same root (LPV 48).

_etymology: dialectal for aldiņi, nom.pl. of àldiņš, dim. to alds 'windbag,' cf. also Lt. aldas~aldà 'noise, shriek.' Borrowed from Ru. dial. holda 'shout, cry.' Probably a surname, cf. alding (Plāķis 2, 369) as well as Lt. Čiáuška (LPDB) Po. Gadula (ISNP). LEW 6 sub áldra; LLV 1, 19; ME 1, 66; SEJL 16 sub al̃doti.
_alternative etymology: nom.pl. of aldinis (personal name) which might nonetheless belong to the same root (LPV 48).

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of Aldona or Aldōna (personal name). Ultimately from Gr. εὐδοκία 'goodwill' via BRu. Aŭdónja and Lt. Aldona. LPDB s.v. Aldõnas; LPV 48.
_alternative etymology: to Lt. aldė́ti 'resound' al̃doti 'yell, make noise' (LPDB s.v. Aldõnas; LPV 48)
_category: foreign names (greek and latin); foreign names (slavic)

_etymology: nom.-acc.sg.neut. of Aleksándrov 'Alexander's,' ov-derivation to Aleksándr (personal name) in the sense 'Alexander's place.' Borrowed from Gr. ἀλέξανδρος 'defending men,' compound of ἀλέξω 'defend' and ἀνήρ 'man.' LPV 49 s.v. Aleksandrs.
_category: foreign names (aramaic and hebrew); foreign names (slavic)

_etymology: Borrowed from Ru. Aleksándrovo (top.)' with transfer to ā-stems. Ru. Aleksándrovo is the nom.-acc.sg.neut. of Aleksándrov 'Alexander's,' ov-derivation to Aleksándr (personal name) in the sense 'Alexander's place.' Borrowed from Gr. ἀλέξανδρος 'defending men,' compound of ἀλέξω 'defend' and ἀνήρ 'man.' LPV 49 s.v. Aleksandrs.
_category: foreign names (aramaic and hebrew); foreign names (slavic)

_etymology: nom.pl. of Aleksejevs, borrowed from Ru. Alekséev (surname), an ev-derivation to Alekséj (personal name). Ru. Alekséj is borrowed from Gr. Ἀλέξιος, to ἀλέξω 'defend.' LPV 49 s.v. Aleksejs.
_category: foreign names (aramaic and hebrew); foreign names (slavic)

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of aliņa, dim. to ala 'cave; hole.' Borrowed from MLG hol, cf. also Lt olà~olė̃ OLt hała. LEW 516 sub olà; ME 1, 66; SEJL 832 sub olà.

nom.-acc.pl. of pers. name Alīna 'Alina.' Borrowed from It. Alina or Fr. Aline, perhaps via HG Alina, contraction of Adelina~Adeline. Ultimately from OHG *Adalind 'noble-mild' vel sim., compound of adal 'noble' and lind 'mild.' Pavić Pintarić 2017, 24 w. ref.
_alternative etymology: From It. Alina, contraction of Adelina, ina-diminutive to Adela, contraction of Adelaida, borrowed from OHG Adalheit 'nobility, nobleness,' compound of adal 'noble' and heit 'manner' (LPV 50); borrowed from Ru. Alína of similar origin or hypocoristic for Albina.

_etymology: nom.pl. of alkšņâre 'alder field' (n error for ņ), compound of alksnis 'alder' and âre, variant of âra 'the open; field; outside.' Possibly a surname referring to someone who lives in an alder field, cf. HG Erlenkamp (DFD). AK.
_alternative etymology: compound of alksne, dial. for alksna 'marshy area' and âre.

_etymology: nom.pl. of àlksnis 'alder,' cf. Lt. al̃ksnis alìksnis el̃ksnis a.o. Lv. dial. èlksnis and further Ru. ol'xá dial. ëlxa Lat. alnus OHG elira ON ǫlr a.o. Unclear whether we are dealing with an inherited lexeme or a (substrate?) loanword. In any case the Baltic forms probably show k-epenthesis and perhaps also syncope of the i and transfer to the ii̯o-stems from the o-stems. If so, then we might reconstruct *alisnos~*elisnos which brings the Baltic forms closer to the Latin. Also a surname, probably referring to someone who lives near a prominent alder tree, cf. Lt. Al̃ksnis (LPDB) Po. Olcha (ISNP) HG Erle (DFD). ALEW s.v. alìksnis; Derksen 2015, 50; LEW 8 s.v. al̃ksnis; ME 1, 68; SEJL 18 s.v. al̃ksnis.
_alternative etymology: nom.pl. of alksnis 'stonefish' of unknown origin (ME 1, 68).

_etymology: nom.pl. of àlksnis 'alder,' cf. Lt. al̃ksnis alìksnis el̃ksnis a.o. Lv. dial. èlksnis and further Ru. ol'xá dial. ëlxa Lat. alnus OHG elira ON ǫlr a.o. Unclear whether we are dealing with an inherited lexeme or a (substrate?) loanword. In any case the Baltic forms probably show k-epenthesis and perhaps also syncope of the i and transfer to the ii̯o-stems from the o-stems. If so, then we might reconstruct *alisnos~*elisnos which brings the Baltic forms closer to the Latin. Also a surname, probably referring to someone who lives near a prominent alder tree, cf. Lt. Al̃ksnis (LPDB) Po. Olcha (ISNP) HG Erle (DFD). ALEW s.v. alìksnis; Derksen 2015, 50; LEW 8 s.v. al̃ksnis; ME 1, 68; SEJL 18 s.v. al̃ksnis.
_alternative etymology: nom.pl. of alksnis 'stonefish' of unknown origin (ME 1, 68).

_etymology: nom.pl. of àlksnis 'alder,' cf. Lt. al̃ksnis alìksnis el̃ksnis a.o. Lv. dial. èlksnis and further Ru. ol'xá dial. ëlxa Lat. alnus OHG elira ON ǫlr a.o. Unclear whether we are dealing with an inherited lexeme or a (substrate?) loanword. In any case the Baltic forms probably show k-epenthesis and perhaps also syncope of the i and transfer to the ii̯o-stems from the o-stems. If so, then we might reconstruct *alisnos~*elisnos which brings the Baltic forms closer to the Latin. Also a surname, probably referring to someone who lives near a prominent alder tree, cf. Lt. Al̃ksnis (LPDB) Po. Olcha (ISNP) HG Erle (DFD). ALEW s.v. alìksnis; Derksen 2015, 50; LEW 8 s.v. al̃ksnis; ME 1, 68; SEJL 18 s.v. al̃ksnis.
_alternative etymology: nom.pl. of alksnis 'stonefish' of unknown origin (ME 1, 68).

_etymology: nom.pl. of al̂nis 'deer; elk,' cf. Lt. élnis dial. álnis OLt. elenis. Ultimately from PIE *h1el-h1en- or *h1el-en- vel sim., cf. OCS jelenь Gr ἐλλός 'fawn' ἔλαφος 'deer' Arm. ełn 'hind' We. elain 'hind' OIr. elit 'roe deer.' The second e in OLt. elenis is probably epenthetic as we would expect Lv **al̃nis with sustained tone if from *alenīs, cf. vȩl̃ns 'devil' < *velinas. The Baltic root is thus acute and points to a preform *h1el-Hn-ii̯o- vel sim. If transferred to the ii̯o-stems within Baltic, then theoretically identical to Gr. ἔνελος 'fawn' < *h1el-h1n-o- with metathesis. Also a surname, perhaps in the sense '(deer) hunter' or figuratively 'agile, curious,' cf. Po. Jeleń Łos (ISNP) HG Hirsch (DFD). ALEW s.v. élnis; Derksen 2015, 152 s.v. elenis; 2015, 153 s.v. elnė; LEW 120 s.v. élnis; ME 1, 68; SEJL 273 s.v. élnis.
nom.pl. of aļ̂ņukal̂ns 'deer mountain,' compound of al̂nis 'deer; elk' and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' Possibly a surname, cf. HG Hirschberg (DFD). AK.
nom.pl. of surname Alps 'Alf.' Borrowed from HG Alf < OHG adalfuns 'noble-ready,' compound of adal 'noble' and funs 'ready, willing,' cf. also Lt. Al̃pas. LPDB s.v. Al̃pas.
_alternative etymology: HG Alf < OHG alfuns 'all-ready,' compound of al 'all' and funs 'ready, willing;' surname, borrowed from Turk. Alp 'hero; brave' (DFD); surname, contraction of Albert (DFD s.v. Alp); surname, to OHG alp 'hobgoblin' (DFD); surname, borrowed from HG Alf < OHG Adalwulf (DFD); borrowed from HG pl. tant. Alpen 'Alps' (LVV 1, 22 s.v. al̃pȩ̄ni); to Lt. alpùs 'sultry' (LVV 1, 22 s.v. al̃pȩ̄ni); to OPr pers. name Alp(as) (LVV 1, 22 s.v. al̃pȩ̄ni); to alpa 'while; breath' (ME 1, 68)

_etymology: nom.sg. alšankas pusmuiža. | Syntagm of gen.sg. of TN alšanka and pusmuĩža 'farm-estate.' Primary element is alšanka which is borrowed from Ru. ol'šánka 'robin (erithacus rubecula); (dial.) amur bitterling (rhodeus sericeus),' janka-derivation to ol'xá 'alder.' Common as HN and TN in Russia, Belarus, Ukraine and Poland and probably borrowed as such. | AK.

nom.pl. of lîdaks, dial. for lîdaka 'pike (esox lucius).' Cognate with Lt. lydekà dial. lydèks and further related to Lt. dial. lydỹs OPr. liede lyda 'id.' Forms with k-suffix must be secondary to the simpler k-less forms. Also a surname, probably in the sense 'fisher,' cf. Lt. Lydekà Lydỹs (LPDB) Po. Szczupak (ISNP) HG Hecht (DFD). ALEW s.v. lydekà; LEW 364 s.v. lydekà; ME 2, 477; PKEŽ 3, 57 s.v. liede; SEJL 655 s.v. lydekà.

dial. for ritȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of ritȩ̄ns 'wheelwright,' ȩ̄ns-derivation to rit- 'roll, spin' or to ritenis 'wheel' with haplology or expected **ritȩnȩ̄ns. For the derivation, cf. nom.pl. tìerdzâni 'merchants' < *tìergs vel sim. 'market' from nearby Susēja369 (Āboliņa 1926, 140) as well as Ritenieks (surname). Also a surname, cf. Lt. Rãčius Rãtininkas (LPDB). LVV R, 275 s.v. Rite.
_alternative etymology: dialectal for ritenis 'wheel,' cf. Lv. dial. ritiņš (ME 3, 532 s.v. ritenis).

_etymology: dial. for ritȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of ritȩ̄ns 'wheelwright,' ȩ̄ns-derivation to rit- 'roll, spin' or to ritenis 'wheel' with haplology or expected **ritȩnȩ̄ns. For the derivation, cf. nom.pl. tìerdzâni 'merchants' < *tìergs vel sim. 'market' from nearby Susēja369 (Āboliņa 1926, 140) as well as Ritenieks (surname). Also a surname, cf. Lt. Rãčius Rãtininkas (LPDB). LVV R, 275 s.v. Rite.
_alternative etymology: dialectal for ritenis 'wheel,' cf. Lv. dial. ritiņš (ME 3, 532 s.v. ritenis).

_etymology: alstiķe 'Halswig's (place).' | ē-derivation to alstiķis 'Halswig' which is borrowed from HG FN Halswig. Compound of OHG hals 'neck, throat' and wīg 'battle.' | LVV 1, 23. FBR 12, 133.
nom.pl. of alstiķis 'Halswig.' Probably a FN, cf. HG Halswig. | Borrowed from HG FN Halswig, compound of OHG hals 'neck, throat' and wīg 'battle.' | LVV 1, 23; FBR 12, 133.
Halswigshof 'Halswig estate.' Compound of FN Halswig and Hof 'estate.' | FN Halswig is a compound of OHG hals 'neck, throat' and wīg 'battle.' | AK.

FN Altene 'Altena' (LUV), cf. Du. Altena (Klaversma 1978). | Borrowed from MLG Altena with reinterpretation of word-final -ena as suffix -ene. The MLG is a Latinate form of Holtena, compound of holten 'wooden' and -a 'stream, floodplain,' cf. TN Holtena (RKB) = Altena (where?). | LVV 1, 24.
_alternative etymology: ē-derivation of HG *Altena (surname) in the sense 'Altena place;' HG Altena borrowed from MLG oldena, compound of olden- 'old' and -a 'floodplain;' borrowed from MLG altō nā 'far too close' (looks like a folk etymology; Niemeyer 2012, 27 s.v. Altena)

_etymology: FN Altene 'Altena' (LUV), cf. Du. Altena (Klaversma 1978). | Borrowed from MLG Altena with reinterpretation of word-final -ena as suffix -ene. The MLG is a Latinate form of Holtena, compound of holten 'wooden' and -a 'stream, floodplain,' cf. TN Holtena (RKB) = Altena (where?). | LVV 1, 24.
_alternative etymology: ē-derivation of HG *Altena (surname) in the sense 'Altena place;' HG Altena borrowed from MLG oldena, compound of olden- 'old' and -a 'floodplain;' borrowed from MLG altō nā 'far too close' (looks like a folk etymology; Niemeyer 2012, 27 s.v. Altena)

_etymology: altona 'forested floodplain.' Perhaps a FN, cf. Lv. Altena Altene Altens a.o. (LUV) Du. Altena (Klaversma 1978). | Borrowed from MLG altena, a Latinate form of Holtena, i.e., compound of holten 'wooden' and -a 'stream, floodplain,' cf. MHG Holtena (RKB) MDu. Holtenaay (Klaversma 1978, 11) Altena (where?). The o in Altona might have arisen in MLG as a reanalysis by folk etymology of Altena as altō nā 'far too close.' | Klaversma 1978, 11; Niemeyer 2012, 27 s.v. Altena.
_alternative etymology: borrowed from MLG oldena, compound of olden- 'old' and -a 'floodplain;' borrowed from MLG altō nā 'far too close' (looks like a folk etymology; Niemeyer 2012, 27 s.v. Altena)

_etymology: nom.pl. of altenis 'inhabitant of Altene.' Perhaps a FN, cf. Lv. Altena Altene Altens a.o. (LUV) Du. Altena (Klaversma 1978). | Derived from altena or altene ← MLG Altena, a Latinate form of Holtena, compound of holten 'wooden' and -a 'stream, floodplain,' cf. TN Holtena (RKB) = Altena (where?). | LVV 1, 24 s.v. altene.
_alternative etymology: HG Altena borrowed from MLG oldena, compound of olden- 'old' and -a 'stream, floodplain.'

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of FN Altena 'Altena' (LUV), cf. also Du. Altena (Klaversma 1978). | Borrowed from HG TN *Altena ← MLG Altena, a Latinate form of Holtena. Compound of holten 'wooden' and -a 'stream, floodplain,' cf. top. Holtena (RKB) = Altena (where?). | LVV 1, 24.
_alternative etymology: HG Altena borrowed from MLG oldena, compound of olden- 'old' and -a 'stream, floodplain.'

_etymology: nom.pl. of altons 'inhabitant of Altona.' Perhaps a FN, cf. Lv. Altena Altene Altens a.o. (LUV) Du. Altena (Klaversma 1978). | Derived from altona ← HG Altona 'forested floodplain.' The HG is itself from MLG Altena, a Latinate form of Holtena, compound of holten 'wooden' and -a 'stream, floodplain,' cf. MHG Holtena (RKB) MDu. Holtenaay (Klaversma 1978, 11) Altena (where?). The o in Altona might have arisen in MLG as a reanalysis by folk etymology of Altena as altō nā 'far too close.' | Klaversma 1978, 11; LVV 1, 24 s.v. altene; Niemeyer 2012, 27 s.v. Altena.
_alternative etymology: HG Altona borrowed from MLG oldena, compound of olden- 'old' and -a 'floodplain;' HG Altona borrowed from MLG altō nā 'far too close' (looks like a folk etymology; Niemeyer 2012, 27 s.v. Altena).

_etymology: dial. or error for alūņi, nom.pl. of alūnis 'alum,' borrowed from MLG alūn, cf. also Lt. alū̃nas. ME 1, 69 s.v. aluôns.
_alternative etymology: borrowed from Po ałun or Lt. alū̃nas (historically a non-Lv. speaking area).

_etymology: nom.pl. of amatiņš, dim. to amats 'trade, profession.' Possibly an old surname in the sense 'workman, craftsman,' cf. Amatnieks (LUV). | Borrowed from MLG ammet, cf. also Lt. ãmatas Est. ammet. Parallel to Lt. amatìnis 'professional' but probably not inherited due to the late date of borrowing. | LEW 9; ME 1, 70; SEJL 23.

dial. for ãmuri, nom.pl. of ãmurs 'hammer.' Borrowed from MLG hamer, cf. also Est hāmer. Also a surname, perhaps in the sense 'smith,' cf. Lt. Plaktùkas (LPDB) Po. Młot (ISNP) HG Hammer (DFD). LVV 1, 66 s.v. ãmars: ME 1, 238 s.v. ãmars.

dial. for nom.pl. of FN Ancȩ̃ns 'Johns.' Exists only as FN, cf. Ancāns Ancēns (LUV) and also Lt. Jõnelis (LPDB) Po. Iwanow (ISNP) HG Hansel Hanses (DFD) Eng. Johns Jones. | ēna-derivation to PN Añcis ← HG Hans which is a short form of Johannes 'John.' Ultimately from BHe. Yōḥānān < YHVH khanún 'God is gracious' via Gr. Ἰωάννης and Lat. Iōhannēs. | LPV 56; LVV 1, 27 s.v. añce; ME 1, 71 s.v. Añcis.
_alternative etymology: HLv. for ancĩši 'agrimony, sticklewort (agrimonia eupatoria)' ultimately of the same origin (ME 1, 71).

_etymology: dial. for ancȩ̃nu rudzīši 'Rudzīši of the Ancēni.' | Syntagm of gen.pl. of FN Ancȩ̃ns 'Johns' (LUV) and nom.pl. of D to rudzis 'rye grain; (pl.) rye; (D, pl.) darnel (lolium temulentum).' | AK.
_category: foreign names (aramaic and hebrew); herbaceous plants; agriculture

_etymology: nom.pl. of FN Ancītis 'Johns' (LUV). | ītii̯o-derivation to PN Añcis ← HG Hans, short form of Johannes 'John.' Ultimately from BHe. Yōḥānān < YHVH khanún 'God is gracious' though borrowed via Gr. Ἰωάννης and Lat. Iōhannēs. Semantically rather 'John's' than a diminutive, cf. Lt. Jõnelis (LPDB) Po. Iwanow (ISNP) HG Hansel Hanses (DFD) Eng. Johns. LPV 56; LVV 1, 27 s.v. añce; ME 1, 71 s.v. Añcis.
_alternative etymology: ancĩši 'agrimony, sticklewort (agrimonia eupatoria)' (ultimately same origin; ME 1, 71).
_category: foreign names (aramaic and hebrew); herbaceous plants; agriculture

_etymology: nom.pl. of FN Ancītis 'Johns' (LUV). | ītii̯o-derivation to PN Añcis ← HG Hans, short form of Johannes 'John.' Ultimately from BHe. Yōḥānān < YHVH khanún 'God is gracious' though borrowed via Gr. Ἰωάννης and Lat. Iōhannēs. Semantically rather 'John's' than a diminutive, cf. Lt. Jõnelis (LPDB) Po. Iwanow (ISNP) HG Hansel Hanses (DFD) Eng. Johns. LPV 56; LVV 1, 27 s.v. añce; ME 1, 71 s.v. Añcis.
_alternative etymology: ancĩši 'agrimony, sticklewort (agrimonia eupatoria)' (ultimately same origin; ME 1, 71).
_category: foreign names (aramaic and hebrew); herbaceous plants; agriculture

_etymology: compound of vȩcs 'old' and pl. tant. Ancīši (top.) Ancīši is the nom.pl. of Ancītis (surname), ītis-derivation to Añcis which is borrowed from HG Hans, a short form of Johannes 'John.' Ultimately from BHe. Yōḥānān < YHVH khanún 'God is gracious' though borrowed via Gr. Ἰωάννης and Lat. Iōhannēs. Semantically rather 'John's' than a diminutive, cf. Lt. Jõnelis (LPDB) Po. Iwanow (ISNP) HG Hansel Hanses (DFD) Eng. Johns. LPV 56; LVV 1, 27 s.v. añce; ME 1, 71 s.v. Añcis.
_alternative etymology: ancĩši 'agrimony, sticklewort (agrimonia eupatoria)' (ultimately same origin; ME 1, 71).
_category: foreign names (aramaic and hebrew); herbaceous plants; agriculture

_etymology: nom.pl. of Andiņš (surname.) iņš-derivation to Andis, short form of Andrejs ← Ru. Andréj (personal name). Ru. Andréj ← Gr. Ἀνδρέᾱς 'manly (vel sim.)' which is derived from ἀνήρ 'man.' Lv. Andiņš semantically rather 'Andrew's' than a diminutive, cf. Lt. Andrejáitis (LPDB) Po. Andrzejak (ISNP) HG Andreasen (DFD) Eng. Andrews. LPV 55.
_alternative etymology: Lv. Andrejs borrowed from Po. Andrzej or BRu. Andréj; to añduļi (LVV 1, 28 s.v. àndeņi2).

_etymology: nom.pl. of pers. name Andrejs 'Andrew.' Borrowed from Ru. or BRu. andréj or Po. Andrzej ← Gr. Ἀνδρέᾱς 'manly (vel sim.),' derived from ἀνήρ 'man.' LPV 56; LVV 1, 28 s.v. mazañdris.

partly standardized variant of Añdrȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of surname Añdrȩ̄ns 'Andrews.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to Andris, short form of pers. name Andrejs 'Andrew' ← Ru. or BRu. Andréj or Po. Andrzej. Ultimately from Gr. Ἀνδρέᾱς 'manly (vel sim.),' derived from ἀνήρ 'man.' Cf. also Lt. Andrejáitis (LPDB) Po. Andrzejak (ISNP) HG Andreasen (DFD) Eng. Andrews. LPV 57; LVV 1, 29 s.v. mazañdris.

dial. for Añdrȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of surname Añdrȩ̄ns 'Andrews.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to Andris, short form of pers. name Andrejs 'Andrew' ← Ru. or BRu. Andréj or Po. Andrzej. Ultimately from Gr. Ἀνδρέᾱς 'manly (vel sim.),' derived from ἀνήρ 'man.' Cf. also Lt. Andrejáitis (LPDB) Po. Andrzejak (ISNP) HG Andreasen (DFD) Eng. Andrews. LPV 57; LVV 1, 29 s.v. mazañdris.

= andrāni (lack of vowel length is common in AŠĢTD), dial. for añdrȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of añdrȩ̄ns 'member of Andrew's household.' Exists only as surname (LUV), cf. also Lt. Andrejáitis (LPDB) Po. Andrzejak (ISNP) HG Andreasen (DFD) Eng. Andrews. | ȩ̄ns-derivation to pers. name Andris, short form of Andrejs 'Andrew' ← Ru. or BRu. Andréj or Po. Andrzej. Ultimately from Gr. Ἀνδρέᾱς 'manly (vel sim.),' derived from ἀνήρ 'man.' | LPV 57; LVV 1, 29 s.v. mazañdris.

dial. for Añdžȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of surname Añdžȩ̄ns 'Andrews.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to Añdža, short form of pers. name Andrejs 'Andrew' ← Ru. or BRu. Andréj or Po. Andrzej. Ultimately from Gr. Ἀνδρέᾱς 'manly (vel sim.),' derived from ἀνήρ 'man.' Cf. also Lt. Andrejáitis (LPDB) Po. Andrzejak (ISNP) HG Andreasen (DFD) Eng. Andrews. LPV 57 s.v. andža; LVV 1, 30 s.v. añdžas.

nom.-acc.pl. of anemone 'anemone; (dial.) pulsatilla.' Borrowed from Gr. ἀνεμώνη via Lat. anemōnē and perhaps HG Anemone. Gr. ἀνεμώνη either derived from ἄνεμος 'wind' or itself borrowed from Phoenician, cf. Ar. pl. šaqāʔiqu n-nuʕmān 'anemones.'
nom.-acc.pl. of pers. name Anfisa. Borrowed from Ru. Anfísa ← Gr. Ἀνθοῦσα 'flowery, blooming; flower nymph,' a derivation to ἄνθος 'flower.' LPV 58.
nom.-acc.pl. of ankaršmite 'anchor smithy,' ē-derivation to *ankaršmits ← HG Ankerschmidt 'anchor smith.' ankar- for anker- due to vowel harmony, cf. āmars ← MLG hamer 'hammer.' LVV 1, 31.
_alternative etymology: *ankaršmits borrowed from MLG ankersmit with š for s due to influence from HG.

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of ankeršmite 'anchor smithy,' ē-derivation to *ankeršmits ← HG Ankerschmidt 'anchor smith.' LVV 1, 31.
_alternative etymology: *ankeršmits borrowed from MLG ankersmit with š for s due to influence from HG.

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of PN Anna 'Ann.' Borrowed from BHe. ḥannâ 'grace, gracious' via Gr. Ἀννα, Lat. Anna and perhaps HG Anna or Ru. Ánna. LPV 60; LVV 1, 31.
nom.-acc.pl. of PN Annuška 'Annie.' | ← Ru. or BRu. Ánnuška, hypocorism for Ánna 'Ann' ← BHe. ḥannâ 'grace, gracious' via Gr. Ἀννα. | LPV 60; LVV 1, 31 s.v. annas-darījums.

dial. for Añtȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of surname Añtȩ̄ns 'Anthonies.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to Añtis, hypocorism of Añtõns ← Lat. Antōnius 'Anthony' via HG Anton or Ru. Antón. Origin unclear. Cf. also Lt. Antanė́nas (LPDB) Po. Antoniak (ISNP) HG Antons (DFD) Eng. Anthonies. LPV 62 s.v. Antis; LVV 1, 33 s.v. anta-dīķis.

misspelling for Antāni, dial. for Añtȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of surname Añtȩ̄ns 'Anthonies.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to Añtis, hypocorism of Añtõns ← Lat. Antōnius 'Anthony' via HG Anton or Ru. Antón. Origin unclear. Cf. also Lt. Antanė́nas (LPDB) Po. Antoniak (ISNP) HG Antons (DFD) Eng. Anthonies. LPV 62 s.v. Antis; LVV 1, 33 s.v. anta-dīķis.

compound of jaûns 'new' and top. Antāni. Antāni is dial. for Añtȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of surname Añtȩ̄ns 'Anthonies.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to Añtis, hypocorism of Añtõns ← Lat. Antōnius 'Anthony' via HG Anton or Ru. Antón. Origin unclear. Cf. also Lt. Antanė́nas (LPDB) Po. Antoniak (ISNP) HG Antons (DFD) Eng. Anthonies. LPV 62 s.v. Antis; LVV 1, 33 s.v. anta-dīķis.

syntagm of top. Antāni and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' Antāni is dial. for Añtȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of surname Añtȩ̄ns 'Anthonies.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to Añtis, hypocorism of Añtõns ← Lat. Antōnius 'Anthony' via HG Anton or Ru. Antón. Origin unclear. Cf. also Lt. Antanė́nas (LPDB) Po. Antoniak (ISNP) HG Antons (DFD) Eng. Anthonies. LPV 62 s.v. Antis; LVV 1, 33 s.v. anta-dīķis.

compound of top. Antāni and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' Antāni is dial. for Añtȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of surname Añtȩ̄ns 'Anthonies.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to Añtis, hypocorism of Añtõns ← Lat. Antōnius 'Anthony' via HG Anton or Ru. Antón. Origin unclear. Cf. also Lt. Antanė́nas (LPDB) Po. Antoniak (ISNP) HG Antons (DFD) Eng. Anthonies. LPV 62 s.v. Antis; LVV 1, 33 s.v. anta-dīķis.

dial. for Aparȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of surname Aparȩ̄ns 'balk dweller.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to apars 'balk (unploughed area); worn-out field,' itself to apar̂t 'plough around.' Parallel to Lt. apara 'ploughed field' to apárti 'plough' (perfective sense). Semantically comparable to LLv. aparnieks 'balk dweller.' Cf. also Lt. Ribáitis (LPDB) HG Rainer (DFD). LVV 1, 36 s.v. apara; ME 1, 75 s.v. apars.

nom.pl. of aparniẽks 'balk dweller.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Ribáitis (LPDB) HG Rainer (DFD). | niẽkas-derivation to apars 'balk (unploughed area used as boundary mark); worn-out field.' To apar̂t 'plough around,' cf. also Lt. apara 'ploughed field' to apárti 'plough.' | LVV 1, 36 s.v. apara; ME 1, 75 s.v. apars.

nom.pl. of aparniẽks 'balk dweller.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Ribáitis (LPDB) HG Rainer (DFD). | niẽkas-derivation to apars 'balk (unploughed area used as boundary mark); worn-out field.' To apar̂t 'plough around,' cf. also Lt. apara 'ploughed field' to apárti 'plough.' | LVV 1, 36 s.v. apara; ME 1, 75 s.v. apars.

nom.pl. of apinãjs 'hopfield; (pl.) hopbines.' Cognate with Lt. apynójas 'hopbine.' ājs-derivation to Lv. apîņi Lt. apyniaĩ 'hops.' Most conservative Lv. variant is apīnãjs with long ī while apinãjs and apenãjs have been reanalysed as if containing suffix -in- or -en-. LVV 1, 37 s.v. ape; ME 1, 90; SEJL 35 s.v. apyniaĩ.

nom.pl. of apinis '(usually pl.) hops.' Also a FN (LUV) in which case MN for 'hops farmer,' cf. Lt. Ap(v)ynỹs (LPDB) Po. Chmiel (ISNP) HG Hopf (DFD). | V of apvīnis which is cognate with Lt. ap(v)yniaĩ and further related to apvît 'wind.' For the loss of v cf. Lv. apaļš < *apvaļš 'round.' | Karulis 2001, 71 s.v. apīņi; LEW 13 s.v. ap(v)yniaĩ; ME 1, 90; SEJL 35 s.v. apyniaĩ.

nom.pl. of apînis '(usually pl.) hops.' Also a FN (LUV) in which case MN for 'hops farmer,' cf. Lt. Ap(v)ynỹs (LPDB) Po. Chmiel (ISNP) HG Hopf (DFD). | V of apvīnis which is cognate with Lt. ap(v)yniaĩ and further related to apvît 'wind.' For the loss of v cf. nom.pl. of apluociņš, dim. to aplùoks 'bend, circle; hat brim; pen, corral.' Also a surname in which case semantically 'corral keeper' or perhaps 'bend dweller.' LVV 1, 38 s.v. apluoks; ME 1, 103 s.v. aplùoks; SEJL 37 s.v. aplúokas.

nom.pl. of apluociņš, dim. to aplùoks 'bend, circle; hat brim; pen, corral.' Also a surname in which case semantically 'corral keeper' or perhaps 'bend dweller.' LVV 1, 38 s.v. apluoks; ME 1, 103 s.v. aplùoks; SEJL 37 s.v. aplúokas.

ščina-derivation to surname Apolinov in the sense 'Apolinov's land,' cf. Ukr. Bojko (surname) > Bojkivščyna 'Boyko's land.' Apolinov is a variant of Apolonov 'Apollo's,' ov-derivation to Apol(l)ón ← Gr. Ἀπόλλων 'Apollo' which is of unclear origin. Source language might also be Lv. in which case the toponym is borrowed from Ru. AK.

Borrowed from Ru. Apolinovščina, ščina-derivation to surname Apolinov in the sense 'Apolinov's land,' cf. Ukr. Bojko (surname) > Bojkivščyna 'Boyko's land.' Ru. Apolinov is a variant of Apolonov 'Apollo's,' ov-derivation to Apol(l)ón ← Gr. Ἀπόλλων 'Apollo' which is of unclear origin. Source language is not likely to be Russian in view of the source in LĢIA. AK.

dial. for Aparȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of surname Aparȩ̄ns 'balk dweller.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to apars 'balk (unploughed area); worn-out field,' itself to apar̂t 'plough around.' Parallel to Lt. apara 'ploughed field' to apárti 'plough' (perfective sense). Semantically comparable to LLv. aparnieks 'balk dweller.' Cf. also Lt. Ribáitis (LPDB) HG Rainer (DFD). LVV 1, 38; ME 1, 75 s.v. apars.

dial. for Aparȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of surname Aparȩ̄ns 'balk dweller.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to apars 'balk (unploughed area); worn-out field,' itself to apar̂t 'plough around.' Parallel to Lt. apara 'ploughed field' to apárti 'plough' (perfective sense). Semantically comparable to LLv. aparnieks 'balk dweller.' Cf. also Lt. Ribáitis (LPDB) HG Rainer (DFD). LVV 1, 38; ME 1, 75 s.v. apars.

dial. for Aparȩ̄ni (vowel length regularly absent in AŠĢTD), nom.pl. of surname Aparȩ̄ns 'balk dweller.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to apars 'balk (unploughed area); worn-out field,' itself to apar̂t 'plough around.' Parallel to Lt. apara 'ploughed field' to apárti 'plough' (perfective sense). Semantically comparable to LLv. aparnieks 'balk dweller.' Cf. also Lt. Ribáitis (LPDB) HG Rainer (DFD). LVV 1, 38; ME 1, 75 s.v. apars.

nom.-acc.pl. of āpse 'badger place' vel sim. Also a FN (LUV), cf. Po. Borsuk Jaźwiec (ISNP) HG Dachs (DFD). | ē-derivation to âpsis < *āpsris 'badger' which is cognate with Lt. opšrỹs~opšrùs and OPr. wobsdus. | ALEW s.v. opšrùs; LEW 517 s.v. opšrỹs; ME 1, 239; SEJL 833 s.v. opšrùs.
_alternative etymology: dial. for âpsis, cf. âpša (ME 1, 239); error for apses, nom.-acc.pl. of apse 'aspen.'

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of apse 'aspen.' Cognates are distributed across Northern Europe, cf. Lt. apušė OPr. abse Po. osa Ru. osína SCr. jàsika OHG aspa ON ǫsp a.o. The alternation *-us- : *-s- might suggest root *ap- + suffix *-us- or *-s-; or we might be dealing with suffix -ušė and dissimilatory loss of s in Lt., i.e., *aps-ušė > apušė; or the Lt. u might be otherwise secondary. Metathesis in either Germanic or Balto-Slavic is presupposed. Also a surname, probably referring to smn who lives near a prominent aspen tree, cf. Po. Osika (ISNP). ALEW s.v. ãpušė; Kroonen 2013, 39; LEW 14 s.v. ãpušė; LVV 1, 38 s.v. apsa; ME 1, 118; SEJL 38 s.v. ãpušė.
nom.-acc.pl. of âpšiņa 'sett.' | substantivized feminine form of a lost associative adjective to âpša, V of âpsis 'badger.,' cf. Lt. opšrìnis 'badger-.' | ME 1, 239 s.v. âpšene.
Latg. for nom.-acc.pl. of âpšine 'sett.' | inē-derivation to âpša, V of âpsis 'badger.' Originally the feminine of an associative adjective, cf. Lt. opšrìnis 'badger-.' | ME 1, 239 s.v. âpšene.
dial. for nom.-acc.pl. of âpšine 'sett.' | inē-derivation to âpša, V of âpsis 'badger.' Originally the feminine of an associative adjective, cf. Lt. opšrìnis 'badger-.' | ME 1, 239 s.v. âpšene.

nom.-acc.pl. of apsīte, dim. to apse 'aspen.' Cognates are distributed across Northern Europe, cf. Lt. apušė OPr. abse Po. osa Ru. osína SCr. jàsika OHG aspa ON ǫsp a.o. The alternation *-us- : *-s- might suggest root *ap- + suffix *-us- or *-s-; or we might be dealing with suffix -ušė and dissimilatory loss of s in Lt., i.e., *aps-ušė > apušė; or the Lt. u might be otherwise secondary. Metathesis in either Germanic or Balto-Slavic is presupposed. Also a surname, probably referring to smn who lives near a prominent aspen tree, cf. Lt. Apušìnskas (LPDB) Po. Osikowicz (ISNP). ALEW s.v. ãpušė; Kroonen 2013, 39; LEW 14 s.v. ãpušė; LVV 1, 38 s.v. apsa; ME 1, 118; SEJL 38 s.v. ãpušė.

nom.-acc.pl. of aptȩka 'flow-around.' Verbal noun to aptecêt 'flow around; get splashed with sth.' Cf. also Lt. aptakà 'river outflow.' LVV 1, 41 s.v. aptaciškas.

nom.pl. of apuôgs 'tawny owl; boreal owl.' Cognate with Lt. apúokas 'eagle owl.' Alternation k~g might be due to onomatopoeic origin or reanalysis of Lv. nom.sg. [apuôks] as /apuôgs/ rather than /apuôks/. Also a surname, cf. Lt. Apúokas (LPDB) Po. Puszcz (ISNP). ALEW s.v. apúokas; LEW 14 s.v. apúokas; LVV 1, 41; ME 1, 133; SEJL 38 s.v. apúokas.

dial. for Arhipišķi, nom.pl. of Arhipišķis 'of Arhip,' išķis-derivation to pers. name Arhips ← Ru. Arhíp, itself borrowed from Gr. Ἀρχιππος 'leading horses,' compound of ἄρχε- 'leading' and ἴππος 'horse.' Probably an old surname, cf. Lt. Archipovas (LPDB) Ru. Arhípov. LPV 66.

_etymology: Borrowed from Ru. oréxovka or BRu. aréxaŭka 'nutcracker (nucifraga caryocatactes).' Common as a toponym in East Latvia and Russia and probably borrowed as such. AK.

nom.-acc.pl. of âre 'the open; field; outside.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Laukas (LPDB) Po. Niwa (ISNP) HG Feld (DFD). | Cognate with Lt. orė̃ 'ploughing; ploughed field.' Thus originally VN in the sense 'ploughing' to *arˀ- 'plough,' cf. mõlė~molė̃ ‘grinding’ to málti ‘grind’ (Skardžius 1943, 71). The mobile V is semelfactive and may have acquired the meaning 'ploughed field' although contamination with Lv. ârs~âra 'the open; field; outside' (Lt. óras 'air; weather') must be assumed, too, due to the other meanings of âre. | ALEW s.v. óras; Derksen 2015, 340 s.v. oras; LEW 518 s.v. óras; LVV 1, 69 s.v. ârabirži; ME 1, 239 s.v. âra; SEJL 834 s.v. orė̃.

Thus originally VN in the sense 'ploughing' to *arˀ- 'plough,' cf. mõlė~molė̃ ‘grinding’ to málti ‘grind’ (Skardžius 1943, 71). The mobile V is semelfactive and may have acquired the meaning 'ploughed field' although contamination with Lv. ârs~âra 'the open; field; outside' (Lt. óras 'air; weather') must be assumed, too, due to the other meanings of âre. | ALEW s.v. óras; Derksen 2015, 340 s.v. oras; LEW 518 s.v. óras; LVV 1, 69 s.v. ârabirži; ME 1, 239 s.v. âra; SEJL 834 s.v. orė̃.
nom.pl. of ârgalis 'dandy, excentric.' ii̯o-derivation to ârgals 'outer end,' compound of ârs~âra 'the open; field; outside' and gals 'end.' Also a surname. ME 1, 243 s.v. ârgalis and ârgals.
nom.-acc.pl. of pers. name Arianda ← Ru. or BRu. Ariánda, variant of Ariádna ← Gr. Ἀριάδνη of Pre-Greek origin. Beekes 2010, 130; LPV 66.

nom.-acc.pl. of âriņa. Diminutive to âra 'the open; field; outside,' variant of ârs 'id.,' cf. Lt. óras 'air; weather.' Vṛddhi-derivation to *arˀ- 'plough' originally meaning '(cultivated) field.' Also a surname in which case the sense is 'field-dweller' or perhaps 'farmer,' cf. Po. Polak (ISNP) HG Felder (DFD). ALEW s.v. óras; Derksen 2015, 340 s.v. oras; LEW 518 s.v. óras; LVV 1, 69 s.v. ârabirži; ME 1, 239; SEJL 833 s.v. óras.

nom.-acc.pl. of ârĩte, diminutive to âre 'the open; field; outside.' Probably cognate with Lt. orė̃ 'ploughing; ploughed field' and thus originally a verbal noun in the sense 'ploughing' to *arˀ- 'plough,' cf. mõlė~molė̃ ‘grinding’ to málti ‘grind’ (Skardžius 1943, 71). The mobile variant is semelfactive and may have acquired the meaning 'ploughed field' although contamination with Lv. ârs~âra 'the open; field; outside' (Lt. óras 'air; weather') must be assumed, too, due to the other meanings of âre. Also a surname, probably referring to smn who lives on a field or perhaps in the sense 'farmer,' cf. Po. Niwa (ISNP) HG Feld (DFD). ALEW s.v. óras; Derksen 2015, 340 s.v. oras; LEW 518 s.v. óras; LVV 1, 69 s.v. ârabirži; ME 1, 239 s.v. âra; SEJL 834 s.v. orė̃.

somehow to Fi. aarni 'treasure; giant; giant tree.' Perhaps error for Ārņi, nom.pl. surname Ārnis, cf. Est. Aarna Fi. Aarni Aarnio a.o. LVV 1, 70 s.v. ārnas-ȩzȩrs.

borrowed from Lv. dial. Áorìši vel sim. as a toponym. Áorìši is dial. for Ârĩši, nom.pl. of ârĩtis, an ītis-derivation to âre 'the open; field; outside' which is probably cognate with Lt. orė̃ 'ploughing; ploughed field' and thus originally a verbal noun in the sense 'ploughing' to *arˀ- 'plough,' cf. mõlė~molė̃ 'grinding' to málti 'grind' (Skardžius 1943, 71). The mobile variant is semelfactive and may have acquired the meaning 'ploughed field' although contamination with Lv. ârs~âra 'the open; field; outside' (Lt. óras 'air; weather') must be assumed, too, due to the other meanings of âre. ALEW s.v. óras; Derksen 2015, 340 s.v. oras; LEW 518 s.v. óras; LVV 1, 68 s.v. ârabirži; ME 1, 239 s.v. âra; SEJL 834 s.v. orė̃. AK.

nom.-acc.pl. of pers. name Arkādija ← Ru. Arkádija, itself borrowed from Gr. Ἀρκαδίᾱ 'Arcadia' or ἀρκαδιᾱ, nom.sg.fem. of ἀρκάδιος 'Arcadian' or Motionsfemininum to Ru. Arkádij ← Gr. ἀρκάδιος. Gr. ἀρκάδιος is an ii̯o-derivation to Ἀρκάς (myth. fig.) of unclear origin—a connection to ἄρκτος 'bear' is dubious and could be a folk etymology. Blažek 2017, 161–162; Chantraine 1960–1980, 110 s.v. ἄρκτος; GEW 1, 142 s.v. ἄρκτος; LPV 67 s.v. Arkādijs.

dial. for or partly standardized variant of arkliņa purvs, syntagm of gen.sg. of arkliņš and purvs 'swamp.' Arkliņš is a dim. to arkls 'plough.' Inherited from PIE, cf. Lt. árklas OCS ralo Go. ardrs OIr. arathar Lat. arātrum Gr. ἄροτρον a.o. Also a surname, probably in the sense 'peasant' or 'ploughsmith,' cf. Po. Sochacki (ISNP) HG Pflügel (DFD). ALEW s.v. árklas; Derksen 2015, 60 s.v. arklas; LEW 17 s.v. árti; LVV 1, 42 s.v. lielais arkla purvs; ME 1, 141; SEJL 42 s.v. árklas.

Also a surname, probably in the sense 'peasant' or 'ploughsmith,' cf. Po. Sochacki (ISNP) HG Pflügel (DFD). ?' | LVV compares nom.pl. ārlupi with nom.-acc.pl. ā̀rles2 as if a compound of ārl- '?' and nom.pl. upji, compositional variant of upe 'stream, river.' | LVV 1, 70 s.v. ā̀rles2.

Ārlupi-upon-Daugava.' | Compound of hydr. Dàugava and top. Ārlupi. LVV compares nom.pl. ārlupi with nom.-acc.pl. ā̀rles2 as if a compound of ārl- '?' and nom.pl. upji, compositional variant of upe 'stream, river.' | LVV 1, 70 s.v. ā̀rles2.

Ārlupi-in-the-woods.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of mežs 'forest' and top. Ārlupi. LVV compares nom.pl. ārlupi with nom.-acc.pl. ā̀rles2 as if a compound of ārl- '?' and nom.pl. upji, compositional variant of upe 'stream, river.' | LVV 1, 70 s.v. ā̀rles2.

_source: E 1922, 55; AŠĢTD 49; LVV 1, 70 s.v. ārnas ȩzȩrs
_etymology: nom.pl. of surname Ārnis ← Est. Aarna or Fi. Aarni vel sim. The Balto-Finnic surnames might belong to Fi. aarni 'treasure; giant; giant tree.' LVV 1, 70 s.v. ārnas-ȩzȩrs.

nom.pl. of ârnieks 'stranger, outsider.' Also a surname, cf. Lt. Svetáitis (LPDB) Po. Cudzy (ISNP) HG Fremd (DFD). | nieks-derivation to ârs~âra 'the open; field; outside,' cf. Lt. óras 'air; weather' and oriniñkas 'weather foreteller.' ârs~âra is a vṛddhi-derivation to *arˀ- 'plough' originally meaning '(cultivated) field.' | LVV 1, 69 s.v. ârabirži; ME 1, 242 s.v. ârenieks.
_alternative etymology: reanalysis of ãrnikas, to OPr. pers. name Arnike (LVV 1, 42 s.v. arnika; 1, 70 s.v. ãrnikas and ãrnieki).

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of arōnija 'aronia, chokeberry.' Borrowed from Gr. Ἀρωνία 'medlar' via Lat. aronia and perhaps HG Aronia. AK.
nom.-acc.pl. of arōnija 'aronia, chokeberry.' Borrowed from Gr. Ἀρωνία 'medlar' via Lat. aronia and perhaps HG Aronia. AK.

nom.pl. of aruõds 'compartment in barn; grain crate,' cf. Lt. arúodas 'flour trough, grain crate; pantry.' | Compound of a putative u-stem *aru- 'grain' (usually compared with OPr. acc.sg. arrien 'grain' Lat. arvum 'farmland' Gr. ἄρουρα 'id.') to *arˀ- 'plough' and of *-das, corresponding to PIE *-dhh1-os. OBRu. orudъ BRu. (h)arúd a.o. 'compartment in granary' and HG dial. arrōde 'Fach in einer Schüttung' are borrowed from Baltic. | ALEW s.v. arúodas and -das; LEW 17 s.v. arúodas; LVV 1, 43 s.v. aruodu salas; ME 1, 142; PKEŽ 1, 91–93.
_alternative etymology: borrowed from Slavic in which case we are dealing with a verbal noun *o(b)rǫdъ to *o(b)rǫditi 'enclose, fence in,' cf. Ru. soorudít’ 'build' (SEJL 45 s.v. arúodas).

_etymology: borrowed from Gr. ἄρον 'cuckoopint (arum maculatum)' of unclear origin. Perhaps borrowed via MLG arōn or HG Aron(stab), cf. also Lt. aronas. Beekes 2010, 136; Chantraine 1960–1980, 112; GEW 1, 146.
borrowed from Gr. ἄρον 'cuckoopint (arum maculatum)' of unclear origin. Perhaps borrowed via MLG arōn or HG Aron(stab), cf. also Lt. aronas. Beekes 2010, 136; Chantraine 1960–1980, 112; GEW 1, 146.

syntagm of gen.sg. of top. Aruona and pusmuiža 'farm-estate, folwark,' i.e., 'Arona farm-estate.' Aruona is a variant of aruone 'cuckoopint (arum maculatum)' ← Gr. ἄρον of unclear origin. Perhaps borrowed via MLG arōn or HG Aron(stab), cf. also Lt. aronas. Beekes 2010, 136; Chantraine 1960–1980, 112; GEW 1, 146.

nom.-acc.pl. of aruone 'cuckoopint (arum maculatum).' Borrowed from Gr. ἄρον 'cuckoopint (arum maculatum)' of unclear origin. Perhaps borrowed via MLG arōn or HG Aron(stab), cf. also Lt. aronas. Beekes 2010, 136; Chantraine 1960–1980, 112; GEW 1, 146.

nom.pl. of asaris (or of dial. asars) 'perch (perca fluviatilis),' cf. also Lt. dial. ašerỹs Lv. dial. aseris. ii̯o-derivation to *aśerāˀ 'fishbone,' cf. Po. jesiora. Ultimately to *aś- 'sharp,' cf. OSw. aghborre 'perch' MHG ag 'id.' Also a surname (Asaris as well as Asars), cf. Lt. Ašerỹs (LPDB) Po. Okoń (ISNP) HG Barsch (DFD) Eng. Perch. ALEW s.v. ešerỹs; Derksen 2015, 158 s.v. ešerys; LEW 125 s.v. ešerỹs; LVV 1, 43 s.v. asare; ME 1, 143; SEJL 279 s.v. ešerỹs.

nom.pl. of asariņš, dim. to asaris 'perch (perca fluviatilis),' also Lt. dial. ašerỹs Lv. dial. aseris. ii̯o-derivation to *aśerāˀ 'fishbone,' cf. Po. jesiora. Ultimately to *aś- 'sharp,' cf. OSw. aghborre 'perch' MHG ag 'id.' Also a surname, probably in the sense '(perch) fisher,' cf. Lt. Ašeriškis (LPDB) Po. Okonek (ISNP). ALEW s.v. ešerỹs; Derksen 2015, 158 s.v. ešerys; LEW 125 s.v. ešerỹs; LVV 1, 43 s.v. asare; ME 1, 143; SEJL 279 s.v. ešerỹs.

nom.pl. of asarītis, dim. to asaris 'perch (perca fluviatilis),' also Lt. dial. ašerỹs Lv. dial. aseris. ii̯o-derivation to *aśerāˀ 'fishbone,' cf. Po. jesiora. Ultimately to *aś- 'sharp,' cf. OSw. aghborre 'perch' MHG ag 'id.' Also a surname, probably in the sense '(perch) fisher,' cf. Lt. Ašeriškis (LPDB) Po. Okonek (ISNP). ALEW s.v. ešerỹs; Derksen 2015, 158 s.v. ešerys; LEW 125 s.v. ešerỹs; LVV 1, 43 s.v. asare; ME 1, 143; SEJL 279 s.v. ešerỹs.

nom.pl. of asītis, ītis-derivation to ass 'sharp.' Inherited from PIE, cf. Lt aš(t)ras OCS ostrъ Gr ἄκρος Lat ācer etc. Not a regular diminutive, probably rather a surname in the sense 'sharply, keen,' cf. Po. Ostrysz (ISNP) HG Scharf (DFD) Eng. Sharp. ALEW s.v. ãštras; Derksen 2015, 64 s.v. aštrus; LEW 19 s.v. aštrùs; ME 1, 144; SEJL 49 s.v. aštrùs.
_alternative etymology: ītis-derivarion to ass 'axle;' ītis-derivation to an unattested cognate with Lt. asỹs 'rough horsetail (equisetum hyemale).'

_etymology: nom.pl. of asns 'sprout.' Might be identical with Ru. ósn 'point, spike.' Ultimately to *h2eḱ- 'sharp.' LEW 18 s.v. asnìs; LVV 1, 44 s.v. asna; ME 1, 144; SEJL 48 s.v. ašnìs.
nom.-acc.pl. of astere 'aster.' Borrowed from Lat. astēr 'star,' perhaps via HG Aster. AK.
nom.-acc.pl. of astere 'aster.' Borrowed from Lat. astēr 'star,' perhaps via HG Aster. AK.
nom.-acc.pl. of astere 'aster.' Borrowed from Lat. astēr 'star,' perhaps via HG Aster. AK.
cognate with Lt. ašuotis 'symploca (type of cyanobacteria).' Probably named after nearby stream asote (now dārzupīte). AK.
_alternative etymology: borrowed from Lt. ašuotis 'symploca (type of cyanobacteria);' cognate with (or borrowed from) Lt. ašuõtis 'hair of horse’s tail or mane;' cognate with (or borrowed from) Lt. ašuõtė 'feather grass (stipa).'

_etymology: syntagm of gen.sg. of top. Asuote and nom.pl. of kaps 'grave; (pl.) cemetery,' i.e., 'Asuote cemetery.' Asuote might be cognate with Lt. ašuotis 'symploca (type of cyanobacteria).' AK.
_alternative etymology: asuote borrowed from Lt. ašuotis 'symploca (type of cyanobacteria);' asuote cognate with (or borrowed from) Lt. ašuõtis 'hair of horse’s tail or mane;' asuote cognate with (or borrowed from) Lt. ašuõtė 'feather grass (stipa).'

_etymology: Asote castle mound' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of top. Asuote and pilskalns 'castle mound,' itself a compound of pils 'castle' and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' Asuote cognate with Lt. ašuotis 'symploca (type of cyanobacteria).' Probably named after homonymous stream nearby (now dārzupīte). | AK.
_alternative etymology: asuote borrowed from Lt. ašuotis 'symploca (type of cyanobacteria);' asuote cognate with (or borrowed from) Lt. ašuõtis 'hair of horse’s tail or mane;' asuote cognate with (or borrowed from) Lt. ašuõtė 'feather grass (stipa).'

_etymology: latg. for asuotes pilskalns 'Asote castle mound.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of top. Asuote and pilskalns 'castle mound,' itself a compound of pils 'castle' and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' Asuote cognate with Lt. ašuotis 'symploca (type of cyanobacteria).' Probably named after homonymous stream nearby (now dārzupīte). | AK.

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of atauga 'young growth; sprout, shoot,' cf. Lt. ãtauga 'young branch; sprout from dormant bud; outgrowth, offshoot; descendant.' Also a surname, referring to a young person or a person of small stature or in the sense 'gardener,' 'farmer' or 'descendant,' cf. HG Keim (DFD). ALEW s.v. áugti; LVV 1, 47.

nom.-acc.pl. of atauga 'young growth; sprout, shoot,' cf. Lt. ãtauga 'young branch; sprout from dormant bud; outgrowth, offshoot; descendant.' Also a surname, referring to a young person or a person of small stature or in the sense 'gardener,' 'farmer' or 'descendant,' cf. HG Keim (DFD). ALEW s.v. áugti; LVV 1, 47.

atmuôda 'awakening,' verbal noun to atmuôst 'awaken.' ME 1, 179.

pl.tant. atplûdi 'ebb,' verbal noun to atplûst 'flow back.' ME 1, 182.

nom.-acc.pl. of atraĩtnĩte 'wild pansy (viola tricolor).' ītis-derivation to atraĩtne 'widow.' Perhaps calque of HG Stiefmütterchen 'id.' ← Stiefmutter 'stepmother' in spite of the semantic difference. Atraĩtne itself derived from atrìest tr. 'separate, unravel.' ME 1, 184 s.v. atraĩtnis and atraĩtnĩte; 1, 186 s.v. atrìest.

nom.pl. of atvars 'opening, hole; abyss, river depth; whirlpool.' Cognate with (or perhaps parallel to) Lt. atãvaras 'river depth; place in river that is not frozen; swamp' Po. otwór 'opening.' Verbal noun to atvẽrt 'open.' Also a surname, probably referring to someone living near a river depth, cf. HG Loch (DFD). LVV 1, 48; ME 1, 207 s.v. I atvars and II atvars.

nom.pl. of atvarnieks 'river depth dweller,' nieks-derivation to atvars 'opening, hole; abyss, river depth; whirlpool.' Atvars is cognate with (or perhaps parallel to) Lt. atãvaras 'river depth; place in river that is not frozen; swamp' Po. otwór 'opening.' Verbal noun to atvẽrt 'open.' Also a surname, cf. HG Lochmann (DFD). LVV 1, 48; ME 1, 207 s.v. I atvars and II atvars.

nom.-acc.pl. of atvara, variant of atvars 'opening, hole; abyss, river depth; whirlpool.' Cognate with (or perhaps parallel to) Lt. atãvaras 'river depth; place in river that is not frozen; swamp' Po. otwór 'opening.' Verbal noun to atvẽrt 'open.' Also a surname, probably referring to someone living near a river depth, cf. HG Loch (DFD). LVV 1, 48; ME 1, 207 s.v. I atvars and II atvars.

nom.pl. of atvasȩ̄ns, ȩ̄ns-derivation to atvasa 'sprout; scion,' cf. Lt. atvašà. Ultimately to Lt. vèšti 'grow well.' Probably a surname referring to a young person or a person of small stature or in the sense 'gardener,' 'farmer' or 'descendant,' cf. HG Keimling (DFD). ALEW s.v. ãtvašas; LEW 23; ME 1, 207; SEJL 61.

dial. or partly standardized variant of atvasȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of atvasȩ̄ns, ȩ̄ns-derivation to atvasa 'sprout; scion,' cf. Lt. atvašà. Ultimately to Lt. vèšti 'grow well.' Probably a surname referring to a young person or a person of small stature or in the sense 'gardener,' 'farmer' or 'descendant,' cf. HG Keimling (DFD). ALEW s.v. ãtvašas; LEW 23; ME 1, 207; SEJL 61.

nom.-acc.pl. of atvase 'sprout; scion,' cf. Lt atvašė. Ultimately to Lt vèšti 'grow well.' Also a surname, possibly referring to a young person or a person of small stature or in the sense 'gardener,' 'farmer' or 'descendant,' cf. HG Keim (DFD). ALEW s.v. ãtvašas; LEW 23; ME 1, 207; SEJL 61.

nom.-acc.pl. of atvasīte, D to atvase 'sprout; scion.' | Cognate with Lt. atvašė. Ultimately to Lt. vèšti 'grow well.' | ALEW s.v. ãtvašas; LEW 23 s.v. atvašà; ME 1, 207 s.v. atvasa; SEJL 61 s.v. atvašà.

nom.pl. of audrȩ̄ns, ȩ̄ns-derivation to an unattested adjective *audrs 'stormy' or a noun *audra~audrs 'strong wind,' cf. Lt. áudra~áudras 'strong wind; surge; flood.' In OLt. áudra refers to water rather than air and the word possibly descends from from PIE *u̯ódr̥ 'water.' Probably a surname in the sense 'rascal,' cf. also aũdrums 'rascal' and surnames Lv. Audriņš Lt. Áudrinis (LPDB). ALEW s.v. áudra; Derksen 2015, 68 s.v. audra; LEW 6 s.v. áldra; LVV 1, 50 s.v. audrau; ME 1, 214 s.v. audaļa; SEJL 62 s.v. áudra.
_alternative etymology: audrȩ̄ns could also be derived from *audrs~audra in an archaic sense 'rapids' vel sim., in which case the ȩ̄ns-derivation would refer to a 'rapids dweller.'

_county: 232 Birzgale (formerly Linde; estate Mazā Muiža, formerly 344 Jumprava)
_etymology: nom.pl. of aûdzenieks, nieks-derivation to aûdze 'generation; shoot; grove; ulcer, boil' or to aûdzis 'grove; adolescent.' Probably a surname in the sense 'grove dweller' or 'descendant,', cf. surnames Audzītis Audziņš Lt. Augėnas (LPDB). LVV 1, 51 s.v. audze; ME 1, 215; 1, 216.
syntagm of nom.sg.fem.def. of aûgsts 'tall, high' and kaupre 'hillock.' LVV 1, 52 s.v. aûgstais; 2, 68.
syntagm of gen.sg. of kaupre 'hillock' and of kal̂ns 'mountain.' LVV 2, 68.

_comment: also a pilskalns in Plāķis so might be two units
_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of kàupre2 'hillock,' cf. Lt. kauprė̃. To Lv. kuprs Lt. kuprà 'hump, bulge.' ALEW s.v. kuprà; LEW 231 s.v. káupas; ME 2, 177; SEJL 483 s.v. kauprà.

compound of aûgsts 'tall, high' and of kal̂ns 'mountain.' Might replace older *augstkalnis, cf. Lt aukštãkalnis. Also a surname, probably referring to someone living on or by a tall mountain, cf. Lt. Aukškálnis (LPDB). AK.

nom.pl. of aûgstums 'height,' cf. Lt. aukštùmas. ums-derivation to aûgsts 'high, tall.' Also a surname, probably referring to someone living in a tall place, cf. Po. Wysota (ISNP) HG Höhe (DFD). ALEW s.v. áukštas; LVV 1, 52 s.v. aûgstais; ME 1, 218.

nom.pl. of augustinišķis, išķis-derivation to pers. name Augustins 'Augustine' (PDB) ← Lat. Augustīnus 'of Augustus,' īno-derivation to augustus 'majestic, venerable' (also an agnomen). The Lv. must have been borrowed via Lt. Augustìnas, Po. Augustyn or Ru Ávgustín—the variant Augustīns (PDB) with long ī might be directly from Lat. or via HG Augustin. Probably an old surname meaning 'Augustine's people,' cf. Lt. Augustináitis (LPDB) Po. Augustyński (ISNP). LPV 74; LVV 1, 52.

dial. or partly standardized variant of augustinišķi, nom.pl. of augustinišķis, išķis-derivation to pers. name Augustins 'Augustine' (PDB) with reanalysis of -in- as a native suffix which may alternate with -en-, cf. -inât~-ȩnât and -inieks~-enieks. Borrowed from Lat. Augustīnus 'of Augustus,' īno-derivation to augustus 'majestic, venerable' (also an agnomen). The Lv. must have been borrowed via Lt. Augustìnas, Po. Augustyn or Ru Ávgustín—the variant Augustīns (PDB) with long ī might be directly from Lat. or via HG Augustin. Probably an old surname meaning 'Augustine's people,' cf. Lt. Augustináitis (LPDB) Po. Augustyński (ISNP). LPV 74; LVV 1, 52.

dial. or partly standardized variant of augustinišķi, nom.pl. of augustinišķis, išķis-derivation to pers. name Augustins 'Augustine' (PDB) ← Lat. Augustīnus 'of Augustus,' īno-derivation to augustus 'majestic, venerable' (also an agnomen). The Lv. must have been borrowed via Lt. Augustìnas, Po. Augustyn or Ru Ávgustín—the variant Augustīns (PDB) with long ī might be directly from Lat. or via HG Augustin. Probably an old surname meaning 'Augustine's people,' cf. Lt. Augustináitis (LPDB) Po. partly standardized variant of augustinišķas, nom.-acc.pl. of augustinišķa, Motionsfemininum to augustinišķis, išķis-derivation to pers. name Augustins 'Augustine' (PDB) ← Lat. Augustīnus 'of Augustus,' īno-derivation to augustus 'majestic, venerable' (also an agnomen). The Lv. must have been borrowed via Lt. Augustìnas, Po. Augustyn or Ru Ávgustín—the variant Augustīns (PDB) with long ī might be directly from Lat. or via HG Augustin. Probably an old surname meaning 'Augustine's people,' cf. Lt. Augustináitis (LPDB) Po. Augustyński (ISNP). The feminine nom.-acc.pl. might be a noun of place here in the sense 'Augustine's place' or 'Augustine's people's place.' LPV 74; LVV 1, 52.

dial. or latgalian for augustinišķas, nom.-acc.pl. of augustinišķa, Motionsfemininum to augustinišķis, išķis-derivation to pers. name Augustins 'Augustine' (PDB) ← Lat. Augustīnus 'of Augustus,' īno-derivation to augustus 'majestic, venerable' (also an agnomen). The Lv. must have been borrowed via Lt. Augustìnas, Po. Augustyn or Ru Ávgustín—the variant Augustīns (PDB) with long ī might be directly from Lat. or via HG Augustin. Probably an old surname meaning 'Augustine's people,' cf. Lt. Augustináitis (LPDB) Po. Augustyński (ISNP). The feminine nom.-acc.pl. might be a noun of place here in the sense 'Augustine's place' or 'Augustine's people's place.' LPV 74; LVV 1, 52.

compound of pers. name Augusts 'August' (PDB) and muĩža 'estate,' i.e., 'August's estate.' Augusts borrowed from Lat. augustus 'majestic, venerable' (also an agnomen) perhaps via HG or MLG August. Also a surname, cf. Lt. Aũgustas (LPDB) Po. August (ISNP) HG August (DFD). LPV 74; LVV 1, 52 s.v. àugusts2.

dial. for Aûgustmuiža, compound of pers. name Augusts 'August' (PDB) and muĩža 'estate,' i.e., 'August's estate.' Augusts borrowed from Lat. augustus 'majestic, venerable' (also an agnomen) perhaps via HG or MLG August. Also a surname, cf. Lt. Aũgustas (LPDB) Po. August (ISNP) HG August (DFD). LPV 74; LVV 1, 52 s.v. àugusts2.

compound of augustiņš, iņš-derivation to pers. name Augusts 'August' (PDB) and pusmuiža 'farm-estate,' a compound of puse 'half' and muĩža 'estate.' Augusts is borrowed from Lat. augustus 'majestic, venerable' (also an agnomen) perhaps via HG or MLG August. Probably a surname in the sense 'of August' cf. Lt. Augustáitis (LPDB) Po. Augustowski (ISNP) Lat. Augustīnus. LPV 74; LVV 1, 52 s.v. àugusts2.

nom.pl. of pers. name Augusts 'August' (PDB) ← Lat. augustus 'majestic, venerable' (also an agnomen) perhaps via HG or MLG August. Also a surname, cf. Lt. Aũgustas (LPDB) Po. August (ISNP) HG August (DFD). LPV 74; LVV 1, 52 s.v. àugusts2.
borrowed from Ru. top. hydr. Avgustovka, ka-derivation to surname Ávgustov, itself the gen.pl. of pers. name Ávgust ← Lat. augustus 'majestic, venerable' (also an agnomen). LPV 74.

_comment: ASGTD estate? Might also be in BM or R
_etymology: phonologically from auliņciems 'beehive village' (= 'apiary'), compound of aũliņš (or aũliņa), diminutive to aũlis 'beehive' and cìems 'village.' Auliņš also a surname, probably in the sense 'beekeeper,' cf. Po. Ul Ulas (ISNP) HG Bienstock (DFD). In this case semantics of the top. rather 'beekeeper village.' LVV 1, 53 s.v. àulaiči2; ME 1, 223 s.v. aũlis.
_alternative etymology: compound of auliņa '(bird)cage' and cìems 'village' (ME 1, 223 s.v. I aũlis); aũlis might have a more archaic sense of 'hollow' or a different sense, e.g., 'riverbed,' cf. hydr. Lt. aulė BRu. ula (LVV 1, 53 s.v. àulaiči2); auliņš iņš-derivation to aũlis 'rascal' (ME 1, 224 s.v. II aũlis); iņš-derivation to aũle~aũls 'boot leg' (ME 1, 223).
