_etymology: contraction of top. Ausejeuka ← Ru. Ovsejevka or BRu. Aŭsejeŭka, ka-derivation to surname Ru. Ovséjev or BRu. Aŭséjeŭ, itself the gen.pl. of pers. name Ru. Ovséj or BRu. Aŭséj, variant of Ru. Jevséj or BRu. Jeŭséj. Ultimately from Gr. Εὐσέβιος, ii̯o-derivation to εὐσεβής 'pious.' LPV 180 s.v. Jevsejs; LVV 1, 55.

syntagm of gen.sg. of top. Ausejeuka and pusmuiža 'farm-estate,' a compound of puse 'half' and muiža 'estate,' i.e., 'Ausejeuka farm-estate.' Ausejeuka is borrowed from Ru. Ovsejevka or BRu. Aŭsejeŭka, ka-derivation to surname Ovséjev~Aŭséjeŭ, itself the gen.pl. of pers. name Ovséj~Aŭséj, variant of Jevséj~Jeŭséj. Ultimately from Gr. Εὐσέβιος, ii̯o-derivation to εὐσεβής 'pious.' LPV 180 s.v. Jevsejs; LVV 1, 55.

borrowed from Ru. top. Ovsejevka, ka-derivation to surname Ovséjev, itself the gen.pl. of pers. name Ovséj, variant of Jevséj. Ultimately from Gr. Εὐσέβιος, ii̯o-derivation to εὐσεβής 'pious.' LPV 180 s.v. Jevsejs; LVV 1, 55 s.v. àuseika2.

contraction of top. Ausejeuka ← Ru. Ovsejevka or BRu. Aŭsejeŭka, ka-derivation to surname Ru. Ovséjev or BRu. Aŭséjeŭ, itself the gen.pl. of pers. name Ru. Ovséj or BRu. Aŭséj, variant of Ru. Jevséj or BRu. Jeŭséj. Ultimately from Gr. Εὐσέβιος, ii̯o-derivation to εὐσεβής 'pious.' LPV 180 s.v. Jevsejs; LVV 1, 55.

Jevséj or BRu. Jeŭséj. Ultimately from Gr. Εὐσέβιος, ii̯o-derivation to εὐσεβής 'pious.' LPV 180 s.v. Jevsejs; LVV 1, 55.

nom.pl. of D to aũseklis 'morning star.' Also a FN, cf. LUV s.v. Auseklis and further Po. Jutrzenka (ISNP) HG Morgenstern (DFD). | eklis-derivation to àust 'break (of day),' cf. Lt. aũšti 'id.' | ME 1, 226.
nom.-acc.pl. of ausma 'daybreak,' ma-derivation to àust 'break (of day),' cf. Lt. aũšti 'id.' Also a pers. name, cf. Lt. Aušra. LPV 75; ME 1, 227.

nom.pl. of àustrums 'east,' ums-derivation to an unattested adjective *austrs 'rising; eastern.' Also a surname, perhaps referring to someone living to the east of the village, cf. HG Ost (DFD). ME 1, 229 s.v. *austrs and àustrums.

dial. or partly standardized variant of daugavauzȩ̄ni, compound of hydr. Daugava and top. àuzȩ̄ni, i.e., 'Auzāni-upon-Daugava.' Àuzȩ̄ni is the nom.pl. of àuzȩ̄ns 'oats farmer,' ȩ̄ns-derivation to àuza '(usually pl.) oats,' cf. Lt. avižà and perhaps OPr. wyse (presumes contamination with wisge 'id.,' cf. Lt vìzgė 'oatgrass, false oats'). Also a surname, cf. Lt. Avižė́nas (LPDB) Po. Owsiak (ISNP) HG Hafermann (DFD). ALEW s.v. avižà; Derksen 2015, 74; LEW 28; LVV 1, 58 s.v. aûzas2; ME 1, 231; SEJL 74.

Lt. avižà and perhaps OPr. wyse (presumes contamination with wisge 'id.,' cf. Lt vìzgė 'oatgrass, false oats'). Also a surname, cf. Lt. Avižė́nas (LPDB) Po. Owsiak (ISNP) HG Hafermann (DFD). ALEW s.v. avižà; Derksen 2015, 74; LEW 28; LVV 1, 58 s.v. aûzas2; ME 1, 231; SEJL 74.

nom.pl. of dial. V of an otherwise unattested *šķȩpȩrs 'boatsman.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Po. Szyper (ISNP) HG Schiffer (DFD). | Borrowed from MLG scheper, cf. also Lv. šķeperis (ME 4, 28) as well as Lt. škiperis ← HG Schiffer. | AK.
_alternative etymology: nom.pl. of an otherwise unattested *škapars 'shepherd' ← MLG schāper (initial š- and short a demand an explanation).

_etymology: partly standardized variant of aûgšgalȩ̄ni (auž-g- < aušk-g-; -gul- < -gal- by vowel harmony or reanalysis of -alȩ̄ns as -ulis + -ȩ̄ns, cf. Endzelīns 1922, 221), nom.pl. aûgšgalȩ̄ns 'highlander.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to aûgšgals 'highlands,' compound of aûgša 'top, the above' and gals 'end.' Probably a surname, cf. Lt. Aukštìnis (LPDB) Po. Góral (ISNP) HG Hochländer (DFD). ME 1, 219 s.v. aûgšgals.

dial. or latg. for aûgšgalȩ̄ni (auž-g- < aušk-g-; -gul- < -gal- by vowel harmony or reanalysis of -galȩ̄ns as -g-ulis + -ȩ̄ns, cf. Endzelīns 1922, 221), nom.pl. of aûgšgalȩ̄ns 'highlander.' ȩ̄ns-derivation to aûgšgals 'highlands,' compound of aûgša 'top, the above' and gals 'end.' Probably a surname, cf. Lt. Aukštìnis (LPDB) Po. Góral (ISNP) HG Hochländer (DFD). ME 1, 219 s.v. aûgšgals.

dial. or latg. for aûgšgalieši (auž-g- < aušk-g-), nom.pl. of aûgšgalietis 'highlander.' ietis-derivation to aûgšgals 'highlands,' compound of aûgša 'top, the above' and gals 'end.' Probably a surname, cf. Lt. Aukštìnis (LPDB) Po. Góral (ISNP) HG Hochländer (DFD). ME 1, 219 s.v. augšgalietis and aûgšgals.

nom.pl. of partly standardized variant of aûgšgalȩ̄ns 'highlander' (auš- < aušk-). ȩ̄ns-derivation to aûgšgals 'highlands,' a compound of aûgša 'top, the above' and gals 'end.' Probably a surname, cf. Lt. Aukštìnis (LPDB) Po. Góral (ISNP) HG Hochländer (DFD). ME 1, 219 s.v. aûgšgals.

nom.-acc.pl. of auziņa, dim. to àuza '(usually pl) oats,' cf. Lt. avižìnis 'oaten.' Cognate with Lt. avižà and perhaps OPr. wyse (if contaminated with wisge 'id.,' cf. Lt vìzgė 'oatgrass, false oats'). Also a surname, probably in the sense 'oats farmer,' cf. Lt. Avižė́nas (LPDB) Po. Owsiak (ISNP) HG Hafermann (DFD). ALEW s.v. avižà; Derksen 2015, 74; LEW 28; LVV 1, 58 s.v. aûzas2; ME 1, 231; SEJL 74.

Owsiak (ISNP) HG Hafermann (DFD). | inis-derivation to àuza 'oat' originally in a purely associative sense, cf. Lt. avižìnis 'oaten' to avižà 'oat.' àuza might further be cognate with OPr. wyse (if contaminated with wisge 'id.,' cf. Lt vìzgė 'oatgrass, false oats'). | ALEW s.v. avižà; Derksen 2015, 74; LEW 28; LVV 1, 58 s.v. aûzas2; ME 1, 231; SEJL 74.

_source: AŠĢTD 67; E 1925, 62; LĢIA 11239; LVV 1, 58 s.v. avȩna
_etymology: nom.pl. of avȩns 'ram,' most likely reanalysis of avins as if containing -en-, cf. -inieks/-ȩnieks a.o. Cognate with Lt. ãvinas OPr. awins OCS ovьnъ. Originally *-no-derivation to *ovis 'sheep.' Also a surname, cf. Lt. Ãvinas (LPDB) Po. Baran (ISNP). ALEW s.v. avìs; Derksen 2015, 73; LEW 28 s.v. avìs; LVV 1, 58 s.v. avȩna; ME 1, 232; SEJL 73.

borrowed from Lv. top. Avȩni. Etymologically nom.pl. of avȩns 'ram,' most likely reanalysis of avins as if containing -en-, cf. -inieks/-ȩnieks a.o. Cognate with Lt. ãvinas OPr. awins OCS ovьnъ. Originally *-no-derivation to *ovis 'sheep.' Also a surname, cf. Lt. Ãvinas (LPDB) Po. Baran (ISNP). ALEW s.v. avìs; Derksen 2015, 73; LEW 28 s.v. avìs; LVV 1, 58 s.v. avȩna; ME 1, 232; SEJL 73.

compound of vȩcs 'old' and top. Avȩni, i.e., 'Old Aveni.' Avȩni is the nom.pl. of avȩns 'ram,' most likely a reanalysis of avins as if containing suffix -en-, cf. -inieks/-ȩnieks a.o. Cognate with Lt. ãvinas OPr. awins OCS ovьnъ. Originally a *-no-derivation to *ovis 'sheep.' Also a surname, cf. Lt. Ãvinas (LPDB) Po. Baran (ISNP). ALEW s.v. avìs; Derksen 2015, 73; LEW 28 s.v. avìs; LVV 1, 58 s.v. avȩna; ME 1, 232; SEJL 73.
nom.pl. of avenis, Motionsmaskulinum to avene 'raspberry.' Only makes sense if surname but unattested as such. LVV 1, 58.

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of avenīte, dim. to avene 'raspberry.' Avene is an ene-derivation to avs 'sheep.' ME 1, 232.

nom.pl. of surname Avgucevičs ← BRu. Aŭgucevič (Av- for Au- perhaps due to russianization), cf. also Lt. Auguscevičius. Derived from pers. name Aŭgust 'August' ← Lat. augustus 'majestic, venerable' (also an agnomen) perhaps via HG or Po. August. LPV 74.

nom.-acc.pl. of ciklamene 'cyclamen' ← Gr. κυκλάμινος, derived from κύκλος 'wheel' with suffix abstracted from σησάμινος 'of sesame' a.o. Borrowed via Lat. cyclamen, perhaps via HG Zyklamen, Fr. cyclamen or Ru. ciklamén. Reanalysed as if containing plant name suffix -ene. Beekes 2010, 798 s.v. κύκλος; Chantraine 1968–1980, 597 s.v. κύκλος; GEW 2, 44 s.v. κύκλος.

_source: E 1925, 63 s.v. avoksneja and darījums; LĢIA 65554; LVV 1, 59 s.v. avuoksneja; 1, 196 s.v. darījums; Plāķis 2, 350
_comment: erroneously referred to as two objects in E 1925 and LVV 1.
_etymology: syntagm of gen.sg. of avuoksnẽjs 'spring area' and darījums 'clearing.' The first element is a substantivization of adj. avuoksnẽjs 'rich in springs,' an ējs-derivation to avuoksne 'spring area' < *avuot-snē. Ultimately from avuõts 'spring.' The second element is an ums-derivation to darīt 'do, make.' LVV 1, 196 s.v. darījums; ME 1, 232 s.v. avuoksnãjs and avuoksnẽjs; 1, 440 s.v. darījums.

syntagm of gen.sg. of darījums 'deed; result; clearing' and pļava 'meadow,' i.e., clearing-meadow. Darījums is an ums-derivation to darīt 'do, make.' LVV 1, 196 s.v. darījums; ME 1, 440 s.v. darījums.
nom.pl. of darījums 'deed; result; clearing,' ums-derivation to darīt 'do, make.' LVV 1, 196; ME 1, 440.

nom.pl. of avuõts 'source, spring.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Šaltìnis (LPDB) HG Spring (DFD) Eng. Spring. | Related to Ved. avatáḥ 'well' avániḥ 'riverbed,' cf. also Lt. HN Avantà a.o. | LEW 6 s.v. Alantà; ME 1, 233.

_alternative etymology: borrowed from Lt. bãbilas 'fat person' (also a surname); variant of babulis 'windbag' (ME 1, 246 s.v. I babulis).

_etymology: nom.pl. of baburis, error for or V of babulis 'windbag.' Probably also a FN, cf. Babulis (LUV) Lt. Babùlis (LPDB) HG Schwätzer (DFD). | ii̯o-derivation to babulêt 'babble' ← MLG babbelen or HG babbeln. | ME 1, 246 s.v. babulêt and I babulis.
_alternative etymology: error for or V of babulis 'cotter; hermit' ← Ru. bobýl' or BRu. babýl' perhaps via Lt. babìlis (ME 1, 247 s.v. II babulis); ← Po. FN Babul to Po. babula 'grandmother; elderly woman' (ISNP); or to Lt. FN Babỹs (LPDB).

_etymology: nom.pl. of bajãrs 'rich person.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Bajõras (LPDB) Po. Bojar (ISNP). | Borrowed from ESl. *bojarъ, cf. ORu. bojarinъ BRu. bajáryn. Similarly Lt. bajõras 'boyar, nobleman.' Ultimately from Turkic. | ALEW s.v. bajõras; LEW 30; LVV 1, 76; ME 1, 252; REW 1, 114 s.v. боя́рин; SEJL 81; Skok 1, 186 s.v. bòljarin.

nom.pl. of bajãrs 'rich person' ← East Slavic *bojarъ, cf. ORu. bojarinъ BRu. bajáryn and also Lt. bajõras 'boyar, nobleman.' Ultimately from Turkic. Also a surname, cf. Lt. Bajõras (LPDB) Po. Bojar (ISNP). ALEW s.v. bajõras; LEW 30; LVV 1, 76; ME 1, 252; REW 1, 114 s.v. боя́рин; SEJL 81; Skok 1, 186 s.v. bòljarin.

Bajõras (LPDB) Po. Bojar (ISNP). ALEW s.v. bajõras; LEW 30; LVV 1, 76; ME 1, 252; REW 1, 114 s.v. боя́рин; SEJL 81; Skok 1, 186 s.v. bòljarin.

nom.pl. of baķis 'bundle, pack; plump person,' borrowed from MLG packe, cf. also Lt. bãkis Liv. bak. Also a surname. LVV 1, 77; ME 1, 253.

error or folk etymology for bakši, nom.pl. of FN Bakša (or Bakšs, Bakšis; LUV), cf. also Lt. Bakšà (LPDB). | Borrowed from Pers. bāğče 'small garden' via OTu. bāğçe 'garden' and Ru. or BRu. bakšá 'watermelon plantation.' Probably borrowed as a FN, cf. BRu. Bakša. | LPDB s.v. Bakšà; REW 1, 43 s.v. бакча́.
_alternative etymology: variant of bâkšķi, nom.pl. of bâkšķis 'ridiculous person; glutton; stuffer; pushy person; wizard; whoremonger.' (s)tis-derivation to bâzt 'push, stuff' with epenthetic k and generalized -šķ-. Also a surname, cf. Po. Wypchał (ISNP) HG Füller. ME 1, 271 s.v. bâkslis and bâkšķis; 1, 275 s.v. bâslis and bāška; Blese 1929, 159 s.v. Bâksch; Motionsmaskulinum to bãkša 'midwife' of unclear origin. Broken tone is unexpected (ME 1, 271 s.v. II bãka and bãkša; 1, 275 s.v. bātene); to an otherwise unattested *bāksis vel sim., cognate with Lt. top. bokščių kaimas which probably belongs to Lt. surname bokštỹs (variants bókštas bakštis a.o., cf. also Lv. baksts), derived from Lt. bókštas 'tower' ← Po. baszta 'bastion' (LEW 52 s.v. bókštas; LPDB s.v. bãkštas; LVV 1, 91 s.v. bàkša); from Po. surname Boksa~Boksza~Bogsza, sza-derivation to bog 'god' (LPDB s.v. bakšà; ISNP s.v. boksa); to an unattested *baksît, variant of bakstît 'poke, stick' (ME 1, 252); from Lt. bakša etc., to baksė́ti~bakšyti 'poke, stick' (LPDB s.v. bakšà).

_etymology: nom.pl. of FN Bakša (or Bakšs, Bakšis; LUV), cf. also Lt. Bakšà (LPDB). | Borrowed from Pers. bāğče 'small garden' via OTu. bāğçe 'garden' and Ru. or BRu. bakšá 'watermelon plantation.' Probably borrowed as a FN, cf. BRu. Bakša. | LPDB s.v. Bakšà; REW 1, 43 s.v. бакча́.
_alternative etymology: error for bâkši, nom.pl. of Motionsmaskulinum to bãkša 'midwife' of unclear origin (broken tone unexpected; ME 1, 271 s.v. Cf. also Po. Wypchał (ISNP) HG Füller. ME 1, 271 s.v. bâkslis and bâkšķis; 1, 275 s.v. bâslis and bāška; Blese 1929, 159 s.v. Bâksch; from Po. surname Boksa~Boksza~Bogsza, sza-derivation to bog 'god' (LPDB s.v. bakšà; ISNP s.v. boksa); to an unattested *baksît, variant of bakstît 'poke, stick' (ME 1, 252); from Lt. bakša etc., to baksė́ti~bakšyti 'poke, stick' (LPDB s.v. bakšà).

_source: AŠĢTD 97; E 1925, 50; LVV 1, 77 s.v. bakša; Plāķis 2, 283

_etymology: pl.tant. bakšu kapi 'Bakši cemetery.' | Syntagm of gen.pl. of TN Bakši and nom.pl. of kaps 'grave; (pl.) cemetery.' Primary element is TN Bakši, nom.pl. of FN Bakša (or Bakšs, Bakšis; LUV), cf. also Lt. Bakšà (LPDB). Borrowed from Pers. bāğče 'small garden' via OTu. bāğçe 'garden' and Ru. or BRu. bakšá 'watermelon plantation.' Probably borrowed as a FN, cf. BRu. Bakša. | LPDB s.v. Bakšà; REW 1, 43 s.v. бакча́.

_etymology: nom.pl. of balberis. Borrowed as a surname from Lt. Balberis, variant of balbiẽrius~barbiẽrius 'barber, hairdresser; barber surgeon' ← Fr. barbier or It. barbiere perhaps via Ru. dial. barběr Po. balbierz or HG Barbier~Balbier. Cf. also surnames Lt. Balbiẽrius Po. Balbierz (LPDB) HG Balbier (DFD). LEW 35 s.v. barbiẽrus; LVV 1, 77; SEJL 84 s.v. balbiẽrius.

nom.pl. of balbieris 'barber, hairdresser; barber surgeon.' Borrowed from Fr. barbier or It. barbiere perhaps via HG Balbier, cf. also Lt. balbiẽrius~barbiẽrius 'barber, hairdresser; barber surgeon.' Also a surname and perhaps borrowed as such, cf. Lt. Balbiẽrius Po. Balbierz (LPDB) HG Balbier (DFD). LEW 35 s.v. barbiẽrus; LVV 1, 77; SEJL 84 s.v. balbiẽrius.

nom.pl. of balduonis 'noisemaker, noisy person,' uonis-derivation to an unattested cognate to Lt. báldyti intens. 'knock, thump,' cf. also baladóti 'make noise' balduonìs 'noisemaker.' Also a surname, cf. also Lt. Baldū́nas (LPDB) a.o. ALEW s.v. báldytis; Derksen 2015, 79 s.v. baldyti; 2015, 86 s.v. belsti; LEW 31 s.v. baladóti; 39 s.v. bélsti; LPDB s.v. baldūnas; SEJL 82 s.v. baladóti; 84 s.v. báldyti.
_alternative etymology: borrowed from Lt. balduonìs 'noisemaker;' uonis-derivation to a d-extension of the root in bala 'clayey, treeless valley; (pl.) bad, moist soil,' cf. Lt balà 'swamp' (ALEW s.v. balà; Blese 1929, 159 s.v. Baldun; Derksen 2015, 77; LEW 30; LVV 1, 78 s.v. baldas; LPDB s.v. baldūnas; SEJL 82).

_etymology: dial. for bal̃gal̂vji, nom.pl. of bal̃gal̂vis 'white-head, blonde, towhead; (pl.) cottongrass (eriophorum angustifolium).' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Balgalvis (LPDB) HG Weisskopf (DFD) Eng. Whitehead. | Compound of bal̃ts 'white' and gal̂va 'head.' Cognate with Lt. balgal̃vis. | LVV 1, 78; ME 1, 253.

nom.pl. of bal̃gal̂vis 'white-head, blonde, towhead; (pl.) cottongrass (eriophorum angustifolium).' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Balgalvis (LPDB) HG Weisskopf (DFD) Eng. Whitehead. | Compound of bal̃ts 'white' and gal̂va 'head.' Cognate with Lt. balgal̃vis. | LVV 1, 78; ME 1, 253.

dial. for bal̃gal̂vji, nom.pl. of bal̃gal̂vis 'white-head, blonde, towhead; (pl.) cottongrass (eriophorum angustifolium).' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Balgalvis (LPDB) HG Weisskopf (DFD) Eng. Whitehead. | Compound of bal̃ts 'white' and gal̂va 'head.' Cognate with Lt. balgal̃vis. | LVV 1, 78; ME 1, 253.

nom.pl. of bãliņš, dim. to bãlis 'brother; relative; (pl) male youth.' Also a surname (LUV), cf. Po. Bracik (ISNP) HG Brüderl (DFD). | Borrowed from MLG bōle 'brother; relative; dear' with ā for expected *uo due to contamination with brãlis 'brother.' | Blese 1929, 159 s.v. Balleing; LVV 1, 91 s.v. bàleņi2; ME 1, 271 s.v. bãlis.

nom.pl. of D to stìebrs 'straw; reed; rush (scirpus; juncus); gun barrel.' Also a FN, cf. LUV s.v. Stiebrs & Stiebriņš. | Cognate with Lt. stíebras 'mast; stick; stalk, stem.' | LEW 904 s.v. stíebas; ME 3, 1077; SEJL 1211 s.v. stíebas.

_source: AŠĢTD 77; E 1925, 57; LVV 2, 183 s.v. kusa; Plāķis 2, 322
_etymology: nom.pl. of kusiņš, dim. to kusis 'small fish.' Belongs to the root of kusls 'small, weakly,' cf. Lt. kùšlas~kušlùs 'id.' Parallel to kuslȩns 'small fish.' Also a surname, probably in the sense 'fisher, fishmonger,' cf. Lt. Žuvẽlis (LPDB) Po. Rybak (ISNP) HG Fischl (DFD). Derksen 2015, 267 s.v. kušlas; LEW 321 s.v. kùšlas; ME 2, 328 s.v. kusis; SEJL 608 s.v. kùšlas.
_alternative etymology: to OPr. pers. name Kusse (LVV 2, 183 s.v. kusa).

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of an otherwise unattested *bal̃ša, perhaps in the sense 'white one.' | i̯ā-derivation to an s-extension of adj. *bals 'white,' cf. Lt. bãlas and further bal̃sis 'white (domestic) animal' (of dog, pig or hare) as well as TN Balsiaĩ. Lv. only has bals 'bleach' which must be a substantivization but a meaning 'white' is implied by bal̃sȩns 'whitish' a.o. According to SEJL the -s- arose due to reanalysis of Lt. bálsta (present stem to bálti 'fade') as {bals-sta} instead of etymologically correct {bal-sta}. | LVV 1, 79 s.v. bal̃sis; SEJL 85 s.v. bals-.
_alternative etymology: to Lt. bal̃čius 'white animal or bird' (LVV 1, 79 s.v. bal̃sis); somehow to bàlss 'voice' (ME 1, 255 s.v. I bàlss), cf. also Lt. balsùs 'loud' (ALEW s.v. bal̃sas); = surname Baltsche, to *balts 'swamp' (Blese 1929, 160).

_etymology: nom.sg.fem. of bal̃ts 'white,' cf. Lt. báltas. Possibly a folk etymology of balda. Also a surname, probably referring to a pale person, cf. Lt. Baltà (LPDB) Po. Biały (ISNP) HG Weiss (DFD). | to-adjective to a lost cognate to Lt. bálti 'fade.' Cognate with OCS blato 'swamp' and Alb. baltë f. 'id.' which are substantivizations of the neuter singular and plural, respectively. Derksen apparently suggests that the noun is older but this seems unlikely. According to Orel MGr. βάλτος f. ‘swamp’ and Ro. baltă ‘id.’ are borrowed from Albanian. | ALEW s.v. báltas1; Derksen 2015, 80; LEW 30 s.v. balà; 32 s.v. bálti; ME 1, 258; Orel 1998, 15; SEJL 86.
_alternative etymology: judging by its distribution, bálti 'fade' could be an inner-Baltic derivation—in this case 'white' must be, too, and 'swamp' might not be so closely related after all.

_etymology: otherwise unattested cognate to Lt. baldà 'noisy appearance,' perhaps in the sense 'noise, roar' (of river). | Verbal noun to an unattested cognate to Lt. báldyti intens. 'knock, thump.' | LEW 39 s.v. bélsti.
_alternative etymology: borrowed from Lt. baldà 'noisy appearance,' perhaps in the sense 'noise, roar (of river); somehow to bala 'clayey valley; (pl.) bad, moist soil' (LVV 1, 78 s.v. baldas pļava); = bal̂da2 (fishing term related to nets) of unclear origin (ME 1, 253).

_etymology: syntagm of nom.sg.fem.def. of bal̃ts 'white' and mãja 'house,' i.e., 'white house.' | AK.
white estate.' | Syntagm of nom.sg.fem.def. of bal̃ts 'white' and muĩža 'estate.' Possibly a calque of HG Weissenhof. | AK.
white estate' | Compound of weiss 'white' and Hof 'estate, court.' | AK.

nom.pl. of bal̃tâbuols 'white clover (trifolium repens).' Also a surname, probably referring to someone living on or near a white clover field. | Compound of bal̃ts 'white' and âbuõls 'apple.' | ME 1, 258 s.v. bal̃ts.

nom.pl. of bal̃tgal̂vis 'blonde, towhead; (pl.) cottongrass (eriophorum angustifolium),' cf. Lt. baltgal̃vis. Also a surname (LUV), cf. Lt. Balgalvis (LPDB) HG Weisskopf (DFD) Eng. Whitehead. | Compound of bal̃ts 'white' and gal̂va 'head.' | ME 1, 257.

pl.tant. in the sense 'Baltgalvji-on-the-field.' | Compound of tīrums 'field, clearing' and top. Baltgalvji, i.e., the nom.pl. of bal̃tgal̂vis 'blonde, towhead; (pl.) cottongrass (eriophorum angustifolium)'—also a surname (LUV), cf. Lt. Balgalvis (LPDB) HG Weisskopf (DFD) Eng. Whitehead. | AK.

exists as a toponym only. | Borrowed from Ru. *baltica, itself from Lv. baltiņu (pusmuiža) 'Baltiņi farm-estate' with Ru. dim. suffix -ica replacing Lv. -iņu. Lv. baltiņu is the gen.pl. of baltiņš, an iņš-derivation to bal̃ts 'white.' ME has bal̃tiņš in the sense 'old white horse' but the derivation might refer to anything associated with the color white, cf. Lt. baltinỹs 'eyewhite; egg white.' Also a surname, probably referring to someone with blond hair or pale skin, cf. Lt. Báltinas (LPDB) Po. Bialik (ISNP) HG Wittke (DFD). | LUV s.v. Baltiņš; ME 1, 257 s.v. bal̃tiņš.

nom.pl. of bal̃tiņš, iņš-derivation to bal̃ts 'white.' ME gives the sense 'old white horse' but the derivation might refer to anything associated with the color white, cf. Bialik (ISNP) HG Wittke (DFD). | bal̃ts 'white' is a to-adjective to a lost cognate to Lt. bálti 'fade,' cf. also Lt. báltas. Further related to OCS blato 'swamp' and Alb. baltë f. 'id.' which are substantivizations of the neuter singular and plural, respectively. Derksen apparently suggests that the noun is older but this seems unlikely. According to Orel MGr. βάλτος f. 'swamp' and Ro. baltă 'id.' are borrowed from Alb. | ALEW s.v. báltas1; Derksen 2015, 80; LEW 30 s.v. balà; 32 s.v. bálti; LUV s.v. Baltiņš; ME 1, 257 s.v. bal̃tiņš; 1, 258 s.v. bal̃ts; Orel 1998, 15; SEJL 86.

nom.pl. of bal̃tziêds 'white blossom' or pl.tant. in the sense 'white river; leukorrhea.' Might also refer to a plant with white blossoms, cf. Lt. baltžiẽdė~-is 'aegopodium; snowdrop (galanthus nivalis); wood anemone (anemone nemorosa); yarrow (achillea).' | Compound of bal̃ts 'white' and ziêds 'blossom.' | ME 1, 258 s.v. bal̃ts; 4, 740 s.v. I zièds.

pl.tant. toponym. | Borrowed as a toponym from Lt. Balučiai, nom.pl. of surname Balutis (LPDB; → Lv. Balutis, LUV), utis-derivation to bãlas 'white.' Probably refers to someone with blond hair or pale skin, cf. Po. Bialik (ISNP) HG Wittke (DFD). | AK.
_alternative etymology: Lt. Balùtis is variant of Baliùtis, utis-derivation to Balỹs (LPDB).

_etymology: nom.pl. of surname Baļulis (LUV). | Borrowed from Lt. Baliùlis (LPDB) of unclear origin. Perhaps ulis-derivation to an otherwise unattested *bãlis~balỹs in the sense 'white one,' ii̯o-derivation to bãlas 'white.' Cf. also Po. Bialik (ISNP) HG Wittke (DFD). | LPDB s.v. Baliùlis.
_alternative etymology: variant of Balùlis, ulis-derivation to bãlas 'white' (LPDB); Lt. Baliùlis ulis-derivation to Balỹs, hypocorism for Bolèslovas, cf. Stasỹs to Stanìslovas (LPDB s.v. Baliùlis and Balỹs); Lv. baļulis ulis-derivation to baļa or balis vel sim., variant to bala 'clayey valley; bad, moist soil.' (LVV 1, 83); Lv. baļulis ulis-derivation to pl.tant. baļas 'winch for pulling nets out of the water' (ME 1, 261).

_etymology: nom.pl. of surname Baļujs (LUV). Probably confused with Baļuļi. | Borrowed from Ru. Baljuj of unclear origin, cf. also Baljuev Baljukin. | AK.
_alternative etymology: error for or dissimilation of baļuļi, nom.pl. of surname Baļulis.

nom.pl. of balutis. Exists only as a surname (LUV). | Borrowed from Lt. Balutis (LPDB), utis-derivation to bãlas 'white.' Probably refers to someone with blond hair or pale skin, cf. Po. Bialik (ISNP) HG Wittke (DFD). | AK.

_etymology: nom.pl. of surname Bambāns (LUV), cf. Lt. Bambónas (LPDB). | āns-derivation to Lv. bambât~bambêt 'beat, pound, make a racket' Lt. bambė́ti 'hum, rumble.' Might be further related to Po. bąbać 'beat' Gr. βομβεῖν 'hum, drone' or we may be dealing with individually arisen onomatopoeia. Semantically 'noisemaker,' 'rogue,' 'crybaby,' 'windbag' or 'beetle,' cf. also Lv. bim̃bals 'gadfly; crybaby' bam̃bals 'beetle' Lt. bam̃balas 'bumblebee; june beetle' Gr. βομβύλη 'bee' Ru. žúk 'beetle; rogue' as well as Lt. surname Bam̃balas (LPDB). | LEW 33 s.v. bam̃balas; ME 1, 261 s.v. bam̃bals and bambât; SEJL 89 s.v. bam̃balas and bambė́ti.
_alternative etymology: āns-derivation to bam̃ba 'ball; mallet' (itself to bambât 'beat, pound, make a racket'); borrowed from Lt. bambónas, āna-derivation to bámba 'navel; bump' or to bámbeti 'grow up, mature' in the sense 'fatty; potbelly,' cf. bam̃balas 'id.' (LEW 33 s.v. bámba).

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of avene 'raspberry.' | ene-derivation to avs 'sheep.' | ME 1, 232.

nom.pl. of bambanišķis. Possibly a surname. | išķis-derivation to an otherwise unattested *bambans, ans-derivation to Lv. bambât~bambêt 'beat, pound, make a racket' Lt. bambė́ti 'hum, rumble.' This verb might be further related to Po. bąbać 'beat' Gr. βομβεῖν 'hum, drone' or we may be dealing with individually arisen onomatopoeia. Semantically 'noisemaker,' 'rogue,' 'crybaby,' 'windbag' or 'beetle,' cf. also Lv. bim̃bals 'gadfly; crybaby' bam̃bals 'beetle' Lt. bam̃balas 'bumblebee; june beetle' Gr. βομβύλη 'bee' Ru. žúk 'beetle; rogue' as well as Lt. surname Bam̃balas (LPDB). | LEW 33 s.v. bam̃balas; ME 1, 261 s.v. bam̃bals and bambât; SEJL 89 s.v. bam̃balas and bambė́ti.
_alternative etymology: error for bambānišķis, išķis-derivation to bambāns; *bambans variant of *bambain(i)s, cognate with Lt. bámbainis 'potbellied' to Lt. bámba 'navel; bump' bámbeti 'grow up, mature.'

_etymology: dial. for bambanišķi, nom.pl. of bambanišķis. This verb might be further related to Po. bąbać 'beat' Gr. βομβεῖν 'hum, drone' or we may be dealing with individually arisen onomatopoeia. _etymology: dial. for bambinišķi, nom.pl. of bambinišķis. Possibly a surname. | išķis-derivation to a cognate with Lt. bam̃binti '(tr.) beat; (itr.) ring; blather, pester; walk tardily,' cf. Lv. bambinâtiês 'wrap oneself up.' Related to Lv. bambât~bambêt 'beat, pound, make a racket' Lt. bambė́ti 'hum, rumble' and further to Po. bąbać 'beat' Gr. βομβεῖν 'hum, drone' unless all are individually arisen onomatopoeia. Semantically bambinišķis might be 'noisemaker,' 'rogue,' 'crybaby' or 'windbag.' | LEW 33 s.v. bam̃balas; ME 1, 261 s.v. bambât and bambinâtiês; SEJL 89 s.v. bam̃balas and bambė́ti.

nom.pl. of bērzāns, a semi-standardized version most likely of *bārzāns (< *bȩ̃rzȩ̃ns). Might be a local FN corresponding to bērziņš. | ȩ̃ns-derivation to bȩ̃rzs 'birch' in the sense 'birchen one'. | AK.

nom.-acc.pl. of bȩ̃rzaûdze 'birch growth, birch grove.' | Compound of bȩ̃rzs 'birch' and aûdze 'growth.' First element is cognate with Lt. béržas, SCr. brȅz, Sln. brẹ̀z and perhaps OPr. berse which point to PIE *bherHǵ-o-. Taking the zero-grade root in Skt. bhūrjá- into consideration, we are probably dealing with an original ablauting root noun *bherHǵ-~*bhrHǵ- 'shine.' Slavic and Germanic mostly attest ā-stems, cf. Ru. berëza, Po. brzoza, OCS brěza, ON bjǫrk, OE beorc a.o. Still other cognates are Lat. fraxinus 'ash' Alb. bredh 'birch' as well as adj. Bu. brjaz and Alb. bardhë 'whitish, pale, spotted.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Béržas (LPDB) Po. Brzoza (ISNP) HG Birke (DFD). Second element is an ē-derivation to verbal root aûg- 'grow,' cf. Lt. aũgė 'growth; stature.' | ALEW s.v. béržas; Derksen 2015, 88 s.v. beržas; Kroonen 2013, 61 s.v. *berkō-; LEW, 40 s.v. béržas; ME 1, 215 s.v. aûdze; 1, 292 s.v. bȩ̃rzs; SEJL, 106 s.v. béržas.

nom.pl. of bȩ̃rzs 'birch.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Béržas (LPDB) Po. Brzoza (ISNP) HG Birke (DFD). | Exact correspondences are found in Lt. béržas, OPr. berse, SCr. brȅz and Sln. brẹ̀z. These point to an o-stem *bherHǵ-o-, which, along with Skt. bhūrjá- 'id.,' is probably derived from an ablauting root noun *bherHǵ-~*bhrHǵ- 'shine.' Slavic and Germanic mostly attest ā-stems, cf. Ru. berëza, Po. brzoza, OCS brěza, ON bjǫrk, OE beorc a.o. Still other cognates are Lat. fraxinus 'ash' Alb. bredh 'birch' as well as adj. Bu. brjaz and Alb. bardhë 'whitish, pale, spotted.' | ALEW s.v. béržas; Derksen 2015, 88; Kroonen 2013, 61 s.v. *berkō-; LEW, 40; ME 1, 292; SEJL, 106.

These point to an o-stem *bherHǵ-o-, which, along with Skt. bhūrjá- 'id.,' is probably derived from an ablauting root noun *bherHǵ-~*bhrHǵ- 'shine.' Slavic and Germanic mostly attest ā-stems, cf. Ru. berëza, Po. brzoza, OCS brěza, ON bjǫrk, OE beorc a.o. Still other cognates are Lat. fraxinus 'ash' Alb. bredh 'birch' as well as adj. Bu. brjaz and Alb. bardhë 'whitish, pale, spotted.' | ALEW s.v. béržas; Derksen 2015, 88; Kroonen 2013, 61 s.v. *berkō-; LEW, 40; ME 1, 292; SEJL, 106.

nom.-acc.pl. of pl.tant. bērziņu mājas 'Bērziņš' home.' | Syntagm of gen.pl. of bẽrziņš and nom.-acc.pl. of mãja 'house; (pl.) home.' Synchronically bẽrziņš is D to bȩ̃rzs 'birch' but exists also as a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Beržìnis (LPDB) Po. Brzozowy (ISNP). Etymologically it is an *inis-derivation to bȩ̃rzs 'birch' in the sense 'birchen,' cf. Lt. beržìnis 'birchen; birch stick' Ukr. bérezenь 'March' Po. brzezień 'id.' Lv. bȩ̃rzs finds exact correspondences in Lt. béržas, OPr. berse, SCr. brȅz and Sln. brẹ̀z. These point to an o-stem *bherHǵ-o-, which, along with Skt. bhūrjá- 'id.,' is probably derived from an ablauting root noun *bherHǵ-~*bhrHǵ- 'shine.' Slavic and Germanic mostly attest ā-stems, cf. Ru. berëza, Po. brzoza, OCS brěza, ON bjǫrk, OE beorc a.o. Still other cognates are Lat. fraxinus 'ash' Alb. bredh 'birch' as well as adj. Bu. brjaz and Alb. bardhë 'whitish, pale, spotted.' | ALEW s.v. béržas; Derksen 2015, 88; Kroonen 2013, 61 s.v. *berkō-; LEW, 40; ME 1, 292; SEJL, 106.

bȩ̃rzu sala 'birch island.' GROVE | Syntagm of gen.pl. of bȩ̃rzs 'birch' and sala 'island; hillock in marsh.' First element is cognate with Lt. béržas, OPr. berse, SCr. brȅz and Sln. brẹ̀z which point to an o-stem *bherHǵ-o-, which, along with Skt. bhūrjá- 'id.,' is probably derived from an ablauting root noun *bherHǵ-~*bhrHǵ- 'shine.' Slavic and Germanic mostly attest ā-stems, cf. Ru. berëza, Po. brzoza, OCS brěza, ON bjǫrk, OE beorc a.o. Still other cognates are Lat. fraxinus 'ash' Alb. bredh 'birch' as well as adj. Bu. brjaz and Alb. bardhë 'whitish, pale, spotted.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Béržas (LPDB) Po. Brzoza (ISNP) HG Birke (DFD). Second element is cognate with Lt. salà 'id.' and perhaps further related to Lt. sálti 'flow' and OPr. salus 'rainwater creek.' If so, then sala might be shortened from *ap(i)sala, a parallel to Po. ostrów SCr. òtok. Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Salà (LPDB). | ALEW s.v. béržas; Derksen 2015, 88 s.v. beržas; 2015, 387 s.v. sala; Kroonen 2013, 61 s.v. *berkō-; LEW, 40 s.v. béržas; 758 s.v. salà 1.; Mažiulis 4, 55 s.v. salus; ME 1, 292 s.v. bȩ̃rzs; 3, 664 s.v. sala; SEJL, 106 s.v. béržas; 1059 s.v. salà II.

nom.pl. of bikavnieks. Also a FN (LUV). | nieks-derivation to bikava of unclear meaning, cf. Lt. HN Bikava. Perhaps to Po. byk or Ru. byk 'bull,' cf. also Lv. bika 'billy goat; ram' (ME 1, 294). | LVV 1, 108 s.v. bikava.

_etymology: pl.tant. uôšu bikavnieki. Only attested as a TN. | Syntagm of gen. pl. of uôsis 'ash (fraxinus excelsior)' and nom.pl. of bikavnieks. First element is cognate with Lt. úosis and OPr. woasis and further related to Ru. jasen' ON askr Lat. ornus a.o. Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Úosis (LPDB) Po. Jesion (ISNP) HG Esche (DFD). Second element is a nieks-derivation to bikava of unclear meaning, cf. Lt. HN Bikava. Perhaps to Po. byk or Ru. byk 'bull,' cf. also Lv. bika 'billy goat; ram' (ME 1, 294). Also a FN (LUV). | ALEW s.v. úosis; Derksen 2015, 481 s.v. uosis; LEW 1167 s.v. úosis; LVV 1, 108 s.v. bikava; ME 4, 421 s.v. I uôsis; PKEŽ 4, 258 s.v. woasis; SEJL 1466 s.v. úosis.

nom.sg. bišu druva 'bee grainfield.' | Syntagm of gen.pl. of bite 'bee' and druva 'grainfield.' First element is cognate with Lt. bìtė and OPr. bitte and further related to OCS bьčela OHG bini OIr. bech a.o. Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Bìtė (LPDB) Po. Pszczoła (ISNP). Second element is cognate with OCS nom.-acc.pl. drъva 'wood.' Inherited from PBS as a neuter o-stem, cf. SCr. dȑvo 'tree.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Druvà (LPDB) HG Saatkamp (DFD). | ALEW s.v. bìtė; Derksen 2008, 122 s.v. *drъ̏vo; 2015, 91 s.v. bitė; LEW 45 s.v. bìtė; ME 1, 300 s.v. bite; 505 s.v. druva; PKEŽ 1, 147 s.v. bitte; SEJL 116 s.v. bìtė.

nom.sg. bišu kal̂ns 'bee hill.' | Syntagm of gen.pl. of bite 'bee' and kal̂ns 'mountain.' First element is cognate with Lt. bìtė and OPr. bitte and further related to OCS bьčela OHG bini OIr. bech a.o. Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Bìtė (LPDB) Po. Pszczoła (ISNP). Second element is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Kálnas (LPDB) Po. Góra (ISNP) HG Berg (DFD). | ALEW s.v. bìtė & kálnas; Derksen 2015, 91 s.v. bitė; 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; LEW 45 s.v. bìtė; 209 s.v. kálnas; ME 1, 300 s.v. bite; 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; PKEŽ 1, 147 s.v. bitte; SEJL 116 s.v. bìtė; 451 s.v. kálnas.

_etymology: nom.pl. of bẽrziņš, D to bȩ̃rzs 'birch.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Beržìnis (LPDB) Po. Brzozowy (ISNP). | *inis-derivation originally in the sense 'birchen' to bȩ̃rzs 'birch,' cf. Lt. beržìnis 'birchen; birch stick' Ukr. bérezenь 'March' Po. brzezień 'id.' Lv. bȩ̃rzs finds exact correspondences in Lt. béržas, OPr. berse, SCr. brȅz and Sln. brẹ̀z. These point to an o-stem *bherHǵ-o-, which, along with Skt. bhūrjá- 'id.,' is probably derived from an ablauting root noun *bherHǵ-~*bhrHǵ- 'shine.' Slavic and Germanic mostly attest ā-stems, cf. Ru. berëza, Po. brzoza, OCS brěza, ON bjǫrk, OE beorc a.o. Still other cognates are Lat. fraxinus 'ash' Alb. bredh 'birch' as well as adj. Bu. brjaz and Alb. bardhë 'whitish, pale, spotted.' | ALEW s.v. béržas; Derksen 2015, 88; Kroonen 2013, 61 s.v. *berkō-; LEW, 40; ME 1, 292; SEJL, 106.

1: mũsa 'fly' inherited (ME 2, 679 and 673 sub muša); 2: = (or ← w. etym. nativization) lt mūšà 'beating; beating of waves (lkž)' (aigars) to lt mùšti 'beat' inherited (Fraenkel 475); 3: = (or ←) bru myša (river) if to myš' 'mouse' and not of baltic origin, cf. lt pela (river) to pelė̃ 'mouse' (Būga 1923, 31); 4: ← mlg mūs f 'mouse' ? (aigars); 5: to mũsainis 'speckled horse' to mũsaîns 'speckled, freckled' (ME 2, 679; LV 2, 463) which probably not to mũsa 'fly' (pace ME 2, 679) but to lt mū̃sai 'mould, mildew' (tone!) cf ge schimmel 'grey speckled horse' (lv mušaîns 'speckled' must be folk etymology), river name mũsa most probably then 'moss(y)' or 'marsh' (cf ge moos n 'moss; marsh'; as for feminine gender, maybe neuter plural *muHs-eh2; lithuanian š due to ruki) what about mūša/mūsala mute? also mũsa and mũsiņas (LV 2) in EH
_alternative etymology: ad 1: lt musìs 'id.' opr muso 'id.' sl muha 'id.' gr μυῖα 'id.', cf. also lt river mūšà; ad 3: root basically means 'grey' not 'mouse'

nom.sg. of HN Dàugava. Rare as a FN (LUV). | ava-derivation to the root *daug- 'much' which is also seen in daũdz Lt. daũg 'much.' Semantically thus 'water-rich river,' cf. also the generic term daugaviņa 'id.' The suffix -ava might be identical to the root in avuots 'spring, source' Skt. avatáḥ 'well' a.o. | Karulis 2001, 203 s.v. daudz; LVV 1, 198; ME 1, 233 s.v. avuõts.

nom.sg. of HN Daugava. | Borrowed from Lv. HN Dàugava, an ava-derivation to the root *daug- 'much' which is also seen in daũdz Lt. daũg 'much.' Semantically thus 'water-rich river,' cf. also the generic term daugaviņa 'id.' The suffix -ava might be identical to the root in avuots 'spring, source' Skt. avatáḥ 'well' a.o. Rare as a FN (LUV). | Karulis 2001, 203 s.v. daudz; LVV 1, 198; ME 1, 233 s.v. avuõts.
nom.sg. of HN Dvina. | To PIE *dheu- 'foam, whirl.' | Karulis 2001, 204 s.v. daudz.

nom.sg. of HN Väina. | Borrowed from a preform to Ru. Dvina etc., i.e., *du̯ei̯nā vel sim., cf. also Lv. TN Dvieņinieki. Belongs to PIE *dheu- 'foam, whirl.' | Karulis 2001, 204 s.v. daudz.
nom.sg. of HN Veina. | Borrowed from a preform to Ru. Dvina etc., i.e., *du̯ei̯nā vel sim., cf. also Lv. TN Dvieņinieki. Belongs to PIE *dheu- 'foam, whirl.' | Karulis 2001, 204 s.v. daudz.
nom.sg. of HN Duna. | Borrowed from Sl. Dvina or a preform hereto, i.e., *du̯ei̯nā vel sim., probably via MLG Dǖne or ON Dȳna. Belongs to PIE *dheu- 'foam, whirl.' | Karulis 2001, 204 s.v. daudz.

HC to a cognate to Lt. gaidỹs, cf. Lv. brãlis : OPr. brāti 'brother.' | ME 1, 584.
_meaning: cock; cockcrow; fire; cock on firearm; last beam on gable; chanterelle; uppermost straw bundles on thatched roof; clods of sour milk in porridge

nom.-acc.pl. of dàugavkràce 'Daugava rapids.' | Compound of HN Dàugava and kràce 'waterfall; rapids; gorge intersected by stream.' | AK.

nom.pl. of dàugavkrasts 'bank of the Daugava.' | Compound of HN Dàugava and krasts 'bank.' First element is an ava-derivation to the root *daug- 'much' which is also seen in daũdz Lt. daũg 'much.' Semantically thus 'water-rich river,' cf. also the generic term daugaviņa 'id.' The suffix -ava might be identical to the root in avuots 'spring, source' Skt. avatáḥ 'well' a.o. Second element is cognate with Lt. krãštas 'edge; bank.' Might belong to Lt. krešė́ti 'grow firm.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. HG Ufer (DFD). | ALEW s.v. krãštas; Karulis 2001, 203 s.v. daudz; LEW 289 s.v. krãštas; ME 1, 233 s.v. avuõts; 2, 260 s.v. krasts; SEJL 561 s.v. krãštas.

nom.-acc.pl. of daugavleja 'Daugava valley.' | Compound of HN Dàugava and leja 'valley; servants' quarters.' First element is an ava-derivation to the root *daug- 'much' which is also seen in daũdz Lt. daũg 'much.' Semantically thus 'water-rich river,' cf. also the generic term daugaviņa 'id.' The suffix -ava might be identical to the root in avuots 'spring, source' Skt. avatáḥ 'well' a.o. Rare as a FN (LUV). Second element is of unclear origin, perhaps related to Go. undarleija 'smallest' Gr. λειμών 'meadow' OIr. lian 'id.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Slėnỹs (LPDB) Po. Dolina (ISNP). | Karulis 2001, 203 s.v. daudz; 2001, 512 s.v. leja; LVV 1, 198 s.v. dàugava; ME 1, 233 s.v. avuõts; ME 2, 447 s.v. I leja.
_alternative etymology: to leja 'sweet dew' (ME 2, 447 s.v. II leja).

pl.tant. jaûnie pìlsȩ̃tas kapi 'new city cemetery.' | Syntagm of nom.pl.masc.def. of jaûns 'new' and gen.sg. of pìlsȩ̃ta 'city' and nom.pl. of kaps 'grave; (pl.) cemetery.' Primary elements are jaûns and pìlsȩ̃ta. First element is cognate with Lt. jáunas OCS junъ and further related to Skt. yuvan- Lat. juvenis We. iau Go. juggs. Originally a derivation with Hoffmann suffix which has been thematicized in BS. Second element is a compound of pìls 'castle' and sȩ̃ta 'fence; farm.' | ALEW s.v. jáunas; Derksen 2015, 209 s.v. jaunas; LEW 190 s.v. jáunas; ME 2, 101 s.v. jaûns; 3, 217 s.v. pìlsȩ̃ta; SEJL 420 s.v. jáunas.

_alternative etymology: to MLG dōle 'ditch' (DFD s.v. Dohle): to MLG dōl 'rash, foolhardy' (DFD s.v. Dohle); if FN Dōlen is itself a TN then maybe to MLG dāl 'valley' (DFD s.v. Dahl); also other options.

nom.sg. dzȩgužkal̂ns 'cuckoo hill.' | Compound of dzȩguze 'cuckoo' and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' First element is cognate with Lt. gegužė̃ and OPr. geguse. Further related to ORu. žegъzulja ON gaukr a.o. Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Gegùžis (LPDB) Po. Kukułka (ISNP). Second element is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Kálnas (LPDB) Po. Góra (ISNP) HG Berg (DFD). | ALEW s.v. gegužė̃ & kálnas; Derksen 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; LEW 142 s.v. gegužė̃; 209 s.v. kálnas; ME 1, 539 s.v. dzȩguze; 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; SEJL 308 s.v. gegužė̃ I.

nom.sg. dzenes kal̂ns 'woodpecker hill.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of dzene 'woodpecker' and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' Primary element is dzene, an ē-stem V of dzenis 'woodpecker' which is cognate with Lt. genỹs and -genis in OPr. aytegenis 'lesser spotted woodpecker,' cf. also OPr. genix 'woodpecker.' Derived from Lv. dzenêt Lt. genė́ti 'prune,' itself to Lv. dzìt Lt. giñti 'drive.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Genỹs (LPDB) Po. Dzięcioł (ISNP) HG Specht (DFD). | ALEW s.v. genỹs; Derksen 2015, 171 s.v. genys; Karulis 2001, 248 s.v. dzenis; LEW 152 s.v. giñti; ME 1, 545 s.v. I dzenis; PKEŽ 1 58 s.v. aytegenis; 1, 349 s.v. genix; SEJL 314 s.v. genỹs II.
_alternative etymology: to dzenis 'piece of wood between plow shoe teeth' (ME 1, 545 s.v. II dzenis); to dzenis 'coachman' (ME 1, 545 s.v. III dzenis); to dzenis 'climbing rope' (ME 1, 545 s.v. IV dzenis); to dzeine (ME 1, 540 s.v. I dzeine); to dzeine (ME 1, 540 s.v. II dzeine).

_etymology: nom.sg. dzeņu kal̂ns 'woodpecker hill.' | Syntagm of gen.pl. of dzenis 'woodpecker' and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' First element is cognate with Lt. genỹs and -genis in OPr. aytegenis 'lesser spotted woodpecker,' cf. also OPr. genix 'woodpecker.' Derived from Lv. dzenêt Lt. genė́ti 'prune,' itself to Lv. dzìt Lt. giñti 'drive.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Genỹs (LPDB) Po. Dzięcioł (ISNP) HG Specht (DFD). Second element is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Kálnas (LPDB) Po. Góra (ISNP) HG Berg (DFD). | ALEW s.v. genỹs & kálnas; Derksen 2015, 171 s.v. genys; 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; Karulis 2001, 248 s.v. dzenis; 2001, 371 s.v. kalns; LEW 152 s.v. giñti; 209 s.v. kálnas; ME 1, 545 s.v. I dzenis; 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; PKEŽ 1 58 s.v. aytegenis; 1, 349 s.v. genix; SEJL 314 s.v. genỹs II; 451 s.v. kálnas.
_alternative etymology: to dzenis 'piece of wood between plow shoe teeth' (ME 1, 545 s.v. II dzenis); to dzenis 'coachman' (ME 1, 545 s.v. III dzenis); to dzenis 'climbing rope' (ME 1, 545 s.v. IV dzenis).

First element is cognate with Lt. ẽglė OPr. addle and further related to Ru. elь 'spruce' Po. jodła 'id.' Lat. ebulum 'dwarf-elder; danewort' a.o. Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Ẽglis (LPDB) Po. Świerk (ISNP) HG Fichte (DFD). Second element is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Kálnas (LPDB) Po. Góra (ISNP) HG Berg (DFD). | ALEW s.v. ẽglė & kálnas; Derksen 2015, 151 s.v. eglė; 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; LEW 117 s.v. ẽglė; 209 s.v. kálnas; ME 1, 565 s.v. egle; 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; PKEŽ 1, 48 s.v. addle; SEJL 266 s.v. ẽglė; 451 s.v. kálnas.

nom. sg. akmeņupīte 'stone stream.' | Compound of akmens 'stone, rock' and upīte, synchronically D to upe 'river, stream.' Primary element is akmens 'stone, rock' which is cognate with Lt. akmuõ Gr. ἄκμων 'anvil' Ved áśman- 'whetting stone; sky' Av asman- 'stone; sky' a.o. The Baltic reflexes show centum reflex of the palatal *ḱ though satǝm reflexes occur in Lv. asmens and Lt. ašmuõ 'blade' which are considered cognates. Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Ãkmenas (LPDB) Po. Kamień (ISNP) HG Stein (DFD). | ALEW s.v. akmuõ; Derksen 2015, 47; LEW 5; ME 1, 64; SEJL 12.

nom.pl. of eleksis 'alder.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Al̃ksnis (LPDB) Po. Olcha (ISNP) HG Erle (DFD). | V of àlksnis~èlksnis (Lt. al̃ksnis~el̃ksnis), cf. elekšņis. Further related to Ru. ol'xá dial. ëlxa Lat. alnus OHG elira ON ǫlr a.o. Unclear whether we are dealing with an inherited lexeme or a (substrate?) loanword. In any case the Baltic forms probably show k-epenthesis and perhaps also syncope of the i and transfer to the ii̯o-stems from the o-stems. If so, then we might reconstruct *alisnos~*elisnos which brings the Baltic forms closer to the Latin. | ALEW s.v. alìksnis; Derksen 2015, 50; EH 1, 367 s.v. elekšņis; LEW 8 s.v. al̃ksnis; ME 1, 68 s.v. àlksnis; 1, 567 s.v. èlksnis; SEJL 18 s.v. al̃ksnis.

elekšu bẽrziņš 'Bērziņš in Elekši.' D to bȩ̃rzs 'birch.' Also a FN, cf. Bērziņš Bērzs (LUV) Lt. Beržìnis (LPDB) Po. Brzozowy (ISNP). |        | Relational inii̯o-derivation to bȩ̃rzs 'birch,' cf. Lt. beržìnis 'birchen; birch stick' Ukr. bérezenь 'March' Po. brzezień 'id.' Lv. bȩ̃rzs finds exact correspondences in Lt. béržas, OPr. berse, SCr. brȅz and Sln. brẹ̀z. These point to an o-stem *bherHǵ-o-, which, along with Skt. bhūrjá- 'id.,' is probably derived from an ablauting root noun *bherHǵ-~*bhrHǵ- 'shine.' Slavic and Germanic mostly attest ā-stems, cf. Ru. berëza, Po. brzoza, OCS brěza, ON bjǫrk, OE beorc a.o. Still other cognates are Lat. fraxinus 'ash' Alb. bredh 'birch' as well as adj. Bu. brjaz and Alb. bardhë 'whitish, pale, spotted.' | ALEW s.v. béržas; Derksen 2015, 88; Kroonen 2013, 61 s.v. *berkō-; LEW, 40; ME 1, 292; SEJL, 106.

Further related to Ru. jantár' etc. Unclear origin. | ALEW s.v. giñtaras; Karulis 2001, 254; LEW 152; ME 1, 552 s.v. dziñtars; 1, 559 s.v. dzĩtars; SEJL 328.
rubuļkal̂ns 'ruble hill.' | Compound of rubulis 'ruble; medal' and kal̂ns 'hill, mountain.' | AK.

nom.pl. of ȩzȩrs 'lake.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Po. Jezioro (ISNP). | Cognate with Lt. ẽžeras OPr. assaran Ru. ózero OCS jezero a.o. as well as Arm. ezr 'edge, bank.' The inherited r-stem has been thematicized in BS. | ALEW s.v. ẽžeras; Derksen 2015, 158; LEW 125; ME 1, 572; SEJL 279.

nom.pl. of ezeriņš, synchronically D to ȩzȩrs 'lake.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Po. Jeziorek (ISNP). | inis-derivation originally in a purely associative sense to ȩzȩrs 'lake,' cf. Lt. ežerìnis 'lake-' to Lt. ẽžeras. Lv. ȩzȩrs also cognate with OPr. assaran Ru. ózero OCS jezero a.o. as well as Arm. ezr 'edge, bank.' The inherited r-stem has been thematicized in BS. | ALEW s.v. ẽžeras; Derksen 2015, 158 s.v. ežeras; LEW 125 s.v. ẽžeras; ME 1, 572 s.v. ȩzȩrs; SEJL 279 s.v. ẽžeras.

nom.sg. ȩzȩrkal̂ns 'lake hill.' Also a FN (LUV). | Compound of ȩzȩrs 'lake' and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' First element is cognate with Lt. ẽžeras OPr. assaran Ru. ózero OCS jezero a.o. as well as Arm. ezr 'edge, bank.' The inherited r-stem has been thematicized in BS. Second element is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' | ALEW s.v. ẽžeras & kálnas; Derksen 2015, 158 s.v. ežeras; 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; LEW 125 s.v. ẽžeras; 209 s.v. kálnas; ME 1, 572 s.v. ȩzȩrs; 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; SEJL 279 s.v. ẽžeras; 451 s.v. kálnas.

ljady azarъ-kolno 'Azar-Kolno untilled lands.' | Syntagm of dial. ljádo 'untilled land, clearing' and TN Azar-Kolno. Primary element is TN Azar-Kolno which is a rendition of dial. V of Lv. ȩzȩrkal̂ns  'lake hill.' | AK.

nom.pl. of ȩzȩrkrasts 'lakeside.' | Compound of ȩzȩrs 'lake' and krasts 'bank.' First element is cognate with Lt. ẽžeras OPr. assaran Ru. ózero OCS jezero a.o. as well as Arm. ezr 'edge, bank.' The inherited r-stem has been thematicized in BS. Also a FN (LUV), cf. Po. Jezioro (ISNP). Second element is cognate with Lt. krãštas 'edge; bank.' Might belong to Lt. krešė́ti 'grow firm.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. HG Ufer (DFD). | ALEW s.v. ẽžeras & krãštas; Derksen 2015, 158 s.v. ežeras; LEW 125 s.v. ẽžeras; 289 s.v. krãštas; ME 1, 572 s.v. ȩzȩrs; 2, 260 s.v. krãštas; SEJL 279 s.v. ẽžeras; 561 s.v. krãštas.

nom.sg. ȩzȩrmala 'lakeside.' | Compound of ȩzȩrs 'lake' and mala 'edge.' First element is cognate with Lt. ẽžeras OPr. assaran Ru. ózero OCS jezero a.o. as well as Arm. ezr 'edge, bank.' The inherited r-stem has been thematicized in BS. Also a FN (LUV), cf. Po. Jezioro (ISNP). Second element is cognate with ON mǫl 'gravel; stone embankment' Alb. mal 'mountain' a.o. | ALEW s.v. ẽžeras; Derksen 2015, 158 s.v. ežeras; LEW 125 s.v. ẽžeras; ME 1, 572 s.v. ȩzȩrs & ȩzȩrmala; 2, 555 s.v. I mala; SEJL 279 s.v. ẽžeras.
_alternative etymology: mala ← ON mǫl or Sw. dial. mal, cf. also Orc. muller 'stony beach' a.o. (de Vries 1977, 401).

Second element is cognate with ON mǫl 'gravel; stone embankment' Alb. mal 'mountain' a.o. | ALEW s.v. ẽžeras; Derksen 2015, 158 s.v. ežeras; LEW 125 s.v. ẽžeras; ME 1, 572 s.v. ȩzȩrs & ȩzȩrmala; 2, 555 s.v. _etymology: nom.pl. of ezernieks 'lake dweller.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Ežerỹs (LPDB). | nieks-derivation to ȩzȩrs 'lake,' cf. also Lt. ežerniñkas to ẽžeras. nom.pl. of ezernieks 'lake dweller.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Ežerỹs (LPDB). | nieks-derivation to ȩzȩrs 'lake,' cf. also Lt. ežerniñkas to ẽžeras. nom.-acc.pl. of ȩzȩrruõze 'lake rose.' Also a FN (LUV). | Compound of ȩzȩrs 'lake' and ruõze 'rose.' First element is cognate with Lt. ẽžeras OPr. assaran Ru. ózero OCS jezero a.o. as well as Arm. ezr 'edge, bank.' The inherited r-stem has been thematicized in BS. Also a FN (LUV), cf. Po. Jezioro (ISNP). Second element is borrowed from HG Rose. Also a FN (LUV). | ALEW s.v. ẽžeras; Derksen 2015, 158 s.v. ežeras; LEW 125 s.v. ẽžeras; ME 1, 572 s.v. ȩzȩrs; 3, 586 s.v. I ruõze; SEJL 279 s.v. ẽžeras.

nom.sg. ȩzȩrsils 'lake pinewoods.' | Compound of ȩzȩrs 'lake' and sils 'pinewoods.' First element is cognate with Lt. ẽžeras OPr. assaran Ru. ózero OCS jezero a.o. as well as Arm. ezr 'edge, bank.' The inherited r-stem has been thematicized in BS. Also a FN (LUV), cf. Po. Jezioro (ISNP). Second element is cognate with Lt. šìlas 'pinewoods; heath' and OPr. sylo 'heath.' Inherited as a neuter o-stem. Migth be further related to Gr. σκέλλω 'dry out' or to Ved. śila- 'ears (of corn) left on field.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Šìlas (LPDB). | ALEW s.v. ẽžeras & šìlas; Derksen 2015, 158 s.v. ežeras; LEW 125 s.v. ẽžeras; 982 s.v. šìlas; ME 1, 572 s.v. ȩzȩrs; 3, 839 s.v. sils; SEJL 279 s.v. ẽžeras; 1292 s.v. šìlas.

nom.sg. ȩzȩrzeme 'lake land.' | Compound of ȩzȩrs 'lake' and zeme 'earth, land.' First element is cognate with Lt. ẽžeras OPr. assaran Ru. ózero OCS jezero a.o. as well as Arm. ezr 'edge, bank.' The inherited r-stem has been thematicized in BS. Also a FN (LUV), cf. Po. Jezioro (ISNP). Second element is cognate with Lt. žẽmė OPr. semmē and perhaps OCS zemlja. Further related to Skt. kṣám- Gr. χθών Hitt. tēkan a.o. Originally a root noun which has been transferred to the ē-stem class in Baltic. Also a FN (LUV). | ALEW s.v. ẽžeras & žẽmė; Derksen 2015, 158 s.v. ežeras; 2015, 516 s.v. žemė; LEW 125 s.v. ẽžeras; 1299 s.v. žẽmė; ME 1, 572 s.v. ȩzȩrs; 4, 708 s.v. zeme; SEJL 279 s.v. ẽžeras; 1620 s.v. žẽmė.

dial. for nom.sg. dzeņa upīte 'woodpecker stream.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of dzenis 'woodpecker' and upīte, D to upe 'river, stream.' Primary element is dzenis 'woodpecker' which is cognate with Lt. genỹs and -genis in OPr. aytegenis 'lesser spotted woodpecker,' cf. also OPr. genix 'woodpecker.' Derived from Lv. dzenêt Lt. genė́ti 'prune,' itself to Lv. dzìt Lt. giñti 'drive.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Genỹs (LPDB) Po. Dzięcioł (ISNP) HG Specht (DFD). | ALEW s.v. genỹs; Derksen 2015, 171; Karulis 2001, 248; LEW 152 s.v. giñti; ME 1, 545 s.v. I dzenis; PKEŽ 1 58 s.v. aytegenis; 1, 349 s.v. genix; SEJL 314 s.v. genỹs II.
_alternative etymology: to dzenis 'piece of wood between plow shoe teeth' (ME 1, 545 s.v. II dzenis); to dzenis 'coachman' (ME 1, 545 s.v. III dzenis); to dzenis 'climbing rope' (ME 1, 545 s.v. IV dzenis).

nom.sg. of TN Vucȩnu ȩzȩrs 'Vucȩni lake.' | Syntagm of gen. of TN Vucȩni and ȩzȩrs 'lake.' Also a FN (LUV). |  | ME 4, 675 s.v. vuc! & vucȩns.

Also a FN (LUV). | ME 2, 61 s.v. ìesalnieks & ìesals.

nom.-acc.pl. of iẽvleja 'bird cherry valley.' | Compound of iẽva 'bird cherry (prunus padus)' and leja 'valley; servants' quarters.' First element is cognate with Lt. ievà 'bird cherry' SCr. ȉva 'willow' a.o. and further related to OHG īwa 'alder' Gr. ὄη 'elderberry tree' a.o. Also a PN and FN (LUV), cf. Po. Czeremcha (ISNP) HG Faulbaum (DFD). Second element is of unclear origin. Perhaps related to Go. undarleija 'smallest' Gr. λειμών 'meadow' OIr. lian 'id.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Slėnỹs (LPDB) Po. Dolina (ISNP). | ALEW s.v. ievà; Derksen 2015, 198 s.v. ieva; Karulis 2001, 512 s.v. leja; LEW 183 s.v. ievà; ME 2, 85 s.v. iẽva; 2, 447 s.v. I leja; SEJL 396 s.v. ievà.
_alternative etymology: to leja 'sweet dew' (ME 2, 447 s.v. II leja).

_etymology: nom.pl. of iẽvziêds 'bird cherry blossom.' | Compound of iẽva 'bird cherry' and ziêds 'blossom.' First element is cognate with Lt. ievà 'bird cherry' SCr. ȉva 'willow' a.o. and further related to OHG īwa 'alder' Gr. ὄη 'elderberry tree' a.o. Also a PN and FN (LUV), cf. Po. Czeremcha (ISNP) HG Faulbaum (DFD). Second element is cognate with Lt. žíedas 'blossom; ring.' Derived from Lv. ziêdêt 'blossom' Lt. žíedėti 'grow hard.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Žíedas (LPDB) HG Blume (DFD). | ALEW s.v. ievà žíedas1 žíedas2; Derksen 2015, 198 s.v. ieva; 2015, 518 s.v. žiedas; LEW 183 s.v. ievà; 1305 s.v. žydė́ti 2; ME 2, 85 s.v. iẽva; 4, 739 s.v. I ziêds; SEJL 396 s.v. ievà; 1627 s.v. žíedas.

Yōḥānān < YHVH khanún 'God is gracious,' borrowed via Gr. Ἰωάννης, Lat. Iōhannēs and probably MLG Johannes. Rare as a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Jõnas (LPDB) Po. Iwan (ISNP) HG Johannes (DFD). | ME 2, 106.

Iwan (ISNP) HG Johannes (DFD). | Ultimately from BHe. Yōḥānān < YHVH khanún 'God is gracious,' borrowed via Gr. Ἰωάννης, Lat. Iōhannēs and probably MLG Johannes. | ME 2, 106.

_etymology: dial. for nom.pl. of jaûnzemis 'pioneer, settler.' | Compound of jaûns 'new' and compositional V of zeme 'earth.' First element is cognate with Lt. jáunas OCS junъ and further related to Skt. yuvan- Lat. juvenis We. iau Go. juggs. Originally a derivation with Hoffmann suffix which has been thematicized in BS. Second element is cognate with Lt. žẽmė OPr. semmē and perhaps OCS zemlja. Further related to Skt. kṣám- Gr. χθών Hitt. tēkan a.o. Originally a root noun which has been transferred to the ē-stem class in Baltic. | ALEW s.v. jáunas & žẽmė; Derksen 2015, 209 s.v. jaunas; 2015, 516 s.v. žemė; LEW 190 s.v. jáunas; 1299 s.v. žẽmė; ME 2, 101 s.v. jaûns; 2, 103 s.v. jaûnzemis; 4, 708; SEJL 420 s.v. jáunas; 1620 s.v. žẽmė.

nom.pl. of jaûnzemis 'pioneer, settler.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Náusėdas (LPDB) Po. Osadnik (ISNP) HG Siedler (DFD). | Compound of jaûns 'new' and compositional V of zeme 'earth.' First element is cognate with Lt. jáunas OCS junъ and further related to Skt. yuvan- Lat. juvenis We. iau Go. juggs. Originally a derivation with Hoffmann suffix which has been thematicized in BS. Second element is cognate with Lt. žẽmė OPr. semmē and perhaps OCS zemlja. Further related to Skt. kṣám- Gr. χθών Hitt. tēkan a.o. Originally a root noun which has been transferred to the ē-stem class in Baltic. | ALEW s.v. jáunas & žẽmė; Derksen 2015, 209 s.v. jaunas; 2015, 516 s.v. žemė; LEW 190 s.v. jáunas; 1299 s.v. žẽmė; ME 2, 101 s.v. jaûns; 2, 103 s.v. jaûnzemis; 4, 708; SEJL 420 s.v. jáunas; 1620 s.v. žẽmė.

_etymology: nom.pl. of aûgškal̂ns 'tall hill.' Also a FN (LUV). | Compound of augšs 'tall' and kal̂ns 'hill, mountain.' First element is a dial. V of aûgsts. Second element is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' | ALEW s.v. kálnas; Derksen 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; LEW, 209 s.v. kálnas; ME 1, 219 s.v. augšs; 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; SEJL 451 s.v. kálnas.

nom.sg. jaunā muiža 'new estate.' | Syntagm of nom.sg.fem.def. of jaûns 'new' and muĩža 'estate.' Primary element is jaûns, cognate with Lt. jáunas OCS junъ and further related to Skt. yuvan- Lat. juvenis We. iau Go. juggs. Originally a derivation with Hoffmann suffix which has been thematicized in BS. | ALEW s.v. jáunas; Derksen 2015, 209; LEW 190; ME 2, 101; SEJL 420.
_alternative etymology: might be a calque of HG Neuhof.

_etymology: nom.sg. Neuhof 'new estate.' Also a surname (DFD). | Compound of neu 'new' and Hof 'yard; estate.' Primary element is neu, related to Lt. naũjas Skt. návaḥ Gr. νεός a.o. | EWD s.v. neu.

neiborna 'New Born.' | Borrowed from HG Neuborn, compound of neu 'new' and FN Born.

jaûnbornes baznīca 'New Born church.' Gen.sg. of jaûnborne 'New Born,' compound of jaûns 'new' and FN Borne (LUV), cf. also HG Born (DFD). | ē-derivation to HG FN Born < MHG born 'spring; well; drinking water.' | AK.

jaûnbornes kapi 'New Born cemetery.' Gen.sg. of jaûnborne 'New Born,' compound of jaûns 'new' and FN Borne (LUV), cf. also HG Born (DFD). | ē-derivation to HG FN Born < MHG born 'spring; well; drinking water.' | AK.

jaûnbornes muiža 'New Born estate.' Gen.sg. of jaûnborne 'New Born,' compound of jaûns 'new' and FN Borne (LUV), cf. also HG Born (DFD). | ē-derivation to HG FN Born < MHG born 'spring; well; drinking water.' | AK.

jaûnbrẽķi 'New Brēķi.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and brẽķi, nom.pl. of brẽķis 'crybaby.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Verksnỹs (LPDB) Po. Beksa (ISNP). | ii̯o-derivation to the root of brèkt 'cry' which is related to Ru. brexát' 'bark; gossip' Po. brzechać 'id.' OHG praht 'noise' a.o. Lt. brėkti is probably borrowed from Lv. (LKŽ s.v. brėkti2). | Karulis 2001, 143 s.v. brēkt; ME 1, 330 s.v. brèkt; 1, 331 s.v. brẽķis.
jaûnbum̃bieri 'New Bumbieri.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and bum̃bieris 'pear.' Also a FN, cf. Bumbieris (LUV). | Borrowed from BG Bumbeere, cf. also Est. pumber. | ME 1, 349.

jaûndãvidi 'New Dāvidi.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and PN FN Dãvids 'David' (LPV; LUV) Lt. Dõvydas (LPDB) Po. Dawid (ISNP) HG David (DFD). | Borrowed from BHe. davíd 'beloved' via Gr. Δαυῑ́δ, Lat. Dāvīd and probably HG David or its MLG counterpart. | LPV 96.

_comment: possible match with E 1925 in grāveri 1.
_etymology: pl.tant. TN Jaûngrãveri 'New Grāveri.' | Compound of jaûns 'new' and TN Grãveri. Primary element is TN Grãveri, nom.pl. of grãveris 'digger' (ME 1, 644). Also a FN (LUV). | Borrowed from MLG grāver. | AK.
jaûngùlbji 'New Gulbji.' Nom.pl. of gùlbis 'swan.' Also a FN (LUV). | Cognate with Lt. gul̃bis and OPr. gulbis. | ME 1, 676.

pl.tant. TN Jaûnie Dàugavieši 'New Daugavieši.' | Syntagm of nom.pl.masc.def. of jaûns 'new' and TN Dàugavieši. Primary element is TN Dàugavieši, nom.pl. of dàugavietis 'Daugava dweller.' ietis-derivation to HN Dàugava, ava-derivation to the root *daug- 'much' which is also seen in daũdz Lt. daũg 'much.' Semantically thus 'water-rich river.' The suffix -ava might be identical to the root in avuots 'spring, source' Skt. avatáḥ 'well' a.o. Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Daũgavietis (← Lv.; LPDB). | Karulis 2001, 203 s.v. daudz; ME 1, 233 s.v. avuõts; 1, 444 s.v. dàugavietis.

nom.pl. of dàugavietis 'Daugava dweller.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Daũgavietis (← Lv.; LPDB). | ietis-derivation to HN Dàugava, ava-derivation to the root *daug- 'much' which is also seen in daũdz Lt. daũg 'much.' Semantically thus 'water-rich river.' The suffix -ava might be identical to the root in avuots 'spring, source' Skt. avatáḥ 'well' a.o. | Karulis 2001, 203 s.v. daudz; ME 1, 233 s.v. avuõts; 1, 444 s.v. dàugavietis.

pl.tant. TN Jaûnie Grãveri 'New Grāveri.' | Syntagm of nom.pl.masc.def. of jaûns 'new' and TN Grãveri. Primary element is TN Grãveri, nom.pl. of grãveris 'digger' (ME 1, 644). Also a FN (LUV). | Borrowed from MLG grāver. | AK.

pl.tant. TN Jaûnie Uôzuõli 'New Uôzuõli.' | Syntagm of nom.pl.masc.def. of jaûns 'new' and TN Uôzuõli. Primary element is TN Uôzuõli, nom.pl. of uôzuõls 'oak.'Cognate with Lt. ą́žuolas and further related to OPr. ansonis 'oak' as well as Ru. úzel Po. węzeł a.o. 'knot.' Given the attested suffix variety we are probably dealing with an original athematic l- or perhaps l/n-stem. Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Ąžuolas (LPDB), HG Eiche (DFD). | ALEW ą́žuolas; Derksen 2015, 75; LEW 28; ME 4, 427; SEJL 75.
nom.pl. of jaûniẽtis 'young person.' Also a FN (LUV). | ietii̯o-derivation to jaûns 'young; new.' | ME 2, 100 s.v. jaûniẽte.

jaûnkaļ̃ķi 'New Kaļķi.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and kaļ̃ķi, nom.pl. of kaļ̃ķis 'limestone, chalk; lime pipe; (pl.) quicklime.' Also a FN (LUV), probably in the sense of a limeburner, cf. Lt. Kálkis (LPDB) Po. Kalka (ISNP) HG Kalk (DFD). | Borrowed from HG Kalk or MLG kalk 'chalk,' cf. also Lt. kálkis Po. kalka. | ME 2, 147.

jaûnkrasti 'New Krasti.' Nom.pl. of krasts 'bank.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. HG Ufer (DFD). | Cognate with Lt. krãštas 'edge; bank.' Might belong to Lt. krešė́ti 'grow firm.' | ALEW s.v. krãštas; LEW 289; ME 2, 260; SEJL 561.

nom.pl. of jaûnlaĩks 'modern time.' | Compound of jaûns 'new' and laĩks 'time.' First element is cognate with Lt. jáunas OCS junъ and further related to Skt. yuvan- Lat. juvenis We. iau Go. juggs. Originally a derivation with Hoffmann suffix which has been thematicized in BS. Second element is cognate with Lt. laĩkas ... | ALEW s.v. jáunas; Derksen 2015, 209; LEW 190; ME 2, 101 s.v. jaûns; 2, 405 s.v. laĩks; SEJL 420.
jaûnleĩšupji 'New Leišupji.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and leĩšupji, nom.pl. of leĩšupis 'Lithuanian stream.' | Compound of leĩtis 'Lithuanian' and upe 'river, stream.' | AK.

jaûnliẽpas 'New Liepas.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and liẽpas, nom.-acc.pl. of liẽpa 'lime tree, linden.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Líepa (LPDB) Po. Lipa (ISNP) HG Linde (DFD). | Cognate with Lt. líepa Ru. lípa Po. lipa SCr lȉpa a.o. | ALEW s.v. líepa; LEW 366; ME 2, 503; SEJL 658.

nom.sg. jaûnlĩve 'new Līve.' | Compound of jaûns 'new' and TN lĩve. Primary element is lĩve which is derived from FN Līvens (LUV) ← HG or MLG FN (von) Lieven, itself from Liv. līvə̂(z) 'Livonian,' cf. also Lv. lĩvis (ME 2, 491 s.v. I lĩvis). | NE s.v. Daugmale.

nom.sg. Dàugavas muĩža 'Daugava estate.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of HN Dàugava and muĩža 'estate.' Primary element is Dàugava, an ava-derivation to the root *daug- 'much' which is also seen in daũdz Lt. daũg 'much.' Semantically thus 'water-rich river,' cf. also the generic term daugaviņa 'id.' The suffix -ava might be identical to the root in avuots 'spring, source' Skt. avatáḥ 'well' a.o. Rare as a FN (LUV). | Karulis 2001, 203 s.v. daudz; LVV 1, 198; ME 1, 233 s.v. avuõts.

jaûnluģenieki 'New Luģenieki.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and luģenieki, nom.pl. of luģenieks 'transport boatsman.' Also a FN (LUV). | nieka-derivation to luģis 'big transport boat' ← Ru. dial. lod'ja. | ME 2, 510 s.v. luģinieks.

pl.tant. TN Jaunmazlejiņas 'New Little Lejiņas.' | Compound of jaûns 'new' and mazs 'little' and TN Lejiņas. Primary element is TN Lejiņas, nom.-acc.pl. of lejiņa, D to leja 'valley; servants' quarters.' Unclear etymology. Perhaps related to Go. undarleija 'smallest' Gr. λειμών 'meadow' OIr. lian 'id.' Also a FN (LUV). | Karulis 2001, 512 s.v. leja; ME 2, 447 s.v. I leja.
_alternative etymology: to leja 'sweet dew' (ME 2, 447 s.v. II leja).

_etymology: pl.tant. jaûnplēši 'new plēši.' Also a FN, cf. Plēsis (LUV). | nom.pl. of plēsis 'ruffian,' ii̯o-derivation to plêst 'tear.' Cognate with lt. plėšỹs 'robber.' | ME 3, 340.

jaûnpodvinka 'New Podvinka.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and podvinka 'situated on the Daugava.' | Borrowed from Ru. podvinka or its BRu. counterpart or from Po. podźwinka. Compound of po 'on' and ka-derivation of dviná~dźwina 'Daugava.' | AK.

jaûnrãcenīši 'New Rācenīši.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and rãcenīši, nom.pl. of D to rãcenis 'sugar beet; turnip; potato; part of spinning wheel.' Also a FN (LUV). | Contamination of *rāpe 'sugar beet' (Lt. rópė) and *raciņi 'root vegetables' (to rakt 'dig'). | ME 3, 494.
_meaning: sugar beet; turnip; potato; part of spinning wheel

_etymology: nom.pl. of riẽksts 'nut.' Also a FN (LUV). | Related to and perhaps even cognate with Lt. ríešutas; apart from the scenarios mentioned in ME, Lv. riẽksts may be derived from *riesuts if we assume syncope (cf., vȩcs : Lt. vẽtušas 'old'), and epenthetic k. Further related to OPr. buccareisis 'beech-nut' Ru. oréx 'walnut' a.o. | Derksen 2015, 382; LEW 731; ME 3, 544 s.v. I riẽksts; SEJL 1027.

nom.pl. of riẽksts 'nut.' Also a FN (LUV). | Related to and perhaps even cognate with Lt. ríešutas; apart from the scenarios mentioned in ME, Lv. riẽksts may be derived from *riesuts if we assume syncope (cf., vȩcs : Lt. vẽtušas 'old'), and epenthetic k. Further related to OPr. buccareisis 'beech-nut' Ru. oréx 'walnut' a.o. | Derksen 2015, 382; LEW 731; ME 3, 544 s.v. I riẽksts; SEJL 1027.
jaûndubulti 'New Dubulti.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and dubulti, nom.pl. of dubults 'double.' Also a FN (LUV). | Borrowed from LG dubbelt, cf. Lt. dubultas. | ME 1, 509.

jaûnrudzāti 'New Rudzāti.' Nom.pl. of rudzāts 'rye farmhouse.' From rudzsāts, compound of rudzis 'rye grain; (pl.) rye' and sāts 'fence; farmhouse.' Also a FN, cf. Rudzāts (LUV). | Cognate with Lt. rugỹs OPr. rugis Ru. rož' ON rugr a.o. | ME 3, 555.
nom.pl. of meĩstars 'master craftsman.' Also a FN (LUV). | ME 2, 592 s.v. meĩsteris.

jaûnrudzāti 'New Rudzāti.' Nom.pl. of rudzāts 'rye farmhouse.' From rudzsāts, compound of rudzis 'rye grain; (pl.) rye' and sāts 'fence; farmhouse.' Also a FN, cf. Rudzāts (LUV). | Cognate with Lt. rugỹs OPr. rugis Ru. rož' ON rugr a.o. | ME 3, 555.

nom.pl. of D to rũķis 'industrious person; dwarf, industrious house spirit.' Also a FN, cf. LUV s.v. Rũķis & Rũķītis. | ii̯o-derivation to the root in rũķêt 'be industrious' ← MLG ruken. The D is used especially in the sense 'dwarf, industrious house spirit.' | ME 3, 570 s.v. I rũķis.
_alternative etymology: rũķis 'sourpuss' to rūkt (ME 3, 570 s.v. I rũķis); rūķis 'small earthworm' (ME 3, 570 s.v. II rũķis); rũķis 'chimney' (ME 3, 570 s.v. III rũķis); rũķis 'execution' (ME 3, 570 s.v. IV rūķis).

_etymology: jaûnsal̂des 'New Saldes.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and sal̂des, nom.-acc.pl. of sal̂de 'sweetness.' Also a FN (LUV). | ē-derivation to sal̂ds 'sweet.' | tezaurs.lv.
nom.-acc.pl. of jaûnsȩ̃ta 'new cottage.' | Compound of jaûns 'new' and sȩ̃ta 'fence; cottage; yard.' | AK.
nom.pl. of jaûnsẽtniẽks 'new cottager, settler.' Also a FN (LUV). | Compound of jaûns 'new' and sẽtniẽks 'cottager; stay-at-home; errand boy.' | ME 3, 834 s.v. sēteniẽks sẽtniẽks.

jaûnsîķeļi 'New Sīķeļi.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and sîķelis 'a bit; small creature' vel sim. | elii̯o-D to sîks 'small, petty; tender; thorough' which is cognate with Lt. sinkus. For semantics see sīkaliņš. | ME 3, 851 s.v. sīkaliņš; 3, 852 s.v. sîks.

jaûnsîķeļi 'New Sīķeļi.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and sîķelis 'a bit; small creature' vel sim. | elii̯o-D to sîks 'small, petty; tender; thorough' which is cognate with Lt. sinkus. For semantics see sīkaliņš. | ME 3, 851 s.v. sīkaliņš; 3, 852 s.v. sîks.

jaûnsîķeļi 'New Sīķeļi.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and sîķelis 'a bit; small creature' vel sim. | elii̯o-D to sîks 'small, petty; tender; thorough' which is cognate with Lt. sinkus. For semantics see sīkaliņš. | ME 3, 851 s.v. sīkaliņš; 3, 852 s.v. sîks.

TN Jaûnsilavas 'New Silavas.' | Compound of jaûns 'new' and TN Silavas. Primary element is TN Silavas, nom.-acc.pl. of silava 'spruce or pine forest; (pl.) grove.' avā-derivation to sils 'pinewoods' which is cognate with Lt. šìlas 'pinewoods; heath' and OPr. sylo 'heath.' Inherited as a neuter o-stem. Might be further related to Gr. σκέλλω 'dry out' or to Ved. śila- 'ears (of corn) left on field.' Also a FN (LUV). | ALEW s.v. šìlas; LEW 982 s.v. šìlas; ME 3, 838 s.v. silava; 3, 839 s.v. sils; SEJL 1292 s.v. šìlas.

jaûnslĩtȩrȩ̃ni 'New Slīterēni.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and slĩtȩrȩ̃ni, nom.pl. of slĩtȩrȩ̃ns 'of the warder.' Also a FN, cf. Slīters (LUV). | ēna-derivation to slĩteris 'warder' ← MLG slǖter. | AK.
nom.pl. of jaûnspruoģis 'curly head junior.' Also a FN, cf. LUV s.v. Sproģis & Jaunsproģis (LUV). | Compound of jaûns 'new; young' and spruoģis 'curly head; (pl.) curls in the clouds.' | AK.
jaûnstraumȩ̄ni 'New Straumēni.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and straumȩ̄ni, nom.pl. of straumȩ̄ns 'rapids dweller.' Also a FN (LUV). | ēna-derivation to straume 'stream, current.' | AK.
jaûnsturti 'New Sturti.' Compound of jaûns 'new' and sturts. | Unclear meaning and etymology. | AK.

jaûnsudrabi 'New Sudrabi.' Nom.pl. of sudrabs 'silver.' Also a FN (LUV). | From sudabrs w. metathesis. Cognate with Lt. sudãbras and possibly also OCS sъrebro. Further related to OPr. siraplis Go. silubr Celtib. silabur a.o. Probably a Wanderwort. | ALEW s.v. sidãbras; Derksen 2015, 396 s.v. sidabras; LEW 780 s.v. sidãbras; ME 3, 835 s.v. sidrabs; 3, 1113 s.v. sudabrs; 3, 1114 s.v. sudrabs; SEJL 1091 s.v. sidãbras.

jaûnsudrabiņi 'New Sudrabiņi.' Nom.pl. of D to sudrabs 'silver.' Also a FN, cf. LUV s.v. Sudrabs & Sudrabiņš. | From sudabrs w. metathesis. Cognate with Lt. sudãbras and possibly also OCS sъrebro. Further related to OPr. siraplis Go. silubr Celtib. silabur a.o. jaûnsudrabiņi 'New Sudrabiņi.' Nom.pl. of D to sudrabs 'silver.' Also a FN, cf. LUV s.v. Sudrabs & Sudrabiņš. | From sudabrs w. metathesis. Cognate with Lt. sudãbras and possibly also OCS sъrebro. iņš-derivation to jaûnuôzuõls 'young oak tree' (cf. ME 2, 103 sub jaûnuôzuõlu muižiņa) compound of jaûns 'new; young' inherited (ME 2, 101) and uôzuõls 'oak tree' inherited (ME 4, 427)
to (?) jaûns 'young, new' inherited (ME 2, 101)
jaûnvaĩruõgi 'New Vairogi.' Nom.pl. of vaĩruõgs 'shield.' Also a FN (LUV). | Related to vairît 'ward off' on the model of karuõgs 'flag.' | ME 4, 443 s.v. vaĩruõgs.
nom.-acc.pl. of jaûnzeme 'new land.' Also a FN (LUV). | Compound of jaûns 'new, young' and zeme 'earth, land.' | AK.
nom.pl. of jaûnzemis 'pioneer, settler.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Náusėdas (LPDB) Po. Osadnik (ISNP) HG Siedler (DFD). | Compound of jaûns 'new' and ii̯o-derivation to zeme 'earth.' | ME 2, 103.

dial. for nom.pl. jaûnzemis 'pioneer, settler.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Náusėdas (LPDB) Po. Osadnik (ISNP) HG Siedler (DFD).| Compound of jaûns 'new' and compositional V of zeme 'earth.' First element is cognate with Lt. jáunas OCS junъ and further related to Skt. yuvan- Lat. juvenis We. iau Go. juggs. Originally a derivation with Hoffmann suffix which has been thematicized in BS. Second element is cognate with Lt. žẽmė OPr. semmē and perhaps OCS zemlja. Further related to Skt. kṣám- Gr. χθών Hitt. tēkan a.o. Originally a root noun which has been transferred to the ē-stem class in Baltic. | ALEW s.v. jáunas & žẽmė; Derksen 2015, 209 s.v. jaunas; 2015, 516 s.v. žemė; LEW 190 s.v. jáunas; 1299 s.v. žẽmė; ME 2, 101 s.v. jaûns; 2, 103 s.v. jaûnzemis; 4, 708; SEJL 420 s.v. jáunas; 1620 s.v. žẽmė.

First element is cognate with Lt. jáunas OCS junъ and further related to Skt. yuvan- Lat. juvenis We. iau Go. juggs. Originally a derivation with Hoffmann suffix which has been thematicized in BS. Second element is cognate with Lt. žẽmė OPr. semmē and perhaps OCS zemlja. Further related to Skt. kṣám- Gr. χθών Hitt. tēkan a.o. Originally a root noun which has been transferred to the ē-stem class in Baltic. | ALEW s.v. jáunas & žẽmė; Derksen 2015, 209 s.v. jaunas; 2015, 516 s.v. žemė; LEW 190 s.v. jáunas; 1299 s.v. žẽmė; ME 2, 101 s.v. jaûns; 2, 103 s.v. jaûnzemis; 4, 708; SEJL 420 s.v. jáunas; 1620 s.v. žẽmė.

Primary element is TN Ziediņi, nom.pl. of ziêdiņš, D to ziêds 'blossom.' inis-derivation to ziêds 'blossom,' cf. Lt. žiedìnis 'having a blossom' to žíedas 'blossom; ring.' Derived from Lv. ziêdêt 'blossom' Lt. žíedėti 'grow hard.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Žiẽdelis (LPDB) HG Blumke (DFD). | ALEW s.v. žíedas1 & žíedas2; Derksen 2015, 518 s.v. žiedas; LEW 1305 s.v. žydė́ti 2; ME 4, 739 s.v. I ziêds; SEJL 1627 s.v. žíedas.
Lv kàlis 'cabbage' from Germanic (ME 2, 191) or kâlis (ME 1, 191) to kā̀ls 'ein Band od. Ein halbes Schock, d. i., 30 Stück' from Liv kā̊l (ME 2, 191) + Lv kal̂ns 'mountain' inherited (ME 2, 143)

nom.pl. of kaļ̃ķis 'limestone, chalk; lime pipe; (pl.) quicklime.' Also a FN (LUV), probably in the sense of a limeburner, cf. Lt. Kálkis (LPDB) Po. Kalka (ISNP) HG Kalk (DFD). | Borrowed from HG Kalk or MLG kalk 'chalk,' cf. also Lt. kálkis Po. kalka. | ME 2, 147.

nom.pl. of kaļ̃ķis 'limestone, chalk; lime pipe; (pl.) quicklime.' Also a FN (LUV), probably in the sense of a limeburner, cf. Lt. Kálkis (LPDB) Po. Kalka (ISNP) HG Kalk (DFD). | Borrowed from HG Kalk or MLG kalk 'chalk,' cf. also Lt. kálkis Po. kalka. | ME 2, 147.

nom.pl. of kaļ̃ķis 'limestone, chalk; lime pipe; (pl.) quicklime.' Also a FN (LUV), probably in the sense of a limeburner, cf. Lt. Kálkis (LPDB) Po. Kalka (ISNP) HG Kalk (DFD). | Borrowed from HG Kalk or MLG kalk 'chalk,' cf. also Lt. kálkis Po. kalka. | ME 2, 147.

nom.-acc.pl. of palma 'palm tree.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Palmas (LPDB) Po. Palma (ISNP), HG Palm (DFD). | Borrowed from Lat. palma, perhaps via HG Palme 'id.' or Palm 'consecrated palm' or MLG palm(e) 'palm tree; consecrated palm; willow; sallow,' cf. also Lt. pálmė Po. palma. | AK.

nom.pl. of kaļ̃ķis 'limestone, chalk; lime pipe; (pl.) quicklime.' Also a FN (LUV), probably in the sense of a limeburner, cf. Lt. Kálkis (LPDB) Po. Kalka (ISNP) HG Kalk (DFD). | Borrowed from HG Kalk or MLG kalk 'chalk,' cf. also Lt. kálkis Po. kalka. | ME 2, 147.

nom.sg. of kaļķukruogs 'Kaļķises' inn' or 'Kaļķi inn.' | Compound of gen.pl. of FN Kaļķis or top. pl.tant. Kaļķi and kruõgs 'pub, inn.' The first element is kaļ̃ķis 'limestone, chalk; lime pipe; (pl.) quicklime' (ME 2, 147) ← HG Kalk or MLG kalk 'chalk,' cf. also Lt. kálkis Po. kalka. As a FN (LUV) probably in the sense of a limeburner, cf. also Lt. Kálkis (LPDB) Po. Kalka (ISNP) HG Kalk (DFD). kruõgs is borrowed from MLG krōch (ME 2, 294). | AK.
nom.sg. of Kalke Krug 'Kaļķises' inn' or 'Kaļķi inn.' | Rendition of Lv. kaļkukruogs. | AK.
lv kal̂ns 'mountain' inherited (ME 2, 143) + aũša 'chatterbox, windbag, scatterbrain' (ME 1, 230)
lv kal̂ns 'mountain' inherited (ME 2, 143) + aũša 'chatterbox, windbag, scatterbrain' (ME 1, 230)
nom.-acc.pl. of kal̃me 'sweet flag (acorus calamus).' Also a FN (LUV). | Borrowed from Gr. κᾰ́λᾰμος 'reed' via HG Kalmus, cf. also Lt. kal̃mės Est. kalmus. | ME 2, 142.

kal̂na àuzāni 'Upper Àuzāni.' nom.pl. of àuzāns. Only attested as TN and FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Avižė́nas (LPDB) Po. Owsiak (ISNP) HG Hafermann (DFD). | ānas-derivation (or ȩ̄nas-) to àuza '(usually pl.) oats,' probably in the sense 'oats farmer.' àuza is cognate with Lt. avižà and perhaps OPr. wyse (if contaminated with wisge 'id.,' cf. Lt vìzgė 'oatgrass, false oats'). | ALEW s.v. avižà; Derksen 2015, 74 s.v. aviža; LEW 28 s.v. avižà; LVV 1, 58 s.v. aûzas2; ME 1, 231 s.v. ; SEJL 74.

kal̂na bajãri 'Upper Bajāri.' Syntagm of gen.sg. of kal̂ns 'hill, mountain' and nom.pl. of bajãrs 'rich person.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Bajõras (LPDB) Po. Bojar (ISNP). | Borrowed from ESl. *bojarъ, cf. ORu. bojarinъ BRu. bajáryn. Similarly Lt. bajõras 'boyar, nobleman.' Ultimately from Turkic. | ALEW s.v. bajõras; LEW 30; LVV 1, 76; ME 1, 252; REW 1, 114 s.v. боя́рин; SEJL 81; Skok 1, 186 s.v. bòljarin.

kal̂na bẽrziņi 'Upper Bẽrziņi.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of kal̂ns 'hill, mountain' and TN Bẽrziņi. Primary element is TN Bẽrziņi, nom.pl. of bẽrziņš, D to bȩ̃rzs 'birch.' inis-derivation originally in the sense 'birchen' to bȩ̃rzs 'birch,' cf. Lt. beržìnis 'birchen; birch stick' Ukr. bérezenь 'March' Po. brzezień 'id.' Lv. bȩ̃rzs finds exact correspondences in Lt. béržas, OPr. berse, SCr. brȅz and Sln. brẹ̀z. These point to an o-stem *bherHǵ-o-, which, along with Skt. bhūrjá- 'id.,' is probably derived from an ablauting root noun *bherHǵ-~*bhrHǵ- 'shine.' Slavic and Germanic mostly attest ā-stems, cf. Ru. berëza, Po. brzoza, OCS brěza, ON bjǫrk, OE beorc a.o. Still other cognates are Lat. fraxinus 'ash' Alb. bredh 'birch' as well as adj. Bu. brjaz and Alb. bardhë 'whitish, pale, spotted.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Beržìnis (LPDB) Po. Brzozowy (ISNP). | ALEW s.v. béržas; Derksen 2015, 88 s.v. beržas; Kroonen 2013, 61 s.v. *berkō-; LEW, 40 s.v. béržas; ME 1, 292 s.v. bȩ̃rzs; SEJL, 106 s.v. béržas.
kal̂na dā̀rzupītes 'Upper Dārzupītes.' Nom.-acc.pl. of dā̀rzupīte 'garden stream.' | Compound of dā̀rzs 'garden' and D to upe 'river.' | AK.

pl.tant. TN Kal̂na Dzeņi 'Upper Dzeņi.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of kal̂ns 'hill, mountain' and TN Dzeņi. Primary element is TN Dzeņi, nom.pl. of dzenis 'woodpecker.' Cognate with Lt. genỹs and -genis in OPr. aytegenis 'lesser spotted woodpecker,' cf. also OPr. genix 'woodpecker.' Derived from Lv. dzenêt Lt. genė́ti 'prune,' itself to Lv. dzìt Lt. giñti 'drive.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Genỹs (LPDB) Po. Dzięcioł (ISNP) HG Specht (DFD). | ALEW s.v. genỹs; Derksen 2015, 171; Karulis 2001, 248; LEW 152 s.v. giñti; ME 1, 545 s.v. I dzenis; PKEŽ 1 58 s.v. aytegenis; 1, 349 s.v. genix; SEJL 314 s.v. genỹs II.
_alternative etymology: to dzenis 'piece of wood between plow shoe teeth' (ME 1, 545 s.v. II dzenis); to dzenis 'coachman' (ME 1, 545 s.v. III dzenis); to dzenis 'climbing rope' (ME 1, 545 s.v. IV dzenis).

_etymology: pl.tant. TN Kal̂na Dziñtari 'Upper Dzintari.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of kal̂ns 'hill, mountain' and TN Dziñtari. Primary element is TN Dziñtari, nom.pl. of dziñtars 'amber.' Curonianism, doublet of dzĩtars and cognate with Lt. gintãras. Further related to Ru. jantár' etc. Unclear origin. Also a PN and a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Giñtaras (LPDB) Po. Burszta (ISNP). | ALEW s.v. giñtaras; Karulis 2001, 254; LEW 152; ME 1, 552 s.v. dziñtars; 1, 559 s.v. dzĩtars; SEJL 328.

_comment: possible match with E 1925 in grāveri 1.
_etymology: pl.tant. TN Kal̂na Grãveri 'Upper Grāveri.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of kal̂ns 'mountain' and TN Grãveri. Primary element is TN Grãveri, nom.pl. of grãveris 'digger' (ME 1, 644). Also a FN (LUV). | Borrowed from MLG grāver. | AK.

TN Kal̂na Kaijas 'Upper Kaijas.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of kal̂ns 'hill, mountain' and TN Kaijas. Primary element is TN Kaijas, nom.-acc.pl. of kaĩja 'gull.' Onomatopoeic, cf. Fi. kaija 'gull' Ru. čájka 'id.' Also a FN (LUV). | Wiktionary s.v. Lv. kaija.
_alternative etymology: borrowed from Fi. kaija 'gull' or its Estonian or Livonian counterpart (ME 2, 132).

_etymology: TN Kal̂na Kaijas 'Upper Kaijas.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of kal̂ns 'hill, mountain' and TN Kaijas. Primary element is TN Kaijas, nom.-acc.pl. of kaĩja 'gull.' Onomatopoeic, cf. Fi. kaija 'gull' Ru. čájka 'id.' Also a FN (LUV). | Wiktionary s.v. Lv. kaija.
_alternative etymology: borrowed from Fi. kaija 'gull' or its Estonian or Livonian counterpart (ME 2, 132).

_etymology: nom.sg. kal̂na muĩža 'mountain estate.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of kal̂ns 'mountain' and muĩža 'estate.' Primary element is kal̂ns 'mountain,' cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Kálnas (LPDB) Po. Góra (ISNP) HG Berg (DFD). | ALEW 509; Derksen 2015, 221; LEW, 209; ME 2, 143; Smoczyński 2016, 451.
kal̂na peļņi 'upper peļņi.' Also a FN, cf. Pelnis (LUV). | pl.tant. peļņi 'salary, wage, gain.' (ii̯)o-stem V of pèļņa. Derived from pèlnît 'earn.' | ME 3, 198 s.v. pèļņa.
_alternative etymology: nom.pl. of pelnis 'day laborer,' ii̯o-derivation to peln- 'earn,' cf. also peļņenieks.

_etymology: TN Kal̂na Pìlādži 'Upper Pìlādži.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of kal̂ns 'hill, mountain' and TN Pìlādži. Primary element is TN Pìlādži, nom.pl. of pìlādzis 'rowan' ← Liv. pīlag. Also a FN (LUV). | ME 3, 231.

pl.tant. TN Kalna ziedi 'Upper Ziedi.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of kal̂ns and TN Ziêdi. Primary element is TN Ziêdi which is the nom.pl. of ziêds 'blossom.' Cognate with Lt. žíedas 'blossom; ring.' Derived from Lv. ziêdêt 'blossom' Lt. žíedėti 'grow hard.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Žíedas (LPDB) HG Blume (DFD). | ALEW s.v. žíedas1 & žíedas2; Derksen 2015, 518; LEW 1305 s.v. žydė́ti 2; ME 4, 739 s.v. I ziêds; SEJL 1627.

kal̂nabutȩ̃ni 'Upper Butēni.' Also a FN, cf. Butāns (LUV) and also Lt. Butė́nas (LPDB). | Nom.pl. of butȩ̃ns 'landlord' vel sim., ēna-derivation to buts 'house' ← Lt. bùtas. | EH 1, 256; LVV 1, 149 s.v. buta-.
_alternative etymology: borrowed from Lt. FN Butė́nas; to Lt. PN Bùtas (LVV 1, 149).

_etymology: nom.sg. kal̂nakruõgs 'hill inn.' | Compound of kal̂ns 'mountain' and kruõgs 'pub, inn.' Primary element is kal̂ns 'mountain,' cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o.
