nom.sg. Kalne Krug. | Syntagm of TN Kalne and Krug 'inn.' Primary element is Kalne, a rendition of Lv. kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' Cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Kálnas (LPDB) Po. Góra (ISNP) HG Berg (DFD). | ALEW 509; Derksen 2015, 221; LEW, 209; ME 2, 143; Smoczyński 2016, 451.
nom.pl. of kal̂nalauciņš 'hill glades' vel sim. | Syntagm of gen.sg. of kal̂ns 'hill, mountain' and D to laũks 'glade; open space; acre; field, domain.' | AK.
_alternative etymology: laũciņš in the sense 'peasant' (Lt. laukìnis); lauks 'overseer' (ME 2, 427 s.v. II lauks); làuks 'pale' (ME 2, 427 s.v. III làuks); lauks 'pale spot' (ME 2, 427 s.v. IV lauks).

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of kal̂naleja 'hill valley.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of kal̂ns 'hill, mountain' and leja 'valley; servants' quarters.' | AK.
kal̂namajuõri 'Upper Majori.' Nom.pl. of majuõrs 'major.' Also a FN (LUV). | Borrowed from HG Major. Ultimately from Lat. maior 'bigger.' | AK.

kal̂namuĩžȩ̃ni 'Upper Muižēni.' Nom.pl. of muĩžȩ̃ns 'estate (land) inhabitant.' | ȩ̄na-derivation to muĩža 'estate' ← Liv. mo͕ì̯zə̑, perhaps via Ru. mýza, cf. also muĩžgaliẽtis (ME 2, 662). | AK.
kal̂na muĩžiņas 'Upper Muižiņas.' Nom.-acc.pl. of D to muĩža 'estate.' Also a FN, cf. LUV s.v. Muiža. | Borrowed from Liv. mo͕ì̯zə̑, perhaps via Ru. mýza. | ME 2, 662.

kal̂nañcīši 'Upper Ancīši.' Compound of kal̂ns 'hill, mountain' and FN Ancītis 'Johns' (LUV). | ītii̯o-derivation to PN Añcis ← HG Hans, short form of Johannes 'John.' Ultimately from BHe. Yōḥānān < YHVH khanún 'God is gracious' though borrowed via Gr. Ἰωάννης and Lat. Iōhannēs. | LPV 56; LVV 1, 27 s.v. añce; ME 1, 71 s.v. Añcis.
_alternative etymology: ancĩši 'agrimony, sticklewort (agrimonia eupatoria)' (ultimately same origin; ME 1, 71).

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of kal̂nâre 'hill field.' Also a FN (LUV). | Compound of kal̂ns 'mountain, hill' and âre 'the open; field; outside.' First element is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' Second element is cognate with Lt. orė̃ 'ploughing; ploughed field.' Thus originally VN in the sense 'ploughing' to *arˀ- 'plough,' cf. mõlė~molė̃ ‘grinding’ to málti ‘grind’ (Skardžius 1943, 71). The mobile V is semelfactive and may have acquired the meaning 'ploughed field' although contamination with Lv. ârs~âra 'the open; field; outside' (Lt. óras 'air; weather') must be assumed, too, due to the other meanings of âre. | ALEW s.v. kálnas & óras; Derksen 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; 2015, 340 s.v. oras; LEW, 209 s.v. kálnas; 518 s.v. óras; LVV 1, 69 s.v. ârabirži; ME 1, 239 s.v. âra; 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; SEJL 451 s.v. kálnas; 834 s.v. orė̃.

nom.pl. of kal̂niņš, D to kal̂ns 'mountain.' Also a surname (LUV) in the sense 'mountain dweller,' cf. Lt. Kálninis (LPDB) Po. Górak (ISNP) HG Berger (DFD). | iņš-derivation to kal̂ns 'mountain,' originally in a purely associative sense, cf. Lt. kalnìnis 'mountain-; mountain dweller.' kal̂ns is a no-derivation to PIE *kel- 'rise,' cf. also Lt. kálnas. Perhaps an athematic n-stem is reconstructible, cf. Gr. κολωνός 'hill' Lat. collis 'id.' OE hyll 'id.' a.o. In this case the form might have been thematicized in East Baltic. | ALEW s.v. kálnas; Derksen 2015, 221; LEW 209; ME 2, 143; SEJL 451.

_comment: slightly outside the expected area according to georeferencing of WRK in kartes.lndb.lv.
_etymology: nom.pl. of mazkal̂niņš. Semantically either diminutive ('little low mountain') or associative ('low mountain-dweller; young mountain dweller'). Infrequent as a common noun but exists as a surname (LUV), probably in the sense 'young Kalniņš,' cf. also HG Kleinkurt Jungkurt (DFD). Kalniņš (LUV) as a surname probably refers to a 'mountain dweller,' cf. Lt. Kálninis (LPDB) Po. Górak (ISNP) HG Berger (DFD). | Either an iņš-derivation to a compound of mazs 'small, little' and kal̂ns 'mountain' or a compound of mazs 'little, small' and kal̂niņš, iņš-derivation to kal̂ns 'mountain.' | AK.

syntagm of gen.pl. of surname Kal̂niņš and nom.pl. of surname Andrãns 'Andrews,' i.e., 'Kalniņš-Andrewses.' As a surname Kalniņš (LUV) probably refers to a 'mountain dweller,' cf. Lt. Kálninis (LPDB) Po. Górak (ISNP) HG Berger (DFD). Andrāns (LUV) only exists as a patronymic surname, cf. Lt. Andrejáitis (LPDB) Po. Andrzejak (ISNP) HG Andreasen (DFD) Eng. Andrews. | Kalniņš is an iņš-derivation to kal̂ns 'mountain.' Andrãns is dial. for Añdrȩ̃ns, ȩ̄ns-derivation to pers. name Andris, hypocorism of Andrejs 'Andrew' ← Ru. or BRu. Andréj or Po. Andrzej. Ultimately from Gr. Ἀνδρέᾱς 'manly (vel sim.),' derived from ἀνήρ 'man.' | LPV 57 s.v. Andris; LVV 1, 29 s.v. mazañdris; ME 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns.
kal̂niņu dreĩmaņi 'Dreimaņi in the hills.' Nom.pl. of dreĩmanis 'wood turner.' Also a FN (LUV). | Borrowed from MLG *dreiman vel sim., cf. also Est. treiman. | ME 1, 497.

Ἀδάμ. | LVV 1, 4 s.v. adama-muiža; LPV 40 s.v. Ādams.

nom.-acc.pl. of krastmala 'bank' (ME 2, 260). | Compound of krasts 'bank' and mala 'edge.' First element is cognate with Lt. krãštas 'edge; bank' and might belong to Lt. krešė́ti 'grow firm.' Second element is cognate with ON mǫl 'gravel; stone embankment' Alb. mal 'mountain' a.o. | ALEW s.v. krãštas; LEW 289 s.v. krãštas; ME 2, 260 s.v. krasts; 2, 555 s.v. I mala; SEJL 561 s.v. krãštas.
_alternative etymology: Lv. mala might also be borrowed from ON mǫl or Sw. dial. mal, cf. also Orc. muller 'stony beach' a.o. (de Vries 1977, 401).

_etymology: nom.sg. kràuja 'steep bank.' Also a FN (LUV). | Possibly a substantivization of adj. kràujš 'steep,' cf. dial. o-stem kràujš 'steep bank.' Probably related to Lt kriaũšis a.o. 'steep bank' a.o. which seems to belong to Lt krùšti 'mash, crush.' Compared on the other hand also to Lv kŗaũt~kraũt 'gather' and krūtiês 'fall' although the relationship remains obscure. | ALEW s.v. kriaũšas; LEW 296 s.v. kriaũšis; ME 2, 262 s.v. III kràuja; SEJL 571 s.v. kriaũšas.

Kraukle looks like a le-derivation to kŗaukt 'cough, croak, caw' or an e-derivation to kraûklis 'raven; toad.' Either way the sense is probably 'toad place.' Pace Šmits (apud Blese 1938, 132) the sustained tone in àizkraũkle might not preclude association with kraûklis 'raven; toad' since we also find dial. kraũklis. LVV 1, 9; ME 2, 263 s.v. kraûklis; 2, 295 s.v. kŗaukt.
Lv kraûklis 'raven (corvus corax); toad (bufo cinereus)' to kŗaukt (ME 2, 263)

nom.sg. laĩmkal̂ne 'fortune hill.' | Compound of laĩme 'fortune' and compositional V of kal̂ns 'hill, mountain.' laĩme is cognate with Lt. láimė and further related to OPr. laeims 'rich.' Perhaps to the root in Lv. laîst 'let, allow.' Also a FN (LUV). kal̂ns is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Kálnas (LPDB) Po. Góra (ISNP) HG Berg (DFD). | ALEW s.v. kálnas & laĩmas; Derksen 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; 2015, 269 s.v. laimė; LEW 209 s.v. kálnas; 333 s.v. láimė; ME 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; 2, 407 s.v. laĩma; SEJL 451 s.v. kálnas; 621 s.v. láimė.

Perhaps to the root in Lv. laîst 'let, allow.' Also a FN (LUV). ziêds is ognate with Lt. žíedas 'blossom; ring.' Derived from Lv. ziêdêt 'blossom' Lt. žíedėti 'grow hard.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Žíedas (LPDB) HG Blume (DFD). | ALEW s.v. laĩmas žíedas1 & žíedas2; Derksen 2015, 269 s.v. laimė; 2015, 518 s.v. žiedas; LEW 333 s.v. láimė; 1305 s.v. žydė́ti 2; ME 2, 407 s.v. laĩma; 4, 739 s.v. pl.tant. laũkâres 'fallow land.' | Compound of laũks 'field; open space; countryside' and âre 'the open; field; outside.' laũks is cognate with Lt. laũkas OPr. laucks Skt. lōkáḥ 'open space' OHG lōh 'low bushes' Lat. lūcus 'grove' a.o. Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Laukas (LPDB) Po. Niwa (ISNP) HG Feld (DFD). âre is cognate with Lt. orė̃ 'ploughing; ploughed field.' Thus originally VN in the sense 'ploughing' to *arˀ- 'plough,' cf. mõlė~molė̃ ‘grinding’ to málti ‘grind’ (Skardžius 1943, 71). nom.sg. Lazdukalnu upīte 'Lazdukalni stream.' | Syntagm of gen. of TN Lazdukalni and upīte, D to upe 'river, stream.' First element is cognate with Lt. lazdà and OPr. laxde and perhaps further related to SCr. lijéska 'id.' Alb. lajthi 'id.' Skt. vleṣka- 'sling' a.o. nom.sg. Rîtiņu upīte 'Rītiņi stream.' | Syntagm of gen. of TN Rîtiņi and upīte, D to upe 'river, stream.' Lv. rîts is cognate with Lt. rýtas and perhaps further related to Skt. rītiḥ 'current; haste' Lat. rīvus 'brook' a.o. Also a FN (LUV). | ALEW s.v. rýtas; LEW 738 s.v. rýtas; ME 3, 541 s.v. rîts; SEJL 1035 s.v. rýtas.

nom.pl. of Jãnītis, D to PN Jãnis 'John; (pl.) Midsummer Day.' Rare as a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Jõnas (LPDB) Po. Iwan (ISNP) HG Johannes (DFD). | Ultimately from BHe. Yōḥānān < YHVH khanún 'God is gracious,' borrowed via Gr. Ἰωάννης, Lat. Iōhannēs and probably MLG Johannes. | ME 2, 106.

_etymology: nom.pl. of lèinȩ̃ns 'knock-kneed person, bowlegged person.' | ēna-derivation to lèins 'bowlegged.' For semantics cf. lèinis. | ME 2, 446 s.v. lèinis I lèins.

nom.pl. of leĩšjãnis 'Lithuanian John.' | Compound of leĩtis 'Lithuanian; ' and Jãnis 'John.' First element is a Curonianism, related to or borrowed from Lt. proper name Léitis, cf. also HN Leĩtė. Second element is ultimately from BHe. Yōḥānān < YHVH khanún 'God is gracious' borrowed via Gr. Ἰωάννης, Lat. Iōhannēs and probably MLG Johannes. | EH 1, 731; LVV 2, 292; ME 2, 106 s.v. Jãnis; 2, 447 s.v. leĩtis.
_alternative etymology: First element might be to leja 'valley' (ME 2, 447).

PN Léitis, cf. also HN Leĩtė. Also a FN (LUV). upe 'river, stream' is cognate with Lt. ùpė and further related to OPr. wupyan 'cloud' and ape 'stream' as well as Skt. ā̆p- and TB āp 'water' a.o. _etymology: pl.tant. lejas bajãri 'Lower Bajāri.' Syntagm of gen.sg. of leja 'valley' and nom.pl. of bajãrs 'rich person.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Bajõras (LPDB) Po. Bojar (ISNP). | Borrowed from ESl. *bojarъ, cf. ORu. bojarinъ BRu. bajáryn. Similarly Lt. bajõras 'boyar, nobleman.' Ultimately from Turkic. | ALEW s.v. bajõras; LEW 30; LVV 1, 76; ME 1, 252; REW 1, 114 s.v. боя́рин; SEJL 81; Skok 1, 186 s.v. bòljarin.

lejas bogdāni 'Lower Bogdāni.' Nom.pl. of FN Bogdāns 'Bogdan' (LUV), cf. also PN Bogdans (LPV 85). | Borrowed from Ru. PN Bogdán or Po. Bogdan. Compound of bog 'God' and dan 'given,' possibly a calque of Gr. PN Θεόδοτος. | LPV 85 s.v. Bogdans.

nom.pl. of TN Lejas Jȩ̃rāni 'Lower Jȩ̃rāni.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of leja 'valley' and TN Jȩ̃rāni. Primary element is TN Jȩ̃rāni, nom.pl. of FN Jȩ̃rāns (LUV). āns-derivation originally in a purely associative sense to jȩ̃rs 'lamb' which is cognate with Lt. ė́ras 'id.' OCS jěrъ 'spring' Go. jēr 'year' ON ár 'id.' and further related to OPr. eristian 'lamb' Av. yārə 'year' Gr. ὤρα 'id.' a.o. The original r/n-stem has been thematicized in BS and Germanic. | Derksen 2015, 154 s.v. ėras; Kroonen 2013, 273 s.v. *jēra-; LEW 121 s.v. ė́ras; ME 2, 114 s.v. jȩ̃rs; SEJL 425 s.v. jė́ras.

TN Lejas kaijas 'Lower Kaijas.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of leja 'valley' and TN Kaijas, nom.-acc.pl. of kaĩja 'gull.' Onomatopoeic, cf. Fi. kaija 'gull' Ru. čájka 'id.' Also a FN (LUV). | Wiktionary s.v. Lv. kaija.
_alternative etymology: kaija borrowed from Fi. kaija 'gull' or its Estonian or Livonian counterpart (ME 2, 132).

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of kaĩja 'gull.' Also a FN (LUV). | Onomatopoeic, cf. Fi. kaija 'gull' Ru. čájka 'id.' | Wiktionary s.v. Lv. kaija.

pl.tant. lejas ķivuti 'Lower Ķivuti.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of leja 'valley' and nom.pl. of ķivutis of unclear meaning. Primary element is ķivutis ← Liv. ki'v or Est. kivi 'stone,' perhaps based on nom.pl. (Liv. kivīd Est. kivid) or with addition of Baltic suffix -utis. | LVV 2, 229 s.v. ķivuti.
_alternative etymology: ķivuti might also be onomatopoeic, cf. Lt. kivit 'tweet' (LKŽ).

_etymology: nom.pl. of FN Plāters 'Plater' (LUV), cf. also Lt. Plateris Po. Plater HG Plater (LPDB s.v. Pliateris). | Borrowed from HG FN Plater. Unclear etymology. | LPDB s.v. Pliateris.
nom.pl. of FN Plāters 'Plater' (LUV), cf. also Lt. Plateris Po. Plater HG Plater (LPDB s.v. Pliateris). | Borrowed from HG FN Plater. Unclear etymology. | LPDB s.v. Pliateris.
dial. for pulpȩ̃ns 'noisemaker.' | ēna-derivation to a cognate to Lt. pulpti 'be noisy,' cf. also Lv. pulpinât 'crake (of quail).' | AK.

nom.pl. of D to spìets2 'swarm of bees; bee colony.' | Related to spiêst2 'swarm' a.o. Semantics of the inii̯o-derivation could be 'beekeeper' or 'basket for gathering bees.' cf. Lt. spietýnas 'basket for gathering bees; swarm.' | EH 2, 555; ME 3, 1006.

nom.pl. of uôsis 'ash (fraxinus excelsior).' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Úosis (LPDB) Po. Potok (ISNP) HG Bach (DFD). | ALEW s.v. ùpė; Derksen 2015, 483 s.v. upė; Karulis 2001, 518 s.v. līcis; LEW 356 s.v. leñkti; 1169 s.v. ùpė; ME 2, 476 s.v. lìcis; 4, 300 s.v. upe; PKEŽ 1, 86 s.v. ape; SEJL 1468 s.v. ùpė.

liẽlā indrica 'Great Indrica.' nom.sg. liẽlāmuĩža 'large estate.' | Compound of liẽls 'large' and muĩža 'estate.' Rare as a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Dìdelis (LPDB) Po. Wielk (ISNP) HG Groß (DFD). | LEW 329 s.v. láibas; ME 2, 500; SEJL 642 s.v. leĩlas.

Rare as a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Dìdelis (LPDB) Po. Wielk (ISNP) HG Groß (DFD). | LEW 329 s.v. láibas; ME 2, 500; SEJL 642 s.v. leĩlas.

lenevard 'landing watchtower.' | Borrowed from MLG or HG Lenneward(en). Ultimately from ON lendavarða, compound of lenda 'land, go ashore' and varða 'watchtower.' | Karulis 1989, 337, 341 apud Balode & Bušs 2015, 142-143.
_alternative etymology: from Lv., first element is Lv. lêne 'lawn on the shore under which land has been washed away' or lēnains 'marshy' (Balode & Bušs 2015, 143); from Balto-Finnic, second element is cognate with Est. TN/FN Vardi or Vardja (Alvre apud Karma 1994, 154).

_alternative etymology: compound of liẽls 'large' and vā̀rds 'word' (Biel 44); from liẽlvāda 'great floodwater' with inserted r due to folk etymology (Endzelīns apud Balode & Bušs 2015, 141-142 LVV 2 334, ME 2 460 4 492); first element is Lv. lêne 'lawn on the shore under which land has been washed away' or lēnains 'marshy' (Balode & Bušs 2015, 143); second element is cognate with Est. TN/FN Vardi or Vardja (Alvre apud Karma 1994, 154).

_etymology: liẽlvā̀rdes mâcītāja muĩža 'lielvārde clergy house.' Also a FN, cf. Lielvārde (LUV). | Compound of liẽls 'great' and vā̀rds 'word; name.' Folk etymology of a borrowed V of ON lendavarða, compound of lenda 'land, go ashore' and varða 'watchtower.' | Karulis 1989, 337, 341 apud Balode & Bušs 2015, 142-143.
_alternative etymology: compound of liẽls 'large' and vā̀rds 'word' (Biel 44); from liẽlvāda 'great floodwater' with inserted r due to folk etymology (Endzelīns apud Balode & Bušs 2015, 141-142 LVV 2 334, ME 2 460 4 492); first element is Lv. lêne 'lawn on the shore under which land has been washed away' or lēnains 'marshy' (Balode & Bušs 2015, 143); second element is cognate with Est. TN/FN Vardi or Vardja (Alvre apud Karma 1994, 154).

_etymology: nom.pl. of liẽpkal̂ns 'linden hill.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also HG Lind(en)berg (DFD). | Compound of liẽpa 'lime tree, linden' and kal̂ns 'mountain.' First element is cognate with Lt. líepa Ru. lípa Po. lipa SCr lȉpa a.o. Second element is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' | ALEW s.v. kálnas & líepa; Derksen 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; LEW 209 s.v. kálnas; 366 s.v. líepa; ME 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; 2, 503 s.v. liẽpa; SEJL 451 s.v. kálnas; 658 s.v. líepa.

nom.pl. of liẽpkrasts 'linden bank.' | Compound of liẽpa 'lime tree, linden' and krasts 'bank.' First element is cognate with Lt. líepa Ru. lípa Po. lipa SCr lȉpa a.o. Second element is cognate with Lt. krãštas 'edge; bank.' Might belong to Lt. krešė́ti 'grow firm.' | ALEW s.v. krãštas & líepa; LEW 289 s.v. krãštas; 366 s.v. líepa; ME 2, 260 s.v. krasts; 2, 503 s.v. liẽpa; SEJL 561 s.v. krãštas; 658 s.v. líepa.

nom.-acc.pl. of liẽpleja 'linden valley.' | Compound of liẽpa 'lime tree, linden' and leja 'valley; servants' quarters.' First element is cognate with Lt. líepa Ru. lípa Po. lipa SCr lȉpa a.o. Second element is of unclear etymology, perhaps related to Go. undarleija 'smallest' Gr. λειμών 'meadow' OIr. lian 'id.' | ALEW s.v. líepa; Karulis 2001, 512; LEW 366 s.v. líepa; ME 2, 447 s.v. I leja; 2, 503 s.v. liẽpa; SEJL 658 s.v. líepa.

nom.sg. liẽpsalniẽks 'linden grove dweller.' | niẽkas-derivation to liẽpsala 'linden grove,' itself a compound of liẽpa 'lime tree, linden' and sala 'island; hillock in marsh; grove.' liẽpa is cognate with Lt. líepa Ru. lípa Po. lipa SCr lȉpa a.o. sala is cognate with Lt. salà and perhaps further related to Lt. sálti 'flow' and OPr. salus 'rainwater creek.' If so, then sala might be shortened from *ap(i)sala, a parallel to Po. ostrów SCr. òtok. | ALEW s.v. líepa; Derksen 2015, 387 s.v. sala; LEW 366 s.v. líepa; 758 s.v. salà; ME 2, 503 s.v. liẽpa; 3, 664 s.v. I sala; PKEŽ 4, 55 s.v. salus; SEJL 658 s.v. líepa; 1059 s.v. salà.

nom.pl. of liẽpstars 'linden branch.' | Compound of liẽpa 'lime tree, linden' and stars 'beam; branch.' liẽpa is cognate with Lt. líepa Ru. lípa Po. lipa SCr lȉpa a.o. stars is cognate with -storъ in Sl. prostorъ 'extension' Skt. staraḥ 'layer' a.o. | ALEW s.v. líepa; LEW 366 s.v. líepa; ME 2, 503 s.v. liẽpa; 3, 1045 s.v. stara; SEJL 658 s.v. líepa.

pl.tant. liẽpu mãjas 'linden home.' | Syntagm of gen.pl. of liẽpa 'lime tree, linden' and nom.-acc.pl. of mãja 'house; (pl.) home.' liẽpa is cognate with Lt. líepa Ru. lípa Po. lipa SCr lȉpa a.o. Dàugavas muĩža 'Daugava estate.' Syntagm of gen. sg. of HN Dàugava and muĩža 'estate.' Also a FN, cf. LUV s.v. Daugava. | ava-derivation to *daug- 'much' as seen in Lv. daũdz Lt. daũg 'much.' _etymology: nom.sg. jaunā muiža 'new estate.' | Syntagm of nom.sg.fem.def. of jaûns 'new' and muĩža 'estate.' Primary element is jaûns, cognate with Lt. jáunas OCS junъ and further related to Skt. yuvan- Lat. juvenis We. iau Go. juggs. Originally a derivation with Hoffmann suffix which has been thematicized in BS. | ALEW s.v. jáunas; Derksen 2015, 209; LEW 190; ME 2, 101; SEJL 420.
nom.sg. of TN lĩve. | Derived from FN Līvens (LUV) ← HG or MLG FN (von) Lieven, itself from Liv. līvə̂(z) 'Livonian,' cf. also Lv. lĩvis (ME 2, 491 s.v. I lĩvis). | NE s.v. Daugmale.

nom.sg. vȩcâ lĩves muĩža 'old Līve estate.' | Syntagm of nom.sg.fem.def. of vȩcs 'old' and gen.sg. of TN lĩve and muĩža 'estate.' Primary element is lĩve which is derived from FN Līvens (LUV) ← HG or MLG FN (von) Lieven, itself from Liv. līvə̂(z) 'Livonian,' cf. also Lv. lĩvis (ME 2, 491 s.v. I lĩvis). | NE s.v. Daugmale.
pikstezeres muiža 'Pikstezere estate.' Gen.sg. of pikstezere 'clanking lake.' | Compound of *pikstêt 'tap, beat' (unattested cognate to Lt. pikšė́ti 'beat, tap') and ȩzȩrs 'lake.' | AK.

nom.sg. vȩclĩve 'old Līve.' | Compound of vȩcs 'old' and TN lĩve. Primary element is lĩve which is derived from FN Līvens (LUV) ← HG or MLG FN (von) Lieven, itself from Liv. līvə̂(z) 'Livonian,' cf. also Lv. lĩvis (ME 2, 491 s.v. I lĩvis). | NE s.v. Daugmale.

_source: AŠĢTD 48; E 1925, 36; LVV 2, 342 s.v. lubas; Plāķis 2, 268
_etymology: nom.pl. of an otherwise unattested lubaũsis. | Compound of luba 'linden or fir bark; long roof shingle; board' and a compositional V of àuss, cf. gaŗausis 'long-ears' a.o. (ME 1, 227). First element is cognate with Lt. lubà 'board; bark' OPr. lubbo 'board' Ru. lob 'forehead' Po. łeb 'head of an animal' a.o. and further related to Ru. lub 'bast (of tree)' Po. łub 'bark' ON laupr 'basket' a.o. The gender of the lexeme was probably neuter in PBS. Second element is cognate with Lt. ausìs OPr. acc.pl. āusins Ru. úxo Po. ucho Go. ausō OIr. au Lat. auris Av. nom.du. uši a.o. Semantics of the compound perhaps related to lubenĩca 'cap with earflaps' (ME 2, 509). | ALEW s.v. ausìs; Derksen 2015, 71 s.v. ausis; 2015, 294 s.v. luba; EH 1, 759 s.v. luba; Karulis 2001, 90 s.v. auss; 2001, 545 s.v. luba; LEW 26 s.v. ausìs; 388 s.v. lubà; ME 1, 227 s.v. àuss; 2, 509 s.v. luba; PKEŽ 1, 123 s.v. ausins; 3, 84 s.v. lubbo; SEJL 68 s.v. ausìs; 686 s.v. lùbos.

bal̃tiņu kapi 'Baltiņi cemetery.' Gen.pl. of bal̃tiņš, iņš-derivation to bal̃ts 'white.' ME gives the sense 'old white horse' but the derivation might refer to anything associated with the color white, cf. Lt. baltinỹs 'eyewhite; egg white.' Also a surname, probably referring to someone with blond hair or pale skin, cf. Lt. Báltinas (LPDB) Po. Bialik (ISNP) HG Wittke (DFD). | bal̃ts 'white' is a to-adjective to a lost cognate to Lt. bálti 'fade,' cf. also Lt. báltas. Further related to OCS blato 'swamp' and Alb. baltë f. 'id.' which are substantivizations of the neuter singular and plural, respectively. Derksen apparently suggests that the noun is older but this seems unlikely. According to Orel MGr. βάλτος f. 'swamp' and Ro. baltă 'id.' are borrowed from Alb. | ALEW s.v. báltas1; Derksen 2015, 80; LEW 30 s.v. balà; 32 s.v. bálti; LUV s.v. Baltiņš; ME 1, 257 s.v. bal̃tiņš; 1, 258 s.v. bal̃ts; Orel 1998, 15; SEJL 86.
_alternative etymology: iņš-derivation to a cognate to Ru. bolóto 'swamp' (LVV 1, 81 s.v. bòltani2)—'swamp' can be reached also if the head word is 'white' since the two are cognates, cf. ALEW s.v. báltas1; Derksen 2015, 80; LEW 30 s.v. balà; 32 s.v. bálti; ME 1, 258; SEJL 86.

nom.sg. mãlakal̂ns 'clay hill.' Also a FN (LUV). | Syntagm of gen.sg. of mãls 'clay' and kal̂ns 'hill, mountain.' mãls is cognate with Lt. mólis though it is unclear whether the o- or ii̯o-stem is older. Further related to Lv. mȩl̃ns 'black' Lt. mė́las 'blue' mùlti 'become dirty' a.o. The same root might be present also in Sl. malina 'raspberry.' kal̂ns is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' | ALEW s.v. kálnas; Derksen 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; LEW 209 s.v. kálnas; 463 s.v. mólis; ME 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; 2, 581 s.v. mãls; SEJL 451 s.v. kálnas; 771 s.v. mólis.

nom.sg. lazdukal̂na upe 'hazel hill stream.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of lazdukal̂ns 'hazel hill' and upe 'stream.' Primary element is lazdukal̂ns 'hazel hill,' a compound of lazda 'hazel' and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' Rare as FN (LUV), cf. HG Haselberger (DFD). First element is cognate with Lt. lazdà and OPr. laxde and perhaps further related to SCr. lijéska 'id.' Alb. lajthi 'id.' Skt. vleṣka- 'sling' a.o. Second element is cognate with Lt. kálnas, cf. further Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll 'id.' a.o. | ALEW s.v. kálnas and lazdà; Derksen 2015, 221 276; LEW 209 348; ME 2, 143 433; PKEŽ 3 54; SEJL 451.
_alternative etymology: lazda ← Slavic (SEJL 640); lazda rather to Sl. loza 'vine' (LEW 348; SEJL 640; PKEŽ 3 54).

_etymology: nom.pl. of D to mežs 'forest.' Cf. Lt. Medìnis (LPDB) Po. Lasek (ISNP). | Phonologically regular V of more common mežiņš which has analogical ž after the derivation base. inii̯o-derivation to mežs 'forest' which was inherited as a neuter o-stem and is cognate with Lt. mẽdžias 'tree; forest' and OPr. median 'forest.' Originally a substantivization of PIE adj. *medhi̯o- 'middle-,' cf. Ved. mádhyaḥ Av. maiδiia- Gr. μέσ(σ)ος Lat. medius Go. midjis a.o. Similarly OCS mežda 'lane, walk' Ru. mežá 'boundary; (dial.) forest' a.o. The inii̯o-derivation originally carried the sense 'wooden; forest-,' cf. Lt. medìnis. | ALEW s.v. mẽdis; Derksen 2015, 309 s.v. medžias; LEW 423 s.v. mẽdis; ME 2, 611; SEJL 727 s.v. mẽdis; 729 s.v. mẽdžias.

dial. or Latg. for D to sils 'pinewood.' Also a FN, cf. LUV s.v. Siliņš and also Lt. Šilìnis (LPDB). | inii̯o-derivation to sils 'pinewood' which is cognate with Lt. šìlas 'pinewood; heath' and OPr. sylo 'heath.' Inherited as a neuter o-stem. Perhaps further related to Gr. σκέλλω 'dry out' or Ved. śila- 'ears (of corn) left on field.' The inii̯o-derivation was originally an associative adjective, cf. Lt. šilìnis 'of the pinewoods.' | ALEW s.v. šìlas; LEW 982 s.v. šìlas; ME 3, 839 s.v. sils; SEJL 1292 s.v. šìlas.

pl.tant. Meža rasas 'Rasas in the woods.' rasas is the nom.-acc.pl. of rasa 'dew.' Also a PN and FN (LUV). | Cognate with Lt. rasà 'dew' OCS rosa 'id.' Skt. rasā́ 'moisture' a.o. and further related to Lat. rōs. | ALEW s.v. rasà; Derksen 2015, 376; LEW 699 s.v.; ME 3, 478; SEJL 1000.

nom.sg. mežâbele 'crab apple tree (malus sylvestris).' | Compound of mežs 'forest' and âbele 'apple tree.' mežs is cognate with Lt. mẽdžias and OPr. median. Inherited as a neuter o-stem but originally a substantivization of PIE adj. *medhi̯o- 'middle-,' cf. Ved. mádhyaḥ Av. maiδiia- Gr. μέσ(σ)ος Lat. medius Go. midjis a.o. Similarly OCS mežda 'lane, walk' Ru. mežá 'boundary; (dial.) forest' a.o. âbele is inherited in EB as an l-stem but transferred to the i- and ē-stems, cf. Lt. dial. C-st. gen.sg. obelès~obel̃s a.o., Lv. dial. i-f âbels, Lt. i-f obelìs. Outside EB we only find forms extended with n-suffix, cf. OPr. wobalne, OCS ablanь, OIr. aball, Lat. top. Abella. If 'apple tree' was lexicalized on the basis of oblique forms of *ábōl (vel sim.) 'apple' then EB forms seem archaic. | ALEW s.v. mẽdis & obelìs; Derksen 2015, 309 s.v. medžias; 2015, 339 s.v. obelis; LEW 423 s.v. mẽdis; 515 s.v. obelìs; ME 1, 234 s.v. âbele; 2, 609 s.v. mežâbele; 2, 611 s.v. mežs; PKEŽ 4, 259 s.v. wobalne; SEJL 727 s.v. mẽdis; 729 s.v. mẽdžias; 831 s.v. obelìs and obuolỹs.

nom.pl. of mežāks 'woodlander; wild, unkempt person.' Also a FN (LUV). | ākas-derivation to mežs 'forest.' | ME 2, 609 s.v. mežaks.
nom.-acc.pl. of mežāka 'woodlander; wild, unkempt person.' Also a FN (LUV). | ākā-derivation to mežs 'forest.' | ME 2, 609 s.v. mežaks.

nom.sg. mežamuiža 'forest estate.' mežs 'forest' is also a FN (LUV). | mežs is cognate with Lt. mẽdžias and OPr. median. Inherited as a neuter o-stem but originally a substantivization of PIE adj. *medhi̯o- 'middle-,' cf. Ved. mádhyaḥ Av. maiδiia- Gr. μέσ(σ)ος Lat. medius Go. midjis a.o. Similarly OCS mežda 'lane, walk' Ru. mežá 'boundary; (dial.) forest' a.o. | ALEW s.v. mẽdis; Derksen 2015, 309 s.v. medžias; LEW 423 s.v. mẽdis; ME 2, 611 s.v. mežs; SEJL 727 s.v. mẽdis; 729 s.v. mẽdžias.

nom.-acc.pl. of mežâre 'forest field.' Also a FN (LUV). | Compound of mežs 'forest' and âre 'the open; field; outside.' mežs 'forest' is cognate with Lt. mẽdžias and OPr. median. Inherited as a neuter o-stem but originally a substantivization of PIE adj. *medhi̯o- 'middle-,' cf. Ved. mádhyaḥ Av. maiδiia- Gr. μέσ(σ)ος Lat. medius Go. midjis a.o. Similarly OCS mežda 'lane, walk' Ru. mežá 'boundary; (dial.) forest' a.o. âre is cognate with Lt. orė̃ 'ploughing; ploughed field.' Thus originally VN in the sense 'ploughing' to *arˀ- 'plough,' cf. mõlė~molė̃ ‘grinding’ to málti ‘grind’ (Skardžius 1943, 71). The mobile V is semelfactive and may have acquired the meaning 'ploughed field' although contamination with Lv. ârs~âra 'the open; field; outside' (Lt. óras 'air; weather') must be assumed, too, due to the other meanings of âre. | ALEW s.v. mẽdis & óras; Derksen 2015, 309 s.v. medžias; 2015, 340 s.v. oras; LEW 423 s.v. mẽdis; 518 s.v. óras; LVV 1, 69 s.v. ârabirži; ME 1, 239 s.v. âra; 2, 611 s.v. mežs; SEJL 727 s.v. mẽdis; 729 s.v. mẽdžias; 834 s.v. orė̃.

nom.pl. of mežavuõts 'forest spring.' | Compound of mežs 'forest' and avuõts 'source, spring.' mežs 'forest' is cognate with Lt. mẽdžias and OPr. median. Inherited as a neuter o-stem but originally a substantivization of PIE adj. *medhi̯o- 'middle-,' cf. Ved. mádhyaḥ Av. maiδiia- Gr. μέσ(σ)ος Lat. medius Go. midjis a.o. Similarly OCS mežda 'lane, walk' Ru. mežá 'boundary; (dial.) forest' a.o. avuõts is related to Ved. avatáḥ 'well' avániḥ 'riverbed,' cf. also Lt. HN Avantà a.o. | ALEW s.v. mẽdis; Derksen 2015, 309 s.v. medžias; LEW 6 s.v. Alantà; 423 s.v. mẽdis; ME 1, 233 s.v. avuõts; 2, 611 s.v. mežs; SEJL 727 s.v. mẽdis; 729 s.v. mẽdžias.

Inherited as a neuter o-stem but originally a substantivization of PIE adj. *medhi̯o- 'middle-,' cf. Ved. mádhyaḥ Av. maiδiia- Gr. μέσ(σ)ος Lat. medius Go. midjis a.o. Similarly OCS mežda 'lane, walk' Ru. mežá 'boundary; (dial.) forest' a.o. cìems is cognate with Lt. kiẽmas 'farmhouse; courtyard' and OPr. caymis 'village.' Probably a loanword from Germanic, cf. Go. haims 'village.' | ALEW s.v. kiẽmas & mẽdis; Derksen 2015, 243 s.v. kiemas; 2015, 309 s.v. medžias; LEW 251 s.v. kiẽmas; 423 s.v. mẽdis; ME 1, 394 s.v. cìems; 2, 611 s.v. mežs; SEJL 513 s.v. kiẽmas; 727 s.v. mẽdis; 729 s.v. mẽdžias.

Lt. medìnis 'wooden; forest-' to mẽdžias 'tree; forest.' Inherited as a neuter o-stem, cf. OPr. median 'forest.' Originally a substantivization of PIE adj. *medhi̯o- 'middle-,' cf. nom.-acc.pl. of nuõra 'worn out land used as pasture; boundary balk.' Also a FN (LUV). | Cognate with Lt. núoara. Verbal noun to Lv. nùoar̂t Lt. nuárti 'plow' (ME 2, 757). | ME 2, 836.

nuotra. | Unclear meaning and etymology. Probably related to valley nuotraine (LVV 2, 487) and river nuotra (LĢIA 96411). | AK.

ruõžupīte 'rose stream.' Compound of ruõze 'rose' and D to upe 'river.' Also a FN, cf. Roze (LUV). | Borrowed from HG Rose. | ME 3, 586 s.v. I ruõze.
_alternative etymology: to ruoze 'ridge in forest or marsh' (ME 3, 585 s.v. I ruôza).

_etymology: oļšaņiks 'alder forest.' | Borrowed from Ru. ol'šánik. | AK.
oļšaņiks 'alder forest.' | Borrowed from Ru. ol'šánik. | AK.
dial. for nom.pl. of apšals 'ice, ice sheet.' | Borrowed from Lt. ãpšalas, cf. also Lv. apsala 'id.' | ME 1, 117 s.v. apsala.

dial. for asinauka 'aspen place.' | Borrowed from BRu. asinaŭka or Ru. osinovka. ovka-derivation to Ru. osína or BRu. asína 'aspen.' | AK.

nom.-acc.pl. of apse 'aspen.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Po. Osika (ISNP). | Cognate with Lt. apušė and OPr. abse and further related to Po. osa Ru. osína SCr. jàsika OHG aspa ON ǫsp a.o. The alternation *-us- : *-s- might suggest root *ap- + suffix *-us- or *-s-; or we might be dealing with suffix -ušė and dissimilatory loss of s in Lt., i.e., *aps-ušė > apušė; or the Lt. u might be otherwise secondary. Metathesis in either Germanic or Balto-Slavic is presupposed. | ALEW s.v. ãpušė; Kroonen 2013, 39; LEW 14 s.v. ãpušė; LVV 1, 38 s.v. apsa; ME 1, 118; SEJL 38 s.v. ãpušė.
osinovka 'aspen place.' | Borrowed from Ru. osinovka, ovka-derivation to osína 'aspen.' | AK.
mihnovka 'Mikhnov river.' | Borrowed from Ru. mixnóvka or its BRu. counterpart. ka-derivation to FN Mixnóv 'Mikhnov,' gen.pl. of BRu. PN Mixno 'Mike' which is a HC to Mixaíl 'Michael.' | AK.
_alternative etymology: Ru. mihnóvka or its BRu. counterpart.
_category: foreign names (aramaic and hebrew); foreign names (slavic)

_etymology: partly standardized V of palabišķu upīte 'Palabišķi stream.' | Gen.pl. of pabališķis 'swamp edge dweller' with metathesis of b and l, cf. pabališķi (E 1925, 51). iskii̯o-derivation to pabalis ← Lt. pabalỹs 'swamp edge.' | AK.
svente 'holy (river).' | ē-derivation to *svȩnts vel sim. ← Po. święty 'holy,' perhaps via Lt. šveñtas. Cf. also Lv. svȩ̀ts 'holy' ← Ru. svjat, probably via HLv. svàts vel sim. | AK.
osinovka 'aspen place.' | Borrowed from Ru. osinovka, ovka-derivation to osína 'aspen.' | AK.
nom.pl. of PN Osips 'Joseph' (LPV 256). | Ultimately from BHe. yoséf 'may he add.' Borrowed via Gr. Ἰωσήφ and Ru. Ósip. | LPV 183 s.v. Jozefs.
_category: foreign names (aramaic and hebrew); foreign names (slavic)

nom.pl. of laũmiņš 'quack.' | inii̯o-derivation to laũma 'flying sorceress; quack; earth goddess.' Related to Lt. laũmė. | ME 2, 428 s.v. I laũma.

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of D ózero 'lake.' | Cognate with OCS jezero Lt. ẽžeras Lv. ȩzȩrs OPr. assaran. The paradigmatic nom.-acc.pl. of ozerkó has final accent, i.e., ozerkí, but ozërki is attested as a TN elsewhere. | REW 3, 125.

nom.pl. of paduõms 'thought, opinion; provisions; counsel; plan.' Also a FN (LUV). | Compound of perfective prefix pa- and o-stem V of duõma 'thought' ← Ru. duma, perhaps via HLv. dùma. Verbal noun to paduõmât 'consider.' | ME 3, 20.

pìedàugava 'Daugava banks.' | Compound of pìe 'by, at' and HN Dàugava. | AK.

nom. pl. of paeglītis, D to paeglis 'juniper (juniperus communis); spruce-below; (pl.; a large mushroom); yew; spurrey (spergula arvensis).' Paeglis (LPDB). | ME 3, 23 s.v. paegle; SEJL 266 s.v. ẽglė.

nom.pl. of paņķis 'bank.' Also a FN (LUV). | Borrowed from Est. pank 'gravel bank; boulder,' cf. also Balt. Ge. Pank 'steep bank coast in Saaremaa and Muhu.' The Estonian form itself is borrowed from Sw. or MLG bank (EDE s.v. pank). | AK.

_alternative etymology: compound of pantarêt 'lisp' and sìlis 'jay (garrulus glandarius);' somehow from MLG panthēre 'pawnbroker.'

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of papar̂de 'fern.' Also a FN (LUV). | Probably inherited as *papar̂ts and thus cognate with Lt. papártis~papartỹs Ru. paporot' a.o. Further related to Skt. parṇám 'wing' OHG farn 'fern' OIr. raith 'id.' a.o. Same root as in Lv. spā̀rns 'wing' and Ru. peró 'feather' etc. | ALEW s.v. papar̃tis; Derksen 2015, 344; 2015, 419 s.v. sparnas; LEW 538; ME 3, 80; SEJL 857.
nom.pl. of papar̂des ziêds 'fern blossom.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of papar̂de 'fern' and ziêds 'blossom.' | AK.

pareĩzticîguo kapi 'orthodox cemetery.' | Masc.gen.pl.def. of pareĩzticîgs 'orthodox.' Compound of pareĩzs 'correct' and ticîgs 'religious.' | ME 3, 90.
paromba 'man-made clearing.' Cf. Po. Poręba & Porąbka (ISNP). | Borrowed from Po. poręba, cf. also Lt. pãrambas. | AK.

nom.-acc.pl. pā̀rsla 'snowflake; ice needle; ash particle; frost flake; wool tuft; a bit.' Also a FN (LUV). | Related to Lv. pērsêt 'get covered with frost, freeze' SCr. prȃh 'powder' ON fors 'waterfall' Skt. pr̥śatám 'drop' a.o. | ME 3, 176.

pl.tant. pìlsȩ̃tas kapi 'city cemetery.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of pìlsȩ̃ta 'city' and nom.pl. of kaps 'grave; (pl.) cemetery.' Primary element is pìlsȩ̃ta which is a compound of pìls 'castle' and sȩ̃ta 'fence; farm.' | ME 3, 217.

_etymology: nom.pl. of pilskalns 'hillfort.' Also a FN (LUV). | Syntagm of gen.sg. of pils 'castle' and kal̂ns 'hill, mountain,' cf. also Lt. pìliakalnis. pils 'castle' is cognate with Lt. pilìs, OPr. -pile in TN nawan-pile and Skt. pū́r and further related to Gr. πόλις 'city.' kal̂ns 'mountain' is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' | ALEW s.v. kálnas & pilìs; Derksen 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; 2015, 356 s.v. pilis; LEW 209 s.v. kálnas; 590 s.v. pilìs; ME 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; 3, 217 s.v. pils; SEJL 451 s.v. kálnas; 904 s.v. pilìs.

Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' | ALEW s.v. kálnas & pilìs; Derksen 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; 2015, 356 s.v. pilis; LEW 209 s.v. kálnas; 590 s.v. pilìs; ME 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; 3, 217 s.v. pils; SEJL 451 s.v. kálnas; 904 s.v. pilìs.

nom.pl. of meža vaĩruõgs 'forest shield.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of mežs 'forest' and vaĩruõgs 'shield.' First element is cognate with Lt. mẽdžias 'tree; forest' and OPr. median 'forest.' Inherited as a neuter o-stem but transferred to masculines in EB. Originally a substantivization of PIE adj. *medhi̯o- 'middle-,' cf. Ved. mádhyaḥ Av. maiδiia- Gr. μέσ(σ)ος Lat. medius Go. midjis a.o. Similarly OCS mežda 'lane, walk' Ru. mežá 'boundary; (dial.) forest' a.o. Second element is derived from  vairît 'ward off' on the model of karuõgs 'flag.' | ALEW s.v. mẽdis; Derksen 2015, 309 s.v. medžias; LEW 423 s.v. mẽdis; ME 2, 611 s.v. mežs; 4, 443 s.v. vaĩruõgs; SEJL 727 s.v. mẽdis; 729 s.v. mẽdžias.

nom.sg. priẽde 'pine (pinus silvestris).' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Priedė (LPDB) Po. Sosna (ISNP) HG Kiefer (DFD). | Probably has cognates in OPr. TNs Preydazare Predekaim a.o. Derived from a verb *preiti 'be superior' or a compound of *prie- and *dēti, i.e., 'put in front.' | Karulis 2001, 714.

_etymology: nom.sg. daĩņa sȩ̃ta 'Dainis' farmstead.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of PN Daĩnis and sȩ̃ta 'fence; farmstead.' Primary element is Daĩnis, Motionsmaskulinum to daĩņa~daĩna or an unattested *daĩne 'folk song,' cf. Lt. dainė̃~dainà. Perhaps further to Lv. diêt 'dance' Lt. dejà 'lamentation' a.o. Also exists as a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Dainỹs (LPDB). | ALEW s.v. dainà; Derksen 2015, 112; LEW 80; ME 1, 432 s.v. daĩņa; SEJL 182.
_alternative etymology: An otherwise unattested cognate to Lt. dainỹs 'singer.'

TNs Preydazare Predekaim a.o. The stem is derived from a verb *preiti 'be superior' or a compound of *prie- and *dēti, i.e., 'put in front.' | Karulis 2001, 714.
_alternative etymology: priẽde from *piedre 'resinous' and related to Gr. πῑδύω 'spring forth' ON fita 'fat' a.o. (ME 3, 392 s.v. I priẽde).

_etymology: nom.pl. of priẽdkal̂ns 'pine hill.' Rare as a FN (LUV). | Compound of priẽde 'pine (pinus silvestris)' and kal̂ns 'mountain.' First element probably has cognates in OPr. TNs Preydazare Predekaim a.o. The stem is derived from a verb *preiti 'be superior' or a compound of *prie- and *dēti, i.e., 'put in front.' Second element is cognate with Lt. kálnas 'mountain' and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Originally perhaps an n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. | ALEW s.v. kálnas; Derksen 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; Karulis 2001, 714 s.v. priẽde; LEW, 209 s.v. kálnas; ME 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; Smoczyński 2016, 451 s.v. kálnas.
_alternative etymology: priẽde from *piedre 'resinous' and related to Gr. πῑδύω 'spring forth' ON fita 'fat' a.o. (ME 3, 392 s.v. I priẽde).

_etymology: nom.pl. of FN priẽdnieks (LUV), cf. Lt. Priedniekas (← Lv.; LPDB). | nieks-derivation to priẽde 'pine (pinus silvestris),' perhaps in the sense 'pine cutter' or 'pinewoods dweller.' priẽde probably has cognates in OPr. TNs Preydazare Predekaim a.o. The stem is derived from a verb *preiti 'be superior' or a compound of *prie- and *dēti, i.e., 'put in front.' | Karulis 2001, 714.
_alternative etymology: priẽde from *piedre 'resinous' and related to Gr. πῑδύω 'spring forth' ON fita 'fat' a.o. (ME 3, 392 s.v. I priẽde); priednieks cognate to Lt. priedininkas 'day worker.'

Ultimately from Ru. pux 'fluff,' cf. also Lv. pũka 'down, fluff' Lt. pūkaĩ 'cotton grass' and pūkìnis 'downy, fluffy.' | ME 3, 445 s.v. pũka. Ēdelmane I., Ozola Ā. Latviešu valodas augu nosaukumi. nom.pl. of pukstiņš, synchronically D to puksts 'knock, heartbeat.' | inis-derivation to puksts 'knock, heartbeat' which is cognate with Lt. pùkštas 'moaner, groaner.' Further related to Lv. pukstêt 'tap, beat' Lt. pukstė́ti 'grumble' a.o. Onomatopoeic, cf. Lt. itj. pukšt | Karulis 2001, 719 s.v. pukstēt; ME 3, 404.
_alternative etymology: to Lt. pùkštas 'mole rat' perhaps of same origin? (LKŽ).

_etymology: pũķu pùrvs 'spirit swamp.' Also a FN, cf. Pūķis (LUV) and also Lt. Pūkỹs (LPDB) Po. Duch Smok (ISNP) HG Geist (DFD). | gen.pl. of pũķis 'dragon; house spirit; cabbage butterfly (pieris brassicae; pieris rapae) ← ON púki 'devil, demon,' cf. also Est. puuk and Lt. pū̃kis. | Karulis 2001, 719; ME 3, 446.
_alternative etymology: Lv. pũķis ← Sw. puke 'house spirit' (EDE s.v. puuk2; Karulis 2001, 719); Lv. pũķis ← MLG spūk (or HG Spuk) 'ghost, spirit' via Est puuk (EDE s.v. puuk2), cf. also Est kratt 'ghost, devil' ← Sw. skratt (EDE); Lv. pũķis is a Curonianism, from *pūtis 'blower,' cf. also kaķis < *katis 'cat' (ME 3, 446); to pũķis 'perch (perca)' ← Lt. pū̃kis 'id.' (ME 3, 446; attested on Curonian Spit).

_etymology: pakal̂nu pùrvs 'hillock swamp.' Also a FN, cf. Pakalns (LUV). | gen.pl. of pakal̂ns 'hillock; foot of the hill.' Compound of approximative suffix pa- (cf., e.g., patȩ̃vs 'stepfather') and kal̂ns 'hill, mountain.' Possibly cognate with Lt. pakal̃nė 'lowlands' or pakálnis 'foot of the hill' if -kal̂ns replaces older -kal̂nis or -kal̂ne. | ME 3, 38 s.v. pakal̂ne.

pũķupe 'spirit stream.' Also a FN, cf. Pūķis (LUV) and also Lt. Pūkỹs (LPDB) Po. (ME 3, 446; attested on Curonian Spit).

_alternative etymology: folk etymology or taboo deformation of pũķupe 'spirit stream.'

_etymology: nom.sg. bẽrzene 'russula' (ME 1, 292). | *inē-derivation to bȩ̃rzs 'birch' (ME 1, 292), cf. also Lt. beržìnė 'birch rod' to béržas 'birch.' Substantivized Motionsfemininum to adjective in *-inīs, cf. Lt. beržìnis 'birchen' and substantivized Ukr. berezenь Po. brzezień 'March.' For the meaning 'russula' cf. also Kash. brzezan 'birch bolete.' | AK.

D to pũķupe 'spirit stream.' Also a FN, cf. Pūķis (LUV) and also Lt. Pūkỹs (LPDB) Po. Duch Smok (ISNP) HG Geist (DFD). | pũķis 'dragon; house spirit; cabbage butterfly (pieris brassicae; pieris rapae)' is borrowed from ON púki 'devil, demon,' cf. also Est. puuk and Lt. pū̃kis. | Karulis 2001, 719; ME 3, 446.
_alternative etymology: Lv. pũķis ← Sw. puke 'house spirit' (EDE s.v. puuk2; Karulis 2001, 719); Lv. pũķis ← MLG spūk (or HG Spuk) 'ghost, spirit' via Est puuk (EDE s.v. puuk2), cf. also Est kratt 'ghost, devil' ← Sw. skratt (EDE); Lv. pũķis is a Curonianism, from *pūtis 'blower,' cf. also kaķis < *katis 'cat' (ME 3, 446); to pũķis 'perch (perca)' ← Lt. pū̃kis 'id.' (ME 3, 446; attested on Curonian Spit).

(ME 3, 446; attested on Curonian Spit).

Ringmundshof 'Ringmund estate.' | Somehow for FN Ringenmuth, compound of MHG ringe 'small, petty' and muot 'reason, mind.' | AK.
rȩ̀mbate 'Ringenmuth (place).' | ē-derivation to a borrowed form of HG FN Ringenmuth. | LVV2 R, 188.

liẽlvā̀rde 'great name.' Also a FN (LUV). | Compound of liẽls 'great' and vā̀rds 'word; name.' Folk etymology of a borrowed V of ON lendavarða, compound of lenda 'land, go ashore' and varða 'watchtower.' | Karulis 1989, 337, 341 apud Balode & Bušs 2015, 142-143.
_alternative etymology: compound of liẽls 'large' and vā̀rds 'word' (Biel 44); from liẽlvāda 'great floodwater' with inserted r due to folk etymology (Endzelīns apud Balode & Bušs 2015, 141-142 LVV 2 334, ME 2 460 4 492); first element is Lv. lêne 'lawn on the shore under which land has been washed away' or lēnains 'marshy' (Balode & Bušs 2015, 143); second element is cognate with Est. TN/FN Vardi or Vardja (Alvre apud Karma 1994, 154).

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of FN Remeika (LUV), cf. also Lt. Remeikà~Rameikà (LPDB). | Borrowed from Lt. FN Remeikà which is related to ramùs 'calm; cheerful.' | LPDB s.v. Rameika.
nom.pl. of FN Rempēteris (LUV). | Unclear origin. | AK.
nom.pl. of rem̂pis2 'weakly person; stout boy; fat pig.' | Related to rȩ̀mpȩns2 'short and thick' a.o. Perhaps also to rem̃ptiês 'crawl.' | ME 3, 510.

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. to reñne 'gully; gutter; fountain spout.' Rare as FN (LUV). | Borrowed from MLG renne 'drain, gutter, channel,' cf. also Est. reńń Lt. renė 'furrow.' | EH 2, 366 s.v. rene; ME 3, 511 s.v. rene.
nom.-acc.pl. of rèvele2 'crybaby.' Also a FN (LUV). | Related to rèvelêt2 'laugh or cry loud and long.' | EH 2, 370 s.v. rèvelis2.
lejasrèveles2 'lower Rēveles.' Also a FN, cf. Rēvele (LUV). | nom.-acc.pl. of rèvele2 'crybaby.' Related to rèvelêt2 'laugh or cry loud and long.' | EH 2, 370 s.v. rèvelis2.
D to rèvele2 'crybaby.' Also a FN, cf. Rēvele (LUV). | Related to rèvelêt2 'laugh or cry loud and long.' Probably the sense here is rather 'rumbling, roaring (river).' | EH 2, 370 s.v. rèvelis2.

nom.pl. of rēzis 'incised mark; strip of (arable) land.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Rėžys (LPDB). | Borrowed from Lt. rėžys 'incised mark; stretch of land' with z for ž in the singular on the model of native ii̯o-stems. Perhaps borrowed as a FN. | LPDB s.v. Rėžys.

fem.nom.-acc.pl. of rȩ̀zns 'loose; cheerful.' Also a FN, cf. Rāzna (LUV). | Borrowed from Ru. rézvyj in the sense 'cheerful.' It is unclear where the sense 'loose' comes from but see also Lt. rė̃svas 'loose, rare' and Lv. rȩ̀zvans 'id.' | EH 2, 370 s.v. II rȩ̄zns; ME 3, 521.

_comment: also name of a nearby waterfall (E 1922).

_etymology: nom.-acc.pl. of rezne. | unclear meaning and etymology. | AK.

partially standardized V of nom.pl. of rībȩ̃ns 'penny bun gatherer' vel sim. | ēna-derivation to pl.tant.  rības 'penny buns (boletus edulis)' ← Ru. grib 'mushroom.' | ME 3, 534 s.v. rības.

dial. for ribaku slabada 'fishermen's village.' Also a FN, cf. Ribaks (LUV). | Syntagm of gen.pl. of ribaks 'fisherman' and slabada 'village; settlement temporarily relieved of tax duty.' | AK.

rĩgas upe 'Riga river.' Also a FN, cf. Rīga (LUV). | gen.sg. of rĩga 'winding (river),' cf. Lt. HNs Ringa Rìngė Lv. Rìņģis as well as Lt. rìnga 'something winding' Lv. rîdziņa 'stream.' | Balode 2017, 43; ME 3, 536 s.v. rîdziņa.

rīdzene 'winding (river).' | inii̯ā-derivation to the root *ring- 'wind, bend,' cf. Lt. HNs Ringa Rìngė Lv. Rìņģis as well as Lt. rìnga 'something winding' Lv. rîdziņa 'stream.' | Balode 2017, 43; ME 3, 536 s.v. rîdziņa.
rĩga 'winding (river).' | Borrowed from Lv. rĩga 'winding (river)' which is cognate with Lt. rìnga 'something winding,' cf. also Lv. rîdziņa 'stream.' | ME 3, 536 s.v. rîdziņa.
nom.-acc.pl. of rîdziņa 'stream.' Also a FN (LUV). | inii̯o-derivation to an unattested *rîga which is cognate with Lt. ringa 'something crooked, bent.' | ME 3, 536.
nom.pl. of riebulis 'massage tool.' | ulii̯o-derivation to rìebt 'heal.' | ME 3, 543.
_alternative etymology: to riêbt 'be abhorrent' (ME 3, 542 s.v. I riêbt); from Lt. riebùlis 'fat person.'

_etymology: nom.sg. riẽkstaine 'rich nut-tree.' | ē-derivation to riẽkstaîns 'rich in nuts,' itself aina-derivation to riẽksts 'nut.' | AK.

nom.pl. of D to riẽksts 'nut.' Also a FN, cf. LUV s.v. Rieksts & Riekstiņš. | Related to and perhaps even cognate with Lt. ríešutas; apart from the scenarios mentioned in ME, Lv. riẽksts may be derived from *riesuts if we assume syncope (cf., vȩcs : Lt. vẽtušas 'old'), and epenthetic k. Further related to OPr. buccareisis 'beech-nut' Ru. oréx 'walnut' a.o. The inis-derivation was originally associative in meaning, cf. Lt. riešutìnis 'nut-.' | Derksen 2015, 382; LEW 731; ME 3, 544 s.v. I riẽksts; SEJL 1027.

rīga 'winding (river).' Also a FN (LUV). | Cognate with Lt. rìnga 'something winding,' cf. also Lt. HNs Ringa Rìngė Lv. Rìņģis as well as Lv. rîdziņa 'stream.' The city is named after the river. | Balode 2017, 43; ME 3, 536 s.v. rîdziņa.
_alternative etymology: to Lat. rigata 'spattered' (Balode 2017, 43); from BG Riege or MLG rīge 'kiln' (Balode 2017, 43); to MLG rīge 'watercourse;' to Ru. riga 'threshing barn' (Balode 2017, 43); Liv. rīj 'threshing barn' (Balode 2017, 43); to Est. TNs Riigi and Rüüga (Endzelīns apud Balode 2017, 43).

_etymology: nom.pl. of rijniẽks 'kiln keeper.' Also a FN (LUV). | nieka-derivation of rija 'kiln' which is borrowed from Est. riha or Liv. rī, cf. also Sw. ria Lt. rija. | ME 3, 524.
nom.pl. of FN rimicāns (LUV). | Unclear meaning and etymology. | AK.

nom.pl. of rindulis 'soldier.' | ulii̯o-derivation to riñda 'row' which is borrowed from Cur. or Lt. (rinda) and related to Sl. rędъ. For the meaning of the derivation, cf. riñdiniẽks (ME 3, 528). | ME 3, 527.
_alternative etymology: from Liv. rīnda (Thomsen apud ME 3, 527); to riñdȩns 'lukewarm' (ME 3, 527); to rinduksis 'net pouch' (ME 3, 528); to or from Lt. rindùliai 'dress folds.'

nom.pl. of rīnūzis 'stream house.' | Earlier rinnūzis vel sim. ← MLG *rinnehūs vel sim., a compound of rinne 'channel, brook' and hūs 'house.' Named after erstwhile stream Lv. rinna. | Wikipedia: Vecmīlgrāvis.
rištaks 'current; ditch.' | Borrowed from HG Rinnstein 'gutter' via Po. rysztok and perhaps Lt. rištãkas. | AK.

rîtàusma 'red dawn.' | Compound of rîts 'morning' and ausma 'daybreak.' | ME 3, 540 s.v. rîtàusa.

Somehow from rùou̯pļava, dial. for rāvpļava 'boggy meadow.' Compound of rāva 'smelly, ferruginous water; swampy place with smelly, ferruginous water' and pļava 'meadow.' Also a FN, cf. Rāva (LUV). | Cognate with Lt. rova 'floodwater residue on meadow.' Related to rāja 'smelly, ferruginous water in depressions' and Kash. râja 'mud.' | LVV2 R, 326; ME 3, 499 s.v. I rāva.
_alternative etymology: to rāva 'depth in sea; rapids' (ME 3, 499 s.v. II rāva).

_etymology: rùožupoles kal̂na dzir̃navezers 'Rožupole upper mill lake.' | Gen.sg. of rùožupole 'rose field.' Syntagm of gen.pl. of ruõze 'rose' and pole 'field.' Perhaps borrowed as a compound from Po. róża + pole or Bru. ruža + pole. | AK.

rùožupoles aûgšdzir̃navu ezers 'Rožupole upper mill lake.' | Gen.sg. of rùožupole 'rose field.' Syntagm of gen.pl. of ruõze 'rose' and pole 'field.' Perhaps borrowed as a compound from Po. róża + pole or Bru. ruža + pole. | AK.

rùožupoles lejas dzir̃navezers 'Rožupole lower mill lake.' | Gen.sg. of rùožupole 'rose field.' Syntagm of gen.pl. of ruõze 'rose' and pole 'field.' Perhaps borrowed as a compound from Po. róża + pole or Bru. ruža + pole. | AK.
dial. for rubanišķu pusmuĩža 'Rubanišķi farm estate.' | iskii̯o-derivation to FN Rubans (LUV) which is borrowed from Ru. FN Ruban. The meaning would be 'of Ruban.' | AK.
rubeņu kal̂ns 'black grouse hill.' Also a FN, cf. Rubenis (LUV). | Syntagm of gen.pl. of rubenis 'black grouse (tetrao tetrix)' and kal̂ns 'hill, mountain.' | AK.
dial. for ruobežnīca 'border (stream).' | nīca-derivation to rùobeža 'border.' Derived on the model of Ru. HN Rubežnica, nica-derivation to rubéž 'border.' | AK.
nom.pl. of rubulis 'ruble; medal.' Also a FN (LUV). | Borrowed from Ru. rubl' with reanalysis of the final -lis as suffix -ulis, cf. also Est. rubl and Lt. rublis. | ME 3, 552 s.v. rublis.
nom.pl. of rudakmens 'fieldstone.' | Compound of ruds 'reddish brown' and akmens 'stone.' | ME 3, 553.

dial. for rudȩ̃nu kapi 'Rudēni cemetery.' Also a FN, cf. Rudāns (LUV). | gen.pl. of rudȩ̃ns 'reddish, reddish brown,' ēna-derivation to ruds 'reddish brown.' | ME 3, 553 s.v. rudaîns.
nom.pl. of rudȩ̃ns 'reddish, reddish brown.' Also a FN, cf. Rudāns (LUV). | ēna-derivation to ruds 'reddish brown.' | ME 3, 553 s.v. rudaîns.
dial. for nom.pl. of rudȩ̃ns 'reddish, reddish brown.' Also a FN, cf. Rudāns (LUV). | ēna-derivation to ruds 'reddish brown.' | ME 3, 553 s.v. rudaîns.

nom.pl. of rudiņš, D to ruds 'reddish brown.' Rare as a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Rudỹs (LPDB) Po. Ryżewski (ISNP) HG Roth (DFD) and Lv. dog name Rudiņš (ME 3, 554). | Originally purely associative iņš-derivation to ruds 'reddish brown,' cf. Lt. rudìnis 'reddish' to rùdas 'id.' Lv. ruds is cognate with Lt. rùdas and perhaps, by dissimilatory loss of the second r, also to Skt. rudhiráḥ Gr. ἐρυθρός Lat. ruber a.o. | Derksen 2015, 384; LEW 745; ME 3, 554 s.v. ruds; SEJL 1043.

Lv. ruds is cognate with Lt. rùdas and perhaps, by dissimilatory loss of the second r, also to Skt. rudhiráḥ Gr. ἐρυθρός Lat. ruber a.o. | Derksen 2015, 384; LEW 745; ME 3, 554 s.v. ruds; SEJL 1043.

tartaka 'sawmill (river).' | ā-derivation to tartaks 'sawmill' ← Po. tartak. | AK.
rudzaite 'rye field.' | aitē-derivation to rudzis 'rye grain; (pl.) rye' which is cognate with Lt. rugỹs OPr. rugis Ru. rož' ON rugr a.o. | EH 2, 382; ME 3, 555.

dial. for rudzaites upīte 'rye field stream.' | gen.sg. of rudzaite 'rye field.' aitē-derivation to rudzis 'rye grain; (pl.) rye' which is cognate with Lt. rugỹs OPr. rugis Ru. rož' ON rugr a.o. | EH 2, 382; ME 3, 555.
D to rudzaita 'rye field.' | aitā-derivation to rudzis 'rye grain; (pl.) rye' which is cognate with Lt. rugỹs OPr. rugis Ru. rož' ON rugr a.o. | EH 2, 382; ME 3, 555 s.v. rudzaite.

_etymology: nom.pl. of FN Ancȩ̃ns 'Johns.' Exists only as FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Jõnelis (LPDB) Po. Iwanow (ISNP) HG Hansel Hanses (DFD) Eng. Johns Jones. | ēna-derivation to PN Añcis ← HG Hans which is a short form of Johannes 'John.' Ultimately from BHe. Yōḥānān < YHVH khanún 'God is gracious' via Gr. Ἰωάννης and Lat. Iōhannēs. | LPV 56; LVV 1, 27 s.v. añce; ME 1, 71 s.v. Añcis.
_alternative etymology: HLv. for ancĩši 'agrimony, sticklewort (agrimonia eupatoria)' ultimately of the same origin (ME 1, 71).

Iwanow (ISNP) HG Hansel Hanses (DFD) Eng. Johns Jones. | ēna-derivation to PN Añcis ← HG Hans which is a short form of Johannes 'John.' Ultimately from BHe. Yōḥānān < YHVH khanún 'God is gracious' via Gr. Ἰωάννης and Lat. Iōhannēs. | LPV 56; LVV 1, 27 s.v. añce; ME 1, 71 s.v. Añcis.
_alternative etymology: HLv. for ancĩši 'agrimony, sticklewort (agrimonia eupatoria)' ultimately of the same origin (ME 1, 71).

_etymology: rudzīšu priẽdes 'Rudzīši pines.' Also a FN, cf. Priede (LUV) and also Lt. Priedė (LPDB) Po. Sosna (ISNP) HG Kiefer (DFD). | nom.-acc.pl. of priẽde 'pine (pinus silvestris).' Probably cognate with first element in OPr. TNs Preydazare Predekaim a.o. Derived from a verb *preiti 'be superior' or a compound of *prie- and *dēti, i.e., 'put in front.' | Karulis 2001, 714.
_alternative etymology: From *piedre 'resinous' and related to Gr. πῑδύω 'spring forth' ON fita 'fat' a.o. (ME 3, 392 s.v. I priẽde).

_etymology: rudzīšu skal̃bes 'Rudzīši sweet flag.' Also a FN, cf. Skalbe (LUV). | nom.-acc.pl. of skal̃be 'sweet flag (acorus calamus)' ← MLG schelp 'reed.' | ME 3, 867.

rudzīšu uôši 'Rudzīši ashes.' Also a FN, cf. Osis (LUV) and also Lt. Úosis (LPDB) Po. Jesion (ISNP) HG Esche (DFD). | nom.pl. of uôsis 'ash (fraxinus excelsior).' Cognate with Lt. úosis and OPr. woasis and further related to Ru. jasen' ON askr Lat. ornus a.o. | ALEW s.v. úosis; Derksen 2015, 481; LEW 1167; PKEŽ 4, 258; ME 4, 421 s.v. I uôsis; SEJL 1466.

rudzīšu uôzuõliņi 'Rudzīši oaks.' Also a FN, cf. Ozols Ozoliņš (LUV) and also Po. Dąbek (ISNP) HG Eichel (DFD). | nom.pl. of D to uôzuõls 'oak.' Cognate with Lt. ą́žuolas 'oak' and further related to OPr. ansonis 'oak' as well as Ru. úzel Po. węzeł a.o. 'knot.' Given the attested suffix variety we are probably dealing with an original athematic l- or perhaps l/n-stem. The inii̯o-stem is cognate with Lt. ąžuolìnis 'oaken.' | ALEW ą́žuolas; Derksen 2015, 75; LEW 28; ME 4, 427; SEJL 75.

_etymology: pl.tant. rudzīži 'red silk.' Only attested as TN. | Compound of ruds 'reddish, reddish-brown' (ME 3, 554) and pl.tant. zīži 'silk' (ME 4, 737). First element is cognate with Lt. rùdas 'reddish' and perhaps, by dissimilatory loss of the second r, to Skt. rudhiráḥ Gr. ἐρυθρός Lat. ruber a.o. (Derksen 2015, 384; LEW 745; ME 3, 554; SEJL 1043). Second element is V of zĩds~zīde 'silk' ← MLG sīde, cf. also Est. sīt' (ME 4, 732 s.v. zĩds). | AK.

"rumbas zvejniek[i]" 'rapids fishermen' (ME 3, 558 s.v. I rum̃ba)) or 'rapids dweller.' Cognate with Lt. rumba 'callus' and further related to rum̃bas 'edge; hem' Ru. rúb Po. rąb 'id.' | Derksen 2015, 385 s.v. rumbas; LEW 748; ME 3, 557-558 s.v. I rum̃ba and II rum̃ba.

_etymology: nom.pl. of ruõžkal̂ns 'rose hill.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. HG Rosenberg (DFD). | Compound of ruõze 'rose' and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' First element is borrowed from HG Rose. Second element is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' | ALEW s.v. kálnas; Derksen 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; LEW, 209 s.v. kálnas; ME 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; 3, 586 s.v. I ruõze; SEJL 451 s.v. kálnas.
_alternative etymology: to ruoze 'ridge in forest or marsh' (ME 3, 585 s. v. I ruôza).

If so, then sala might be shortened from *ap(i)sala, a parallel to Po. ostrów SCr. òtok. | Derksen 2015, 387; LEW 758; PKEŽ 4, 55; ME 3, 664; SEJL 1059.

TN Salas muĩža 'Sala estate.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of TN Sala and muĩža 'estate.' TN Sala =  sala 'island; hillock in marsh.' Cognate with Lt. salà and perhaps further related to Lt. sálti 'flow' and OPr. salus 'rainwater creek.' If so, then sala might be shortened from *ap(i)sala, a parallel to Po. ostrów SCr. òtok. | Derksen 2015, 387; LEW 758; PKEŽ 4, 55; ME 3, 664; SEJL 1059.

TN Salas pusmuĩža 'Sala farm estate.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of TN Sala and pusmuĩža 'farm estate.' TN Sala =  sala 'island; hillock in marsh.' Cognate with Lt. salà and perhaps further related to Lt. sálti 'flow' and OPr. salus 'rainwater creek.' If so, then sala might be shortened from *ap(i)sala, a parallel to Po. ostrów SCr. òtok. | Derksen 2015, 387; LEW 758; PKEŽ 4, 55; ME 3, 664; SEJL 1059.

nom.-acc.pl. of dàugavsala 'Daugava island.' | Compound of HN Dàugava and sala 'island; hillock in marsh.' HN Dàugava is an ava-derivation to the root *daug- 'much' which is also seen in daũdz Lt. daũg 'much.' Semantically thus 'water-rich river,' cf. also the generic term daugaviņa 'id.' The suffix -ava might be identical to the root in avuots 'spring, source' Skt. avatáḥ 'well' a.o. sala is cognate with Lt. salà and perhaps further related to Lt. sálti 'flow' and OPr. salus 'rainwater creek.' If so, then sala might be shortened from *ap(i)sala, a parallel to Po. ostrów SCr. òtok. | Derksen 2015, 387 s.v. sala; Karulis 2001, 203 s.v. daudz; LEW 758 s.v. salà; LVV 1, 198 s.v. dàugava; ME 1, 233 s.v. avuõts; 3, 664 s.v. sala; PKEŽ 4, 55 s.v. salus; SEJL 1059 s.v. salà.

salas pusmuĩža 'island farm estate.' Gen.sg. of sala 'island.' Also a FN, cf. Sala (LUV). | Cognate with Lt. salà and perhaps further related to Lt. sálti 'flow' and OPr. salus 'rainwater creek.' If so, then sala might be shortened from *ap(i)sala, a parallel to Po. ostrów SCr. òtok. | Derksen 2015, 387; LEW 758; PKEŽ 4, 55 s.v. salus; ME 3, 664; SEJL 1059 s.v. salà.

If so, then sala might be shortened from *ap(i)sala, a parallel to Po. ostrów SCr. òtok. pils 'castle' is cognate with Lt. pilìs, OPr. -pile in TN nawan-pile and Skt. pū́r and further related to Gr. πόλις 'city.' | ALEW s.v. pilìs; Derksen 2015, 356 s.v. pilis; 2015, 387 s.v. salà; LEW 590 s.v. pilìs; 758 s.v. salà; PKEŽ 4, 55 s.v. salus; ME 3, 217 s.v. pils; 3, 664 s.v. sala; SEJL 904 s.v. pilìs; 1059 s.v. salà.

Skt. vleṣka- 'sling' a.o. | ALEW s.v. lazdà; Derksen 2015, 276 s.v. lazda; LEW 348 s.v. lazdà; ME 2, 433 s.v. lazda; PKEŽ 3, 54 s.v. laxde; SEJL 640 s.v. lazdà.

nom.sg. of TN Silavu daugaviņa 'Daugaviņa in Silavas.' | Syntagm of gen. of TN Silavas and TN Daugaviņa. Primary element is daugaviņa, inis-derivation to HN Dàugava, probably in the sense 'associated with the Daugava, by the Daugava.' Also a FN (LUV). Dàugava is an ava-derivation to the root *daug- 'much' which is also seen in daũdz Lt. daũg 'much.' Semantically thus 'water-rich river,' cf. also the generic term daugaviņa 'id.' The suffix -ava might be identical to the root in avuots 'spring, source' Skt. avatáḥ 'well' a.o. | Karulis 2001, 203 s.v. daudz; ME 1, 233 s.v. avuõts.

pl.tant. TN Silavu daugmales 'Daugmales in Silavas.' | Syntagm of gen. of TN Silavas and TN Daugmales. Primary element is TN Daugmales, nom.-acc.pl. of daugmale 'bank of the Daugava,' itself a compound of HN Dauga and mala 'edge; bank.' First element is an ā-derivation to the root *daug- 'much' also seen in daũdz Lt. daũg 'much.' Semantically thus 'water-rich river.' Second element is a compositional V of mala 'edge, bank,' cognate with ON mǫl 'gravel; stone embankment' Alb. mal 'mountain' a.o. Rare as a FN (LUV). | EH 1, 310 s.v. Dauga; ME 1, 445 s.v. dàugavmale; 2, 555 s.v. I mala.
_alternative etymology: mala ← ON mǫl or Sw. dial. mal, cf. also Orc. muller 'stony beach' a.o. (de Vries 1977, 401); daugmale shortened from daugavmale.

_etymology: nom.sg. of TN Silavu ȩzȩrs 'Silavas lake.' | Syntagm of gen. of TN Silavas and ȩzȩrs 'lake.' Primary element is TN Silavas, nom.-acc.pl. of silava 'spruce or pine forest; (pl.) grove.' avā-derivation to sils 'pinewoods.' Also a FN (LUV). sils is cognate with Lt. šìlas 'pinewoods; heath' and OPr. sylo 'heath.' Inherited as a neuter o-stem. Might be further related to Gr. σκέλλω 'dry out' or to Ved. śila- 'ears (of corn) left on field.' | ALEW s.v. šìlas; LEW 982 s.v. šìlas; ME 3, 838 s.v. silava; 3, 839 s.v. sils; SEJL 1292 s.v. šìlas.

nom.sg. of TN Silavu kraujas 'Kraujas in Silavas.' | Syntagm of gen. of TN Silavas and TN Kraujas. Primary element is TN Kraujas, nom.-acc.pl. of kràuja 'steep bank.' Possibly a substantivization of adj. kràujš 'steep,' cf. dial. o-stem kràujš 'steep bank.' Probably related to Lt kriaũšis a.o. 'steep bank' a.o. which seems to belong to Lt krùšti 'mash, crush.' Compared on the other hand also to Lv kŗaũt~kraũt 'gather' and krūtiês 'fall' although the relationship remains obscure. Also a FN (LUV). | ALEW s.v. kriaũšas; LEW 296 s.v. kriaũšis; ME 2, 262 s.v. III kràuja; SEJL 571 s.v. kriaũšas.

nom.sg. silavu pùrvs 'spruce forest swamp.' | Syntagm of gen.pl. of silava 'spruce or pine forest; (pl.) grove' and pùrvs 'swamp.' Might be further related to Gr. σκέλλω 'dry out' or to Ved. śila- 'ears (of corn) left on field.' Also a FN (LUV). Second element is cognate with Lt. pur̃vas 'mud.' nom.pl. of sìlkal̂nis 'pinewoods hill.' Possibly a FN, cf. Silkalns (LUV). | Compound of sils 'pinewoods' and compositional V of kal̂ns 'mountain.' First element is cognate with Lt. šìlas 'pinewoods; heath' and OPr. sylo 'heath' and possibly further related to Gr. σκέλλω 'dry out' or to Ved. śila- 'ears (of corn) left on field.' Inherited as a neuter o-stem. Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Šìlas (LPDB). Second element is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Kálnas (LPDB) Po. Góra (ISNP) HG Berg (DFD). | ALEW s.v. šìlas & kálnas; Derksen 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; Karulis 2001, 816 s.v. sīlis; LEW 209 s.v. kálnas; 982 s.v. šìlas; ME 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; 3, 839 s.v. sils; SEJL 451 s.v. kálnas; 1292 s.v. šìlas.

_etymology: nom.pl. of šķēršķȩ̃ns 'of Christian.' Also a FN, cf. Sķerškāns Škerškāns Skerškāns Skerškans (LUV). | From šķȩ̃rstȩ̃ns with assimilation of -st- to -šķ-. ēna-derivation to PN Šķȩ̃rsts 'Christian' ← MLG Kerst. Ultimately from Lat. Chrīstiānus 'Christian,' iānus-derivation to Chrīstus ← Gr. Χρῑστός, a calque of BHe. māšīaḥ 'anointed.' | LPV 300; ME 4, 37 s.v. Šķȩ̃rsts.
_alternative etymology: to šķẽrste 'skirt slit' (ME 4, 37); to šķȩ̄rsts 'warp beam; wooden skewer' (ME 4, 37).
_category: foreign names (aramaic and hebrew); foreign names (germanic)

dial. for nom.pl. of strads 'thrush.' Also a FN, cf. LUV s.v. Strads & Strods. | Dissimilated V of strazds which is cognate with Lt. strãzdas OPr. tresde Ru. drozd ON þrǫstr OIr. truit a.o. | Derksen 2015, 431; LEW 920; ME 3, 1080 s.v. strads; 3, 1083 s.v. strazds; SEJL 1225.

_etymology: nom.pl. of struķis. Exists only as TN and FN (LUV), cf. HG Struck (DFD). | Borrowed from MLG struk~strūk 'shrub.' | AK.

_etymology: nom.pl. of struopȩ̃ns 'beekeeper' vel sim. | ēna-derivation to struops 'beehive; bee swarm; hollow stalk; stout person.' which is possibly cognate with Lt. stram̃pas 'cudgel, stick.' | EH 2, 592; ME 3, 1098 s.v. struops.
nom.pl. of struops 'beehive; bee swarm; hollow stalk; stout person.' Also a FN (LUV). | Might be cognate with Lt. stram̃pas 'cudgel, stick.' | EH 2, 592; ME 3, 1098.
_meaning: beehive; bee swarm; hollow stalk; stout person
_category: apiculture; botany; insects and microorganisms; nicknames

_etymology: strūves parks 'Struve's park.' Gen.sg. of FN Strūve (LUV), cf. also HG Struve (DFD). | Borrowed from HG FN Struve, itself from MLG strūf 'standing on end, uneven, strict.' | DFD s.v. Struve.
kruõņa dā̀rzs 'crown garden.' Gen.sg. of kruõnis 'crown; government; tooth corona.' Also a FN (LUV). | Borrowed from MLG krone, cf. also Est. roon. | ME 2, 294.
nom.-acc.pl. of stučka 'stout elderly woman.' Also a FN (LUV). | Unclear etymology. | ME 3, 1100.
_alternative etymology: to or from Lt. FN Stučka (LPDB).

_etymology: nom.pl. of students 'student.' Also a FN (LUV). | Borrowed from Lat. studēns, present active participle to studeō 'study.' | AK.

nom.pl. of FN Stukmanis 'Stockmann' (LUV), cf. also HG Stockmann (DFD). | Borrowed from HG FN Stockmann or its MLG counterpart. Compound of MHG stoc 'stick, rod, pole; boundary post; tree trunk, tree stump; prison' or MLG stock 'stick; sign of official authority; tree stump; beehive' and HG Mann 'man.' Semantics might be 'forest dweller; clearing dweller' or 'prison guard; beekeeper: official.' | DFD s.v. Stockmann.

Stockmannshof 'Stockmann estate.' Also a FN, cf. Stukmanis (LUV) HG Stockmann (DFD). | Compound of MHG stoc 'stick, rod, pole; boundary post; tree trunk, tree stump; prison' or MLG stock 'stick; sign of official authority; tree stump; beehive' and HG Mann 'man.' Semantics might be 'forest dweller; clearing dweller' or 'prison guard; beekeeper: official.' | DFD s.v. Stockmann.

stupeļa pùrvs 'barrel swamp.' Gen.sg. of stupelis 'barrel.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Stupẽlis (LPDB). | Borrowed from Lt. stùpelis 'large cup, barrel,' perhaps as a FN. | LPDB s.v. Stupelis.
oginska pùrvs 'Oginski's swamp.' Gen.sg. of FN Oginskis (LUV), cf. also Lt. Agìnskas (LPDB) Po. Ogiński (ISNP). | Borrowed from Po. FN Ogiński, ski-derivation to ogień 'fire.' | AK.
nom.pl. of stùrabrẽķis 'corner crybaby.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of stùris 'corner, angle' and brẽķis 'crybaby.' | AK.

_etymology: pl.tant. upes stūres 'Stūres-by-the-river.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of upe 'river' and nom.-acc.pl. of stūre 'corner, angle.' Primary element is stūre, a V of stùris. Narożnik (ISNP) HG Ecke (DFD). | Karulis 2001, 950; LEW 934 s.v. stùris; ME 3, 1110 s.v. I stùris; SEJL 1235.

nom.pl. of vanadziņš, synchronically D to vanags 'hawk, falcon.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Vanagelis (LPDB) Po. Jastrząbek (ISNP). | Cognate with Lt. vãnagas and the second element of compounds OPr. sperglawanag 'sparrowhawk' and gertoanax 'goshawk.' | ALEW s.v. vãnagas; Karulis 2001, 1115; LEW 1194; ME 4, 468; PKEŽ 1, 357 s.v. gertoanax; 4, 145 s.v. sperglawanag; SEJL 1500.

nom.-acc.pl. of vanagâre 'hawk field.' | Compound of vanags 'hawk, falcon' and âre 'the open; field; outside.' First element is cognate with Lt. vãnagas and the second element of compounds OPr. sperglawanag 'sparrowhawk' and gertoanax 'goshawk.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Vãnagas (LPDB) Po. Jastrząb (ISNP) HG Habicht (DFD). Second element is cognate with Lt. orė̃ 'ploughing; ploughed field.' Thus originally VN in the sense 'ploughing' to *arˀ- 'plough,' cf. mõlė~molė̃ ‘grinding’ to málti ‘grind’ (Skardžius 1943, 71). The mobile V is semelfactive and may have acquired the meaning 'ploughed field' although contamination with Lv. ârs~âra 'the open; field; outside' (Lt. óras 'air; weather') must be assumed, too, due to the other meanings of âre. Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Laukas (LPDB) Po. Niwa (ISNP) HG Feld (DFD). | ALEW s.v. óras & vãnagas; Derksen 2015, 340 s.v. oras; Karulis 2001, 1115 s.v. vanags; LEW 518 s.v. óras; 1194 s.v. vãnagas; ME 1, 239 s.v. âra; 4, 468 s.v. vanags; PKEŽ 1, 357 s.v. gertoanax; 4, 145 s.v. sperglawanag; SEJL 834 s.v. orė̃; 1500 s.v. vãnagas.

pl.tant. of TN vanagâres pļavas 'Vanagāre meadows.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of vanagâre 'hawk field' and nom.-acc.pl. of pļava 'meadow.' Primary element is vanagâre, itself a compound of vanags 'hawk, falcon' and âre 'the open; field; outside.' First element is cognate with Lt. vãnagas and the second element of compounds OPr. sperglawanag 'sparrowhawk' and gertoanax 'goshawk.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Vãnagas (LPDB) Po. Jastrząb (ISNP) HG Habicht (DFD). Second element is cognate with Lt. orė̃ 'ploughing; ploughed field.' Thus originally VN in the sense 'ploughing' to *arˀ- 'plough,' cf. mõlė~molė̃ ‘grinding’ to málti ‘grind’ (Skardžius 1943, 71). The mobile V is semelfactive and may have acquired the meaning 'ploughed field' although contamination with Lv. ârs~âra 'the open; field; outside' (Lt. óras 'air; weather') must be assumed, too, due to the other meanings of âre. Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Laukas (LPDB) Po. Niwa (ISNP) HG Feld (DFD). | ALEW s.v. óras & vãnagas; Derksen 2015, 340 s.v. oras; Karulis 2001, 1115 s.v. vanags; LEW 518 s.v. óras; 1194 s.v. vãnagas; ME 1, 239 s.v. âra; 4, 468 s.v. vanags; PKEŽ 1, 357 s.v. gertoanax; 4, 145 s.v. sperglawanag; SEJL 834 s.v. orė̃; 1500 s.v. vãnagas.

nom.sg. vanagkal̂ns 'hawk hill.' | Compound of vanags 'hawk, falcon' and kal̂ns 'hill, mountain.' First element is cognate with Lt. vãnagas and the second element of compounds OPr. sperglawanag 'sparrowhawk' and gertoanax 'goshawk.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Vãnagas (LPDB) Po. Jastrząb (ISNP) HG Habicht (DFD). Second element is cognate with Lt. kálnas and further related to Lat. collis 'mound' Gr. κολωνός 'id.' OE hyll (*hulni-) 'id.' a.o. Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' | ALEW s.v. kálnas & vãnagas; Derksen 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; Karulis 2001, 1115 s.v. vanags; LEW 209 s.v. kálnas; 1194 s.v. vãnagas; ME 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; 4, 468 s.v. vanags; PKEŽ 1, 357 s.v. gertoanax; 4, 145 s.v. sperglawanag; SEJL 451 s.v. kálnas; 1500 s.v. vãnagas.

nom.-acc.pl. of vanagpriẽde 'hawk pine.' Only attested as a TN, perhaps in the sense 'Vanagi pines.' | Compound of vanags 'hawk, falcon' and priẽde 'pine (pinus silvestris).' First element cognate with Lt. vãnagas and the second element of compounds OPr. sperglawanag 'sparrowhawk' and gertoanax 'goshawk.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Vãnagas (LPDB) Po. Jastrząb (ISNP) HG Habicht (DFD). Second element probably has cognates in OPr. TNs Preydazare Predekaim a.o. Derived from a verb *preiti 'be superior' or a compound of *prie- and *dēti, i.e., 'put in front.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. Lt. Priedė (LPDB) Po. Sosna (ISNP) HG Kiefer (DFD). | ALEW s.v. vãnagas; Karulis 2001, 714 s.v. priede; 2001, 1115 s.v. vanags; LEW 1194 s.v. vãnagas; ME 4, 468 s.v. vanags; PKEŽ 1, 357 s.v. gertoanax; 4, 145 s.v. sperglawanag; SEJL 1500 s.v. vãnagas.
_alternative etymology: priede from *piedre 'resinous' and related to Gr. πῑδύω 'spring forth' ON fita 'fat' a.o. (ME 3, 392 s.v. I priẽde).

_etymology: pl.tant. vȩcduõles pilsdrupas 'Old Duole castle ruins.' | Syntagm of gen.sg. of TN vȩcduõle 'Old Duole' and pilsdrupas 'castle ruins.' Primary element hereof is duõle, borrowed from MLG FN Dōlen after Johann von Dolen, the first owner of the object (Tuulse 1942, 39). Etymologically to dāle~dōle 'jackdaw (coloeus monedula),' cf. HG Dohle (DFD). | AK.

_etymology: nom.pl. of TN Vȩcjȩ̃rāni 'Old Jȩ̃rāni.' | Compound of vȩcs 'old' and TN Jȩ̃rāni. Primary element is TN Jȩ̃rāni, nom.pl. of FN Jȩ̃rāns (LUV). āns-derivation originally in a purely associative sense to jȩ̃rs 'lamb' which is cognate with Lt. ė́ras 'id.' OCS jěrъ 'spring' Go. jēr 'year' ON ár 'id.' and further related to OPr. eristian 'lamb' Av. yārə 'year' Gr. ὤρα 'id.' a.o. The original r/n-stem has been thematicized in BS and Germanic. | Derksen 2015, 154 s.v. ėras; Kroonen 2013, 273 s.v. *jēra-; LEW 121 s.v. ė́ras; ME 2, 114 s.v. jȩ̃rs; SEJL 425 s.v. jė́ras.

pl.tant. vȩckaļķi 'old Kaļķi.' | Compound of vȩcs 'old' and top. kaļ̃ķi. Top. kaļ̃ķi is nom.pl. of kaļ̃ķis 'limestone, chalk; lime pipe; (pl.) quicklime' ← HG Kalk or MLG kalk 'chalk,' cf. also Lt. kálkis Po. kalka. It also exists as a FN (LUV), probably in the sense of a limeburner, cf. Lt. Kálkis (LPDB) Po. Kalka (ISNP) HG Kalk (DFD). | ME 2, 147.

TN Vȩckal̂nieši 'Old Kalnieši.' | Compound of vȩcs 'old' and TN Kal̂nieši. Primary element is TN Kal̂nieši, nom.pl. of kal̂nietis 'highlander.' ietis-derivation to kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' Cognate with Lt. kalniẽtis to kálnas. Also a FN (LUV). | ME 2, 142.

pl.tant. vȩckvederi 'Old Kvederi.' Compound of vȩcs 'old' and FN Kvederis 'Theodore' (LUV?). Cf. Lt. Kvederis (LPDB). | Borrowed from Lt. FN Kvederis or BRu. FN Xvedor. Ultimately from Gr. Θεόδωρος 'God's gift.' | AK.

Rũķis & Rũķītis. | ii̯o-derivation to the root in rũķêt 'be industrious' ← MLG ruken. The D is used especially in the sense 'dwarf, industrious house spirit.' | ME 3, 570 s.v. I rũķis.

nom.sg. TN Vucȩnu siliņš 'Vucȩni forest.' | Syntagm of gen. of TN Vucȩni and siliņš, D to sils 'pinewoods.' Primary element is TN Vucȩni, nom.pl. of vucȩns 'ram.' enas-derivation to an unattested *vuks, cf. avins 'ram' to avs 'sheep.' *vuks is itself an ukas-derivation to a V of avs 'sheep' without the initial a-. Also a FN (LUV). | ME 4, 675 s.v. vuc! & vucȩns.

nom.pl. of ziêdkal̂ns 'blossom hill.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. HG Blumberg (DFD). | Compound of ziêds 'blossom' and kal̂ns 'mountain, hill.' First element is cognate with Lt. žíedas 'blossom; ring.' Suffixal variation suggests an original n-stem *kolH-(e)n-~*kl̥H-n-. Derived from PIE *kel- 'rise.' | ALEW s.v. kálnas žíedas1 žíedas2; Derksen 2015, 221 s.v. kalnas; 2015, 518 s.v. žíedas; LEW, 209 s.v. kálnas; 1305 s.v. žydė́ti 2; ME 2, 143 s.v. kal̂ns; 4, 739 s.v. lejas zvidzȩ̄ni 'Lower Zvidzēni.' Nom.pl. of zvidzȩ̄ns 'guffawer.' Probably a FN, cf. Zvidzāns (LUV). | ēna-derivation to the root in zvigât 'guffaw,' cf. also zviga zvigulis a.o. | ME 4, 774 s.v. zviga zvigât zvigulis.
nom.pl. of zviẽdrẽns 'of the Swede.' | ēna-derivation to zviẽdrs 'Swede' ← MLG *sweder, cf. HG Schweder and Lt. žviedras. | ME 4, 782 s.v. II zviẽdrs.
_alternative etymology: to zvìedrs 'coarse sand' (ME 4, 782 s.v. I zvìedrs)

_etymology: nom.pl. of zvīgulis 'shiny drop, bead; shimmer.' Also a FN (LUV). | To zvàigzne 'star.' Cognate with Lt. žvygulỹs 'something shiny; shimmer.' | ME 4, 779 s.v. I zvīgulis.
_alternative etymology: zvīgulis 'someone who always laughs loudly' (ME 4, 779 s.v. zvīgulis).

_etymology: nom.pl. of zvir̃bulis 'sparrow.' Also a FN (LUV), cf. also Lt. Žvìrblis (LPDB) Po. Wróbel (ISNP) HG Sperling (DFD). | Cognate with Lt. žvìrblis, possibly with -ulis for -lis on the model of cīrulis 'lark' svāpulis 'bullfinch' a.o. Perhaps further related to Ru. vorobéj Po. wróbel if contaminated with zvĩgurs 'id.' vel sim. | ALEW s.v. žvìrblis; LEW 1328; ME 4, 776; SEJL 1656.
_alternative etymology: -ulis is the original suffix, cf. Po. wróbel 'sparrow' (ME 4, 777).
